business.start.para: Mr. SPEAKER (Hon. Sir John McLeay) took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - I ask the Postmaster-General a question without notice. 1 have been informed that members of the Australian Broadcasting Commission's orchestra have not been granted a wage increase of $2 although technicians who work with them have received the $2 increase. What is the reason for this discrimination? Are not members of the orchestra entitled to the $2 increase granted by the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

- I am afraid I cannot give the honorable member a direct answer. I will certainly look into the matter he has raised. Yesterday I approved an additional payment in relation to journalists employed by the Australian Broadcasting Commission but there are so many categories of employees within the Commission that it is impossible to keep up to date with all of them. I know that there have been discussions between certain groups and the management of the Commission. I will see what details I can obtain and advise the honorable member.

- Will the Minister for the Army consider attaching selected Citizen Military Forces officers as observers to the Australian Regular Army battalions in Vietnam for a period of, say, a fortnight or more in order that they may gain some experience with these battle units, which would be of great benefit, I am sure, to the morale of the C.M.F.?

- The honorable member will know that, in the normal course of their duties, officers of the Australian Regular Army go to Vietnam on staff and liaison duties for periods of up to two or three weeks at times. I am hoping that within a relatively short time it will be possible to send selected officers of the C.M.F., probably of the rank of captain and major, to Vietnam for two or three weeks to see at first hand the conditions in which our forces are operating. I believe such experience would be of particular value to their units in Australia. It is too early to give a firm decision on this matter but I have every hope that the right decision will be reached.

- My question, directed to the Minister for Immigration, is prompted by the case of a school teacher who has migrated from the United States of America because he no longer wants to work and live in the integrated racial conditions which the United States Supreme Court, Congress and Administration have striven to achieve. What inquiries does the Department of Immigration make into the racist views of the increasing number of applicants in the United States and the decreasing number in South Africa and Rhodesia? In view of the repercussions for Australia in the world generally and not least in the countries of origin, what attitude does the Department take towards those prospective migrants who proclaim their view of Australia as a racial refuge?

- I would say that the inquiries made regarding people who are migrating from countries such as the United States of America would cover security, character, general background and fitness to be in this country. I would not imagine that personal views such as those mentioned by the honorable member would be canvassed. Perhaps it is unwise for people to express extreme views, but I should think that the views expressed from time to time by honorable members on the other side of the House are far more extreme than any views held by this gentleman.

- My question is directed to the Minister for the Interior. Can he say definitely on what date the rolls for the forthcoming election will close? Will his Department publicise the desirability of all eligible persons who are not on the rolls making application to be included before that date?

- I cannot say definitely on what date the rolls will close, as it is not my province to announce the date for the issue of the writs. However, I think this will be done in the very near future. It is with the issue of the writs that the rolls are closed. After that date, people cannot have their names put on the rolls. I will take note of the honorable member's suggestion that publicity be given to the need for people to become enrolled. I will see whether we can do something now to encourage anybody whose name is not on the rolls to become enrolled immediately.

- I address my question to the Minister for Territories. Will he say whether the Government intends to withhold assent to the Land Tenure Transitional Provisions Bill which was passed by the Legislative Council of the Northern Territory? In view of the uncertainty, and in many cases actual hardship occasioned to occupants of the land involved, by the delay in giving assent, will the Minister take urgent action to promulgate the legislation without further delay?

- A decision has not been taken on the .-Bill mentioned by the honorable member Tor the Northern Territory. I also have a great concern for the people on the coastal plains area who at present, in a sense, have a temporary licence for occupation. It is unfortunate that the Bill includes some amendments which, in my view, do not accord with the Government's policy. I am awaiting the decision of Cabinet on this matter. I hope it will be dealt with very soon.

- I desire to ask the Minister for Social Services a question. He will be aware that, where a large number of pension cheques are handled by a post office in a relatively small centre, such as Tingha in northern New South Wales, some difficulty is experienced by business houses in providing cash when this is requested by pensioners. This situation is brought about because Tingha, like many other centres of a similar size, is visited by a bank on only one day each week. Can the Minister suggest a means of overcoming this problem?

- The honorable gentleman and other honorable members have been in constant touch with officers of my Department and with me since we announced a change would be made to try to encourage all pensioners to receive their pensions by cheque. There does seem to be some difficulty for residents of Tingha, the town mentioned by the honorable member for Gwydir, and residents of other small communities. Consequently, in any circumstances where a pensioner believes that it is to his advantage to continue to receive his pension payment by order book, arrangements are being made for him to continue to do so. However, the order book system., is not completely efficient administratively and it is intended at some, time in the future, although planning is not yet complete, to transfer from an. order book to a type of cash voucher which will be transferable in the same way as the present vouchers .extracted from the order book are. It is hoped that it, will be possible for these to be converted into cash to meet the convenience of pensioners who find that payment by cheque is not satisfactory. At the same time I would say that over '90 per cent, of pensioners are now receiving payment by cheque, and this seems to be meeting their needs in terms of availability of pension money.

- I ask the Prime Minister: Does he know that serious discontent exists in certain Commonwealth Government departments because of long standing grievances relating to annual leave and the payment of wage and salary increments? Will the right honorable gentleman, as Leader of the Government, take immediate action to provide annual leave benefits to Commonwealth employees on the same basis as those enjoyed by workers employed by the State of New South Wales? Finally, will he, at this belated hour, give effect to the principle of equal pay to male and female workers engaged in similar work classifications?

- Dealing with the latter part of the question first, I point out that the Government's view on this question of equal pay was stated by me when I was Minister for Labour and National Service. It was reaffirmed by my colleague, the present Treasurer, when he held the portfolio of Labour and National Service, and I think it has been reaffirmed also by the present holder of that portfolio. There should be no ambiguity about our position, but I shall see that a copy of the Government's official statement on this matter is made available to the honorable gentleman. He asked about annual leave and about wages and conditions. I do not know specifically what he had in mind in respect of wages and conditions, but if he gives me a little more detail 1 shall try to let him have a full answer. Some time ago I received a deputation of representatives of the Public Service organisations and I undertook to bring the views of that deputation, which was pressing for four weeks' annual leave for Commonwealth public servants, to the Cabinet. A Cabinet submission has been prepared which goes fully into this matter. I should expect it to be considered shortly and a decision to bc reached for announcement before the Parliament rises.
- And before the present Bill is passed? There is a Public Service Bill on the Senate notice paper.
- But not dealing with annual leave.

- Is the Minister for Defence aware of any solution to a major problem arising out of two proposals from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition; first, that Australian troops be withdrawn from Vietnam and, secondly, that Australia send a large team of civilian workers to that country? Will he endeavour to ascertain whether the latter proposal has complete disregard for Australian lives or whether it anticipates a guarantee of safety either by the Vietcong or the United States and allied enlisted men whom we would have deserted-

- Mr. Speaker, I rise to order. You were not here during the last few weeks when other questions were asked purporting to be based on statements I had made. It is not difficult from " Hansard " or from other sources to verify what I have said. I would expect you, Sir, to insist that a person basing a question on a report should be ready to verify that report. During your absence another question was based on a report which was said to be a report of something I had said on television, and the next day the newspaper from which the questioner had been quoting expressed regret that it had misreported me. The technique that has been developed by some honorable members opposite is to take some summary of remarks, place an interpretation on it and then ask a Minister to comment. It is not a matter in respect of which a Minister has any responsibility, and the questioners are not in a position to verify the ostensible reports, in relation to some of which in fact the newspapers have later expressed regret for having been inaccurate.

- Order! I point out to the honorable member for Evans that he has directed attention to a statement and has quoted from it. Under the Standing Orders it will be necessary for him to vouch for the accuracy of the statement.
- I verify that I have seen, in the ordinary and accepted means of communication-
- Order! The honorable member has a straight out obligation, that is, to vouch for the accuracy of the statement, or not.
- Yes, I vouch for it.

- Mr. Speaker, I raise a point of order. An honorable member cannot vouch for a statement by merely asserting that he vouches for it. 1 submit the honorable member has to prove to your satisfaction that what he says, is true. I would not believe a word he says.
- Order! I point out to the honorable member for Evans that it is to the House that he is guaranteeing that he can vouch for the accuracy of the statement.
- I saw it on television and I still vouch for it.
- Order! Does the honorable member persist with his guarantee as to the accuracy of the statement?
- Yes.
- I call the Minister for Defence.

- This seems to be where we came in last week. I hope we can get through this situation without a repeat of last week's performance. 1 have not seen the report to which the honorable gentleman refers and therefore I should like to have the details of it. I hope honorable gentlemen opposite will remember what has been said today when they ask questions of Ministers in the future because if they are required to verify the statements on which they base their questions there will be a lot fewer questions asked in the House. All I can say is that I am generally aware of the vast variety of interpretations given by the Labour Party of what purports to be its policy.
- Nonsense.
- There is no nonsense about it. The honorable gentleman himself has contributed something like 10 variations on the same theme.
- Nothing of the sort.

- I can only say in answer to the question that the House and the people of Australia must be completely confused on what the Opposition proposes. There have been various reports, some of them undoubtedly authenticated by the newspapers themselves, containing photostats of the texts from which statements have been made. These indicate that, immediately on election to office, the Labour Party would bring home the whole of the Australian force.
- No, no. That is wrong too. You do not even read.
- Yes I do.
- I do not think you can read.

- The honorable gentleman may correct me and I will accept the correction gladly because I will be happy to know if I have misinterpreted him, but he did propose to bring home all the national servicemen.
- That is right.
- This inevitably involves the complete withdrawal, or at least the regrouping and perhaps retraining, of the whole Australian component in Vietnam.
- That is completely wrong too.
- And the whole component will be coming out between March and June under your own programme. The Australian generals in Vietnam told me this.

- Here is another statement by the Deputy Leader of the Party who quotes the dates on which Australian servicemen will come out of Vietnam. As I am completely unaware of any agreement with the United States on this, it means the Labour Party proposes to reduce our troops without any by-your-leave and without proper consultation with our ally, the United States. I hardly think this is the code of behaviour anyone in Australia would like its Government of the future to follow. The only thing I have to say is that the Labour Party is completely confused as between the military effort and the effort of civil reconstruction which essentially must follow it. There can be no guarantee of peace and security for the agencies of reconstruction, unless it is military security, until the matter in Vietnam is settled by victory or by agreement.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and Industry, is it a fact, as reported in the Adelaide " News ", of Thursday, 6th October 1966, that some motor vehicle companies have asked the Government to revise the 95 per cent. Australian content rule when annual sales of a model reach a level between 7,500 and 20,000 units? If this is a fact, has the Government yet made a decision on this most important matter? If it has not yet made a decision, will the Minister now provide a ray of hope and encouragement for the many thousands of workers in the Australian motor vehicle industry by giving a firm assurance that the Government does not intend to alter the prevailing conditions and so import further unemployment into this country?

- Reports on this matter have led to a misunderstanding of the position. The reports quite frequently state that the Government required some motor producers to achieve a 95 per cent. Australian content in their products by a certain date, and certain other motor producers a different content. The position is that for many years the motor industry has been assisted by a variety of means. One of the principal means has been to permit assemblers or manufacturers of motor cars in Australia to import important sections of cars without payment of duty, notwithstanding that duties were prescribed in the tariff schedule for some of these items. The forgiving of duty was done under the by-law system. This has proved a valuable method of encouraging the establishment of this great industry. But a point of time was reached at which a very big proportion of components was being imported duty free, notwithstanding that the tariff schedule provided for duties. The Government decided to regularise this position and it told the companies that they could continue to import their components duty free for a period of five years if they declared that by the end of that time they would have a 95 per cent. Australian content in their products. This is desirable. It will provide employment and save exchange. It is desirable in every respect.

answer.para: This meant that for the first time one motor company would know the circumstances in which another motor company was importing items, and whether it was paying duty or not paying duty. Quite a number of motor vehicle assemblers and manufacturers took advantage of this proposition. Now that there has been, not what I am prepared to call a recession in the motor industry but a relapse from an extremely high level of production and registration to a level some 20,000 units or more a year below that previously high level, some of the companies have said that they are quite content to go on but others have said that they see themselves having some trouble. In these circumstances what we have said is: " Right, come and talk to us. If you can establish that the engagement you entered into is difficult for you to live up to and that without prejudicing the general objectives of the Government we can have a standstill period and extend the time within which you will reach the 95 per cent. Australian content, we will be quite ready to consider granting such an extension." At the present time officials of the Department are active in discussions, with a view to eliciting the facts, with the motor companies that are asking for this modification of the engagement which they voluntarily entered into.

talk.start.para: - I direct this question to you, Mr. Speaker. I ask whether you have examined or thought about the situation that existed previously when we had a number of Parliamentary UnderSecretaries. Are you prepared to give a ruling before you retire, as I also shall be doing, as to the validity of the position of Under-Secretary?
- I think this is a matter that is outside the administration of the Speaker and, therefore, it is out of order to direct such a question to him at question time.

- On the same point, Mr. Speaker, will you consider the ruling given by your predecessor that UnderSecretaries have no position in the Parliament under the Constitution and therefore could not be called upon to answer questions; and if they took salary for service as Under-Secretary they would be liable to have their seats declared vacant?
- I would say this: My great reverence and respect for the late Archie Cameron's judgment would indicate to me that I would be 99 per cent, correct today in agreeing with what he said on this matter.

- I direct a question to the Minister for Defence. I preface it by saying that from my recent observations in Saigon I know that the flags of some 14 nations are flying to indicate that they provide civilian aid to South Vietnam. Is it not a fact that most of these nations have no troops in Vietnam to protect their civilian personnel?
- It may also be that the nations whose flags fly in Saigon are acting under the military protection of nations who do have troops there.
- What has that got to do with it?
- It has a fair bit to do with it. I merely say that the Labour Party is getting its priorities completely mixed.
- The Minister is in trouble. Two marks out of ten.
- Order!
- I am not in any trouble, Mr. Speaker. I merely say that the Labour Party is putting the cart before the horse. The country must be pacified before we can build with any security.

- My question is directed to the Minister for the Interior, and I preface it by reminding him that in many polling centres at election time great difficulty is often experienced in securing satisfactory personnel to man the booths, ls it true that, as a result of a ruling given by the Commonwealth Electoral Officer, in future such personnel will not be reappointed if they are over the age of 65 years, and that in exceptional circumstances this may be extended to 70 years of age? If this is so, will the Minister 'consider altering the instructions to allow the Divisional Returning Officer the authority to reappoint personnel of any age, providing that those to be appointed have the qualifications and ability that would be beneficial to all concerned?

- There is no .prohibition on polling clerks being over the age of 65. It is the responsibility of the Divisional Returning Officer to obtain personnel who will provide the highest standards of practical efficiency on polling day. Although the job of polling clerk is not difficult, it requires long hours of concentrated work and does tax the stamina and eyesight, of the polling official. It is for this reason that the Divisional Returning Officer tries to obtain younger people if possible. However, where qualifications are equal, preference is given to ex-servicemen or to persons in indigent circumstances.

- I direct my question to the Minister for Civil Aviation. Is he aware that on 6th July 1965 the Newcastle City Council wrote to the New South Wales Regional Director of Civil Aviation and sought the provision of air space necessary for a civil airport for Newcastle on the Hexham site and that since that date the Lord Mayor, aldermen and the Town Clerk have written, phoned and personally interviewed the Regional Director asking for a reply and a decision? Why has not the Council received a reply to these representations, and are there any sound reasons for not granting the necessary air space so that Newcastle can have a civil airport independent of the Royal Australian Air Force base at Williamtown? Does the Department of Air object to the granting of this air space because the site of the proposed civil airport at Hexham is close to the R.A.A.F. base at Williamtown? Will the Minister have the Council's request investigated immediately so that it can have a reply to its correspondence of 6th July 1965?

- It has not been possible so far to conclude the matter in relation to proposals for an airport at Hexham. It is a fact that the Council there has written to my Department in Sydney and raised the matter on several occasions. It is a fact also that my Department has replied to the Council. I believe that two or three letters have been written to the Council. The first was in the form of an acknowledgment, and then followed a letter advising that the matter was still under consideration but that no decision had been made regarding the proposals which had been submitted.

answer.para: The honorable member also has written to me direct regarding this matter, I think at the request of the Chamber of Commerce in Newcastle. The reply that I gave him a couple of months ago indicated that we were still negotiating with the Royal Australian Air Force regarding the control of air space in this region. I am afraid that situation still applies today.

This matter is not easy of solution because quite a large R.A.A.F. base is established there and quite an amount of civilian traffic is operating in the region at the same time on a commercial basis, as well as general aviation. Consequently, I am afraid that I cannot give the honorable member an answer at the present time. Negotiations are still proceeding and. as soon as it is possible to do so, I will advise him of the decision.

talk.start.para: - I address a question to the Minister for Trade and Industry. Is there any accuracy in the report which indicated that Australia was willing to consider reducing tariffs on imports of Japanese industrial goods in return for concessions on primary produce sent from Australia to Japan? Can the Minister tell the House what manufacturing goods would be involved in an agreement of this nature?

- The position is that Australia is engaged in negotiations with all countries which are parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, pursuant to the Kennedy Round of negotiations. The character of these negotiations is that each country will negotiate with any other trading partner with which there is scope for negotiation, but no finality will be concluded bilaterally. If any progress were made it would be endorsed only in a total sense within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and, therefore, any concessions given by any country as an outcome of negotiation, even with one country, would be concessions given to every one which was a party to it. The whole concept of this is that Australia, seeking concessions, must be willing to give concessions.

answer.para: I make two points here: First, I secured a decision at a meeting of the Kennedy Round countries that Australia was absolved from the general rule of a uniform tariff cut. We, New Zealand and South Africa have been absolved from that rule, so we are under no obligation. But we have said that we will pay for it. I have said repeatedly, as I Say now, that we will not make tariff concessions which prejudice existing Australian industries - that is flat and unqualified - but there are a number of items on which we can reduce tariffs. I refer to industrial items which we do not produce in Australia and which there is no prospect of producing in Australia. Many of these items have been identified for us by the Tariff Board. A list of the items covered by the inquiry is available to any honorable member who wants it. Some are items in respect of which we can offer to reduce tariffs without prejudicing an Australian industry. There is another category of tariff items in respect of which we give a certain level of preference in our tariff schedule as a result of existing trade treaties. If the existing trade treaties are altered as an outcome of the Kennedy Round tariff negotiations, we shall be free to make reductions in some of those cases where we have given preferences already. But that would be the outcome of what some other countries did, not the result of our initiative. I repeat to the House and the country that it is not the intention of this Government to make tariff concessions which will prejudice existing Australian industries.

talk.start.para: - I should like to preface my question, which is addressed to the Treasurer, by referring to the reply given by him yesterday in which he said that he felt that some incentives could be given to the production of gold by way of a subsidy on an international basis and, further, that while some time could elapse before this happened, he felt that it would eventually happen. I now ask the Treasurer: Will he, for the purpose of ensuring that there is no further decline in Australia's gold mining industry between now and the time when a determination in relation to an international incentive is arrived at by the International Monetary Fund, take immediate action to provide an increase in the present subsidy to both large and small producers with a view to helping to offset the rather substantial increase in the costs of production which has occurred since the Gold-mining Industry Assistance Act was amended some 16 months ago? If he will not do this, then how does he substantiate his argument that any currency should be tied to gold?

- Dealing with the last part of the honorable gentleman's question first, let me say that there is no logical connection between his question and my statement yesterday. I believe there is a strong case for an increase in international liquidity and I believe also that there is a very strong case for tying any increase in liquidity to gold. After all, gold is the. foundation of international finance at the moment, and we think it should stay that way. As to the part of the honorable gentleman's question relating to the subsidy, this is a matter of Government policy and as yet I have received no request about it.

- I address to the Minister for Trade and Industry a question which follows to some extent that asked by the honorable member for Balaclava. The New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement has now been in operation for some period. Can the right honorable gentleman state whether any dislocation has occurred to Australian industries, in particular to the dairy, pigmeat, bean and pea industries'.' I ask this question in view of the fears expressed by members of the Opposition last year and engendered by them in those industries.

- The New ZealandAustralia Free Trade Agreement has been in operation for more, than nine months now, and figures of trade for the first eight months of this year are available. Notwithstanding all the scaremongering that went on earlier for political reasons, the position is that no pigmeat has been imported from New Zealand in that period. This arises from the fact that there was and still is a quarantine restriction. Not one pound of pigmeat has been imported. But, because of the rumours that were circulated. I was fortunate enough to have the President of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Pig Society write to me a month ago saying -

quote.para: We were worried about the outcome of this Agreement and we would have been upset if we had been prejudiced. In the circumstances, I think it is fair to lel] you, Mr. McEwen, that in Sydney recently we have had inquiries as to whether Australia can supply pigmeat to New Zealand.

answer.para: The Agreement permitted 400 tons of cheddar cheese to come into Australia this year. For the first eight months of the year, the rate of entry of cheddar cheese has been approximately three-quarters of the permitted rate of 400 tons a year. So no danger has arisen there. This is not an arranged question, but it so happens that I have in my hand a letter which I received from my colleague, the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty). He has been very watchful of the interests of the vegetable growers in Tasmania who had their fears aroused in connection with this Agreement. I think that the House, which has displayed great interest in the proposition, will be willing to listen to me for about another 30 seconds. Senator Henty tells me that he approached various processors of green peas in Tasmania. The first factory advised that it had already contracted at the volume for which it contracted last year. The second factory advised Senator Henty that it had doubled last year's contract purchases of green peas. The third factory advised him that it had substantially increased its contract. There were two factory processors of green beans. The first of these advised Senator Henty that its contracts for this year were 50 per cent, higher than those for last year.

talk.start.para: - What rubbish.

- This is unpleasant hearing, is it not? It brings out the lying and the scaremongering that you practised before. The second factory processing green beans advised that it had contracted for a 100 per cent, increase compared to its contracts for last year.
- Did the Minister say " lying "?
- Yes, I said " lying ".
- Order! 1 think the right honorable gentleman-

- I said that there was lying last year. If the Deputy Leader of the Opposition likes, I shall withdraw that remark. What was said last year was wrong, lt was incorrect. In respect of processed carrots, the first factory reported a substantial increase in its contracts. The second factory reported a 100 per cent, increase in its contract purchases.
- This is question time. The Minister should not make his reply too long.

- There is just one more item - red beet. I am sure that the honorable gentleman is very interested. The first factory processing red beet reported a substantial increase in its contracts. The second factory reported a 100 per cent, increase. I want to be frank about the facts. The only ripple that I see on the surface is some indication that there may be an assault on the Australian paper market in respect of a certain item from New Zealand, and this could generate a counter attack by Australian paper producers, which was possible under the terms of the New ZealandAustralia Free Trade Agreement. I say, as I have said before in this House: This would be a very unhappy byproduct of an agreement designed to be for the good of both countries.

- I direct a question to the Minister for the Army. Will he arrange for troops taking part in the exercise known as Operation Barra Winga to parade through Rockhampton in accordance with the representations that I made to him last month on behalf of the Rockhampton Sub-branch of the Returned Services League of Australia?

-I may owe the honorable member an apology. As he says, he made representations to me on this matter. Through channels in which this was not known and in which it was not realised that I had become interested in the matter, the fact that a march through Rockhampton is to be held has already been announced, I think. This march will take place on 5th November. It will involve about 2.500 troops, comprising two infantry battalions, a mechanised column and a cavalry squadron. There will be a fly past of Army light aircraft at the same time. This event will take place at the end of the exercise, and most of the troops will march through Rockhampton on their way to the railway station.I would like to make just one other point: The Army is most appreciative of the way in which the authorities and the people in Rockhampton have co-operated with the Service since it has been involved in the Shoalwater Bay area. This is something that has made the part that we play much easier than it might have been.

- My question is directed to the Minister for Social Services. I ask: As the system of establishing regional offices of the Department of Social Services outside metropolitan areas has met with approval and success, will the Minister make investigations with a view to opening an office of his Department in the city of Dubbo in the Lawson electorate where it should serve more than the number of people necessary to justify the existence of a regional office?

- Like many other honorable members, the honorable member for Lawson has an interest in securing a regional office of my Department not only in Dubbo but in other centres in his electorate. In the past 12 months the Department has extended into quite a number of country centres and intends in the future to open regional offices wherever possible. However, the opening of an office depends on the amount of business within a community. Although there is within a radius of 20 miles of Dubbo a population of about 28,000 people there is not at this time a great deal of inquiry from the officer who attends Dubbo from Orange as business warrants. I will look into the possibility of opening an office in Dubbo in the future but I cannot hold out any immediate prospect.

. - by leave - Honorable members will recall that, in reply to a question without notice by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell), I said that the Government was planning on the basis that the general election would be held on 26th November this year. I now wish to inform the House that this date has been confirmed. The intention is to dissolve the House of Representatives as at noon on 31st October 1966. The date set for the issue of writs is 3 1st October 1966. Nominations will close on 7th November 1966.

talk.start.para: - In accordance with the provisions of the Public

speech.para: Works Committee Act 1913-1965 I present the report relating to the following proposed work -

quote.para: Development of Airfield Pavements at Coolangatta Airport, Queensland.

speech.para: I ask for leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

talk.start.para: - There being no objection, leave is granted.

- The proposal is that the main runway shall be extended by 500 feet to 6,500 feet with a sealed stopway of 200 feet at each end. The main taxiway is to be widened from 50 feet to 75 feet to comply with international requirements and a new loop taxiway is to be constructed between the runway and the existing main taxiway.

speech.para: The two airline companies serving Coolangatta - Ansett-A.N.A. and TransAustralia Airlines - intend to upgrade the services provided by using Electra and DC9 aircraft as soon as possible to cope with the heavy increase in passenger traffic at this popular centre. Construction of the works in this reference is recommended with an addendum that the adequacy of aircraft parking facilities should be kept under review. The attention of the Committee was drawn to the fact that at some peak periods there is some congestion on the parking apron, usually caused by the scheduling of flights by both companies originating from Melbourne and Sydney but arriving at Coolangatta at approximately the same time. A small adjustment of timetables would overcome this problem. In addition, it is felt that the provision of the loop taxiway will offer holding facilities for loaded aircraft waiting to take off while other aircraft landing might require the use of the runway and the parking apron. The cost of the proposal as referred to the Committee is $1.3 million.
Ordered that the report be printed.
Rebuilding at H.M.A.S. " Nirimba ".

speech.para: I do so to express condemnation of the Government for its failure to conduct an inquiry into all aspects of education in government and non-government schools and for its failure to make adequate provision for teacher training. The standards in Australian secondary schools in particular are not keeping up with the standards of comparable countries because the Commonwealth has not concerned itself with them. The Commonwealth's involvement has been inhibited by the two issues of State rights and State aid. In the last 20 years, the Commonwealth has assumed the sole or the major role in almost all the important fields which used to be described as State responsibilities. It provides all the finance for housing and rail standardisation and more than half the finance for road construction, health services and universities. Schools are the only substantial exception in this postwar pattern, and they represent the greatest single item in every State budget.

The Australian school system is a dual one. State finances are fully committed to departmental schools. It is not practicable for the States to divert funds to needy private schools, lt is not practicable for the Commonwealth to help one sector alone of the dual system. It must help both if it is to help either. Only the Commonwealth can now ensure that an equal opportunity is given to every student to develop his natural talents, irrespective of his parents' locality, religion, means and occupation. As long ago as 1945, the Chifley Government passed the Education Act, which provides for Commonwealth grants to the States and to other authorities for educational purposes. The Act set up the Commonwealth Office of Education to advise on these grants to public and private schools. The staff of the office was slashed in half in 1951. Temporary and specific committees had to be set up later to recommend and implement Commonwealth aid to education. The science blocks legislation in 1964 was the first Commonwealth innovation without a preliminary inquiry. It has been rendered largely ineffective through the subsequent rejection of the Martin Committee's recommendations for teacher training.

The former Prime Minister, every year since we started moving a resolution on the estimates for his Department in these terms - I think the first occasion was 1958 - always rejected our proposition and all his supporters joined him in voting against it. The present Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt), I regret to say, in answer to a question asked by my colleague, the honorable member for Stirling (Mr. Webb), has repeated the refusal to hold an inquiry into Australia's primary and secondary education needs. His justification is that inquiries of this kind are matters for each State. lt is still apparently necessary to survey the field of Commonwealth and State financial relations before one deals with this greatest single remaining item of State financial responsibility. In the last full financial year before the First World War, the total revenue and loan expenditure by the Commonwealth was 23,897,000. By the States, it was f 68,007,000. In the last complete financial year before the Second World War, the total expended by the Commonwealth was 98,596,000 and by the States 128,535,000. This, it is necessary to recall, was before the time of uniform income tax. The first figures were before the days of the Financial Agreement. The financial situation of the Commonwealth and the States has been completely transposed in the course of the last generation. I shall now deal, in greater detail, with the proportion of State budgets which has been spent on education. In the last complete financial year before the First World War, 8.25 per cent, of State budgets was spent on education. In the last complete financial year before the Second World War, it was 9.43 per cent. In 1963-64, the last period for which it has been possible for me to elicit information by questions on notice addressed to the Treasurer (Mr. McMahon), it had risen to 20.89 per cent. It is quite clear that the percentage of the State budgets being spent on education is now rising by geometric proportion. It is of interest to notice that the State activity on which there has been the greatest decline in expenditure - in fact, a corresponding decline in expenditure - has been public transport.

I now analyse the proportions of the State expenditures on education in the various fields. Here I quote from the reports made to us each year by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. In 1942-43, the first financial year for which the Commission dissect. a the different school expenditures, the States' expenditure on universities per head of population was ls. 3d. In 1963-64 it was 28s. 2d. On secondary education between those years, it rose from 4s. 9d. to 86s. 5d. On primary education, it rose from 25s. 2d. to 144s. Id. It will be noticed, Mr. Chairman, that between these years the expenditure per head on primary education increased sixfold; on secondary education and on university education, twentyfold. It is in university education alone that the Commonwealth has helped to meet the bill. The lavish special plea put in by the Government in July of this year under the title " The Commonwealth Government in Education " lists the percentage of current State revenues devoted to education in 1964-65 as over 3.1 per cent, and of gross loan expenditure as 19.4 per cent. The utter disparity between the Commonwealth's interest in university education - not tertiary education as a whole, because very notably there is no interest at all in teacher training, which is certainly tertiary education - and other education is made quite clear by this document. The interest in schools has been fractional.

The proportion of moneys found for universities by the Commonwealth has varied, according to an answer given to me yesterday by the Prime Minister, between 40.6 per cent, of the total income in the case of Monash University and 27.9 per cent, in the case of the University of Queensland. The percentage of total income received from the States varies between 50.6 per cent, in the case of Monash University and 33.5 per cent, in the case of the University of Sydney. On the other hand, fees over the years have amounted to an ever smaller proportion of the universities' incomes. The Martin Committee reported to us that in 1914 fees represented 30 per cent, of the income of universities. In 1944 they had decreased to 19 per cent., in 1950 to 18 per cent, and in 1954 to 11 per cent. In the figures the Prime Minister gave me yesterday, the percentage of the total income received from fees by the universities varied between 14.6 per cent, in the case of the University of Sydney and 4.5 per cent, in the case of Monash University. The f:cs. however, are in fact largely paid by the Commonwealth, because university fees paid by the Commonwealth varied between 44.5 per cent, of the total fees received by the University of Sydney and 19.8 per cent, of the total fees received by the University of New England. Whatever way we look at it, it is clear that university expenditure has risen and that the Commonwealth's interest in universities is continuing and expanding whereas the Commonwealth's interest in other forms of tertiary education and in secondary, technical and primary education has remained absent. If the States were unable to cope with university expenditure without equal Commonwealth participation how can they cope with their very much greater school expenditure without Commonwealth participation?

For some years past - ever since Professor Karmel's Buntine Oration in May 1962 - educationists and members of the Australian Labour Party have quoted the comparative percentages of gross national product spent on education in Australia and in the countries with which Australians compare themselves, and also the comparative percentage of teenagers undertaking full time education in Australia and in the countries with which we compare ourselves. Doubt has been cast by Government supporters at seminars, and in each chamber, on the current relevance of Professor Karmel's figures. The doubters did not attack Professor Karmel's figures for the years he quoted because Professor Karmel had been appointed by the Government to many of its ad hoc committees. On 4th October, however, at the 10th Theodore Fink Memorial Seminar at the University of Melbourne, Professor Karmel concluded that though the percentage of Australia's gross national product spent on education has risen, the increase has been enough merely to cater for the higher percentage of children in the school age group and represents no qualitative improvement at all over the 4i years since he delivered the Oration which we on this side support and which honorable members opposite disparage.

There has never been such a clear case of the absence of planning in any government field in Australia as there has been with education. In fact, the principal State field of expenditure is the one in which there has been no national investigation at all. The consequence is that greater and greater inequalities are developing in the opportunities available for Australians until they secure admission to universities.

The second part of my amendment refers to teaching. Teachers are the basis and the nucleus of all education. Australia's urgent need is to produce enough properly trained teachers in all subjects in all schools. As the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia recommended, teacher training must increasingly come under the auspices of the universities and thus of the Commonwealth. Only in this way will teacher training be accepted as a national responsibility and the status of teachers be raised. Teachers must more and more be regarded as members of a nationwide and international profession as well as members of a State public service or a religious order. Teacher training should be free of bonding and fees. Trained teachers should bc free to accept appointments wherever they choose, in State schools, private schools or Territory schools. Nobody with a knowledge of the cost of education or a knowledge of Commonwealth and State financial arrangements can fail to realise that our State and private schools will never acquire staff, facilities and equipment such as Australia needs and comparable countries provide, unless and until the Commonwealth comes to play as big and expanding a role in financing and co-ordinating them, both State and private, as it already plays in relation to the universities.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to refer to the operation of the Public Service Act and the Commonwealth Superannuation Act, both of which are under the administration of the Prime Minister's Department. In particular I want to refer to the modus operandi that is followed when a temporary member of the Public Service applies for permanent status. The acquisition of this status is vital to him for the rest of his career because it governs his promotion in the Public Service, his salary and, most of all, his superannuation. The Commonwealth lays down certain legislative requirements. One is the age qualification. A clerical examination has to be passed. A departmental agreement as to retention of service for a certain period of years has to be entered into, and finally the person must undergo a medical examination. I wish to refer to the medical examination. Where a member satisfies the other conditions I have mentioned, the medical examination has a threefold effect. It determines, first, whether he is eligible for superannuation. If he is not, it determines whether he is eligible to contribute to the Provident Account. Finally, it determines whether he is ineligible for either of those benefits.

speech.para: The medical examination is carried out by one Commonwealth medical officer. I know that in borderline cases this officer can refer to some of his colleagues. He can discuss the case with senior members of the Public Service Board. My point is that only one medical officer makes the physical and clinical examination of the member's body. I know that a set of standards is drawn up by the Public Service Board and the Department of Health and that they have a committee that meets several times a year to decide what standards shall be maintained and what standards shall be altered in accordance with changed medical techniques. However, the point is that the member is physically examined by one medical officer only, and that officer's opinion is not open to professional challenge. If a member disputes his rejection on medical grounds he may make a written request for his private medical officer to be furnished with his medical file. He can get a copy of the medical file, but he does not get the reasons for rejection. To my knowledge there is no other professional opinion in any field that is so insulated by departmental secrecy and which is not open to challenge by professional peers. Consequent upon this single opinion - an arbitrary opinion - a man's livelihood and that of his family may be materially affected. Changes in medical science, even in the postwar years, have been tremendous, and we must admit that the attitudes of medical men to changes can never be uniform, because how they react to changes in their own fields depends on individual antecedents. There is a wide variety of medical opinion even in respect of the more common complaints. I saw an article in the Melbourne " Sun News-Pictorial " some months ago written by Alan Trengove in which he quoted some remarks by Dr. M. O. Kent Hughes, Chairman of the Medical Education
Committee which operates under the auspices of the Australian College of General Practitioners. He said -

quote.para: The family doctor, like every other professional man, faces an unending struggle to cope with " the knowledge explosion ". Medical knowledge has doubled in the past 20 years and doctors today use only 30 per cent, of the drugs they prescribed seven years ago.

speech.para: Each one of us, from his own experience, knows of differing medical opinions and sometimes opposing views which have been offered by either general or specialist practitioners; but in the context of qualification for permanency in the Public Service we are left with only one medical opinion and, if that medical opinion is adverse to the applicant, it is not open to challenge. There is ne appeal. I took up this matter some time ago with the Minister for Health (Dr. Forbes) and more recently with the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt). 1 have recommended, the presentation of amending legislation to enable the establishment of a medical board of appeal to deal with disputed cases, a medical board where the applicant concerned can be represented by his own medical officer who will have communicated to him, as from one medical source to another, the reasons for the rejection of the application. Let me make myself clear. 1 offer no criticism of the Commonwealth medical officers. I have the highest regard for them. I am criticising only the system under which they work, a system which in my view is undemocratic and does not afford the degree of justice which is normally afforded in courts of law.

I illustrate my proposal by referring to a specific case. This concerns a young man who enlisted in the Royal Australian Air Force in 1952 after being medically examined and accepted for a six year term. In 1954 he was feeling a bit worried about certain matters so he went to his R.A.A.F. medical officer who suggested that the young man undergo psychiatric treatment. This he did. He had one month's rest in hospital, one month of insulin treatment and a further two months of occupational therapy and rest. He was finally discharged as cured in January 1955 and returned to his unit in which he continued to serve until 1958 when he was again medically examined for a further term of enlistment of six years. He was classified medically Al. When he completed that six year term in March 1964 he was again medically examined and classified Al. He was then a sergeant engine fitter. He signed on in the R.A.A.F. Reserve to which he is still bound.

Two days after discharge from the R.A.A.F. he was accepted for employment as a senior examiner with Quality Control Branch, Department of Air. He passed the examination for clerical assistant on 4th July 1964, was medically examined and was appointed to a permanent position. A month went by and he asked why he was not contributing to the Superannuation Fund. He was told that the Department had not yet received his Air Force medical file. To make a long story short, when the Department received his medical file it scrubbed him, despite the fact that this man, married with young children, had been in first class physical and mental health for the previous ten years. His whole future has been completely upset as a result of a single medical opinion which is confidential to the Public Service Board and from which there is no right of appeal. In reply to my representations, the Minister for Health said that the man's previous Air Force history had been examined and the decision as to his permanent appointment had not been taken lightly. The Department recommended that this young man was not acceptable as a contributor for superannuation benefits or even for the Provident Account. There the matter ends. There is no appeal.

Stemming from this matter of the medical examination of applicants for permanent employment there is the further matter which I have put before the Prime Minister for over three years. It concerns the people who apply for permanent appointment, are rejected and who remain temporary employees. They are denied all retirement benefits because of their lack of physical fitness. The present system is neither just nor fair. I suggested to the Prime Minister three years ago that these people should be given the option to contribute to the Provident Account on the express condition that if they failed for any reason to serve their full time until retirement they would accept repayment of their contributions in full settlement of their claim. This seems to me to be the perfectly normal thing to do. These people would then have the option, if they served their full time until retirement, as often occurs, of receiving a lump sum payment from the Provident Account upon retirement. Experience has shown that there are many people who have done this. Medical treatment these days is such that they have been able to continue working until the normal retiring age.

One can imagine how they feel when a person who joined the Service at the same time as they did and worked alongside them - one accepted for the Provident Account and the other not - retires with a substantial payment from the Provident Account while all they have is their furlough pay, provided they are entitled to that. One of my constituents was in this position. He suffered a heart condition and worked as a clerk but his heart condition did not interfere at all with his work. In fact, he did not lose one hour from work in the whole of his service. A fellow clerk who suffered acutely from stomach ulcers lost a good deal of time because he was in great pain but he had been accepted for the Provident Account. That man retired with a lump sum of $3,000 whereas my constituent retired with nothing.

The Prime Minister advised me on 18th February this year that my proposal was being examined but because it was a radical departure from present superannuation principles the examination must be necessarily a lengthy one. Personally, I do not agree that it is a radical departure because repayment of contributions when a member of any insurance scheme falls down on any of the conditions of his contract or agreement is a matter of precedent. If a man falls down on his contract his contributions are refunded and his contract is at an end. There is nothing radical in that. I cannot see why a fund like the Provident Account, which involves no actuarial consideration, could not operate in that way. The contributors pay in their money and the Account will not be adversely affected by the repayment to them of a lump sum. They will have made their contributions over the full term from the date of acceptance to the date of retirement. There can be no adverse effect.

I ask the Minister for Immigration (Mr. Opperman), who is at the table, to convey my remarks to the Prime Minister. It is now three years since this matter was first raised and I believe he should now give urgent consideration to that matter and also to the proposal to establish a medical board of appeal in the Public Service. If these two suggestions are implemented by amendments to the legislation I am sure the Public Service will be much happier in the future and a lot of the present dissatisfaction will be removed. I repeat the two prime matters that I have raised. First, I suggest the establishment of a medical board of appeal, and secondly, I suggest that applicants for permanency who are rejected on medical grounds should have the option to contribute to the Provident Account on the express conditions I have mentioned. If these two proposals are implemented I am certain the Public Service will be a much happier place in which to work.

Although one may agree with certain aspects of the amendment proposed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Whitlam), such as the lack of teacher training and so on, the appropriations have been determined. I support them and reject the amendment.

talk.start.para: . - I rise to support the amendment which has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Whitlam) as a means to condemn the Government for its failure to conduct an inquiry into all aspects of education in government and non-government schools and its failure to make adequate provision for teacher training. 1 assert that there is a very definite crisis in education in Australia today. I suggest that it takes a number of forms. First, we have insufficient and inadequately trained teachers. Secondly, there are no real plans for improving the supply of teachers with genuinely professional qualifications for either State or non-State schools. Thirdly, there is an appalling shortage of even reasonable classroom accommodation and teaching equipment. Fourthly, there are increasing inequalities of educational opportunities, arising out of heavy reliance on private coaching and also on parents' and citizens' organisations for the purchase of vital school requisites, including even capital items, such as libraries, gymnasiums and assembly halls. I assert that these inequalities are also intensified by the increasing scarcity of Commonwealth secondary school scholarships. Fifthly, only a very small amount of educational research is being carried on in Australia. Sixthly, there is a failure on the part of the Government to make any realistic assessment of what place the non-State system of education is to have in the Australian community.

speech.para: It is fair to say that stark poverty faces the State educational services - not only the State schools but also the private schools. I do not want to dwell on what goes on in respect of universities and on what the Government is doing in respect of colleges of advanced education. Legislation that is to come before the House shortly will provide me with ample opportunity to speak on those matters and the reports dealing with them. But there is one thing I do want to note, and that is that the Commonwealth Government has put the States in a most invidious position. It has denied them, at meetings of the Australian Loan Council, the funds necessary to carTy out important services, including the very vital education services. Then it has also set out, on the basis of the report of the Universities Commission and the report dealing with colleges of advanced education, a programme of assistance over the next three years which involves very substantial expenditure by the States to match Commonwealth grants. The programme for State universities envisaged by the Universities Commission involves the expenditure, for both capital and recurrent items, of $446 million over the period 1967-69.

It is all very well for the Commonwealth to tell the Australian public that something like S600 million is to be spent in the next three years on these two forms of tertiary education, but the situation bears a closer analysis. The Commonwealth's share of the expenditure for State universities will amount to $175 million out of a total of $446 million. In other words, the States will be required to find $271 million out of the total of $446 million. Moreover, of this total amount 74 per cent, is for what is described as recurrent expenses, and of this amount the States are required to provide $1.85 for every $1 provided by the Commonwealth. This imposes extremely heavy burdens on

State Governments. As a matter of fact this was recognised by the Universities Commission in its report, and the Commission made a very strong recommendation that from now on the Commonwealth should meet dollar for dollar the recurrent expenses of the universities and the tertiary colleges. But as those of us who have read the Minister's speech on the matter are aware, the Commonwealth has rejected Ais recommendation. As a result the States cannot even accept all the offers of the Commonwealth by way of matching grants, and so there will be $56 million less spent on this programme than was recommended by the Universities Commission.

But the important aspect of the situation is that the Commonwealth is compelling the States, under this system of matching grants, to divert money from primary, secondary, technical and teacher education to universities and the new forms of tertiary education. I am suggesting to the Committee that this is a very lopsided form of educational development in Australia. Let us look at some of the characteristics that cause worry and create crisis conditions in primary, secondary, technical and tertiary education. First, let us look at the position in respect of teachers. I asked the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt) a question on notice recently. I asked him how many graduate and non-graduate secondary science teachers were employed in each of the States and the Commonwealth Territories during the last 1 0 years. Despite the fact that the Commonwealth Government has tried to make the community believe it is giving high priority to science education in schools, the Prime Minister had to tei) me that this information was not available to him. In other words the Commonwealth is telling us that it does not know how many science teachers there are to teach in the science laboratories of secondary schools run by the Commonwealth, let alone those run by the States and subsidised by the Commonwealth.

As to teachers, the worrying fact is the inadequate number of fully qualified teachers available for secondary schooling in most of the States. More and more children are staying on to complete secondary schooling. In my State of New South Wales secondary schooling now continues for six years. This takes it to a level of education that has never been available before. At the same time we see a declining proportion of graduate teachers available to teach our children matriculation subjects. As a matter of fact, in my State I think only about 46 per cent, of teachers in secondary schools have graduate status and the proportion is declining year by year. When I look at figures provided to me by the Prime Minister on 18th August I find that in Queensland in 1955 the number of degrees held by full time secondary teachers was 373 while the number of full time teachers without degrees was 361. In other words, in 1955 in Queensland there were almost equal numbers of graduate and non-graduate teachers in secondary schools. But what was the position in 1964? The number of degrees held by full time teachers in secondary schools in Queensland was 608, but the number of full time teachers without degrees was 2.405. The position has so deteriorated that although in 1955 there were almost equal numbers of graduate and non-graduate teachers, in 1964 there were four times as many non-graduate teachers as there were graduate teachers. It is no wonder that parents have to resort to having their children coached in private coaching colleges in order to supplement the inadequate teaching they get in schools.

The disheartening feature is that this Government is not prepared to do anything about the situation. It established a committee, the Martin Committee, to inquire into various forms of tertiary education. One of its very strong recommendations was that the Government should support the States in setting up autonomous boards of teacher education, providing fully professional training for teachers of State and non-State schools. It proposed capital and recurrent grants to assist the States in setting up such teacher training facilities. It recommended the provision of 10 per cent, bondfree Commonwealth scholarships to enable people to go to them, get their teaching qualifications and then teach where they wanted to. This, of course, would have provided private schools with a source of trained teachers. Everybody knows today that in our private schools, particularly in the Catholic schools, the number of lay teachers being employed is increasing dramatically. In many Catholic private schools today more than half the staff are lay teachers. Unforunately, many of them, who are teaching young Australians, have had no teacher training whatever. This is the disheartening thing; the Commonwealth has not been prepared to implement the Martin Committee's recommendations.

I say here and now that an important pledge by the Labour Party at the next Federal election will be the implementation of the Martin Committee's recommendations - as it has been in the past - to provide Australian State and non-State schools with the professionally trained teachers that are denied at present. The fact is that more and more children are staying on at school. The figures indicate, for instance, in my own State of New South Wales, that in form four between 1964 and 1965 the percentage of students in government schools staying in that form rose from 34 per cent, to 42 per cent. In non-government schools the figure rose from 45 to 57 per cent. More children are staying on in school and there are more inducements for them to do so. The Commonwealth is inducing them to do so by providing new forms of tertiary education and assistance to universities. But how many of these children will be able to reach those levels of education if we are not able to provide the highly qualified teachers demanded, under the Wyndham scheme, in the latter years of secondary schooling in New South Wales? Much the same is required in every other State.

New demands are being made for more teachers. We have just received the report on the colleges of advanced education which indicated that between 1966 and 1969 university enrolments are expected to increase by 20 per cent., from 91,160 to 109,480, and that in the advanced colleges of education - which the Commonwealth says are a vital part of our tertiary programme from now on - there is going to be an 88 per cent, increase in enrolments, from 24,342 to 45,948. But where are the teachers to come from? The Commonwealth is making provision for the building of colleges and the payment of salaries; but there is no provision for the training of teachers for this greatly expanded programme of tertiary education.

Where are the teachers to come from? They will come from the same source from which the teachers colleges are recruiting their lecturers - from the secondary schools. Our secondary schools will become more poverty stricken educationally than they ever were. So, while building up this superstructure of tertiary education, we are undermining the base on which it is built - primary and secondary education. Under the Government's programme we have a lopsided development in our education structure. It is not only educationally stupid but it is economically unwise. In many cases money is being thrown down the drain and will be wasted. Inadequately trained students will come up from the secondary schools to enter these colleges and universities.

The position in private schools is even worse than in State schools. But there is not just a shortage of teachers, there is a shortage of classrooms. There was an announcement on 25th August in the " Sydney Morning Herald " under the heading "Crisis move on portable classrooms". This referred to New South Wales, of course. The article said -

quote.para: The State Government yesterday called tenders for 120 prefabricated classrooms to meet an acute accommodation shortage in N.S.W. secondary schools next year.
The Government plans to put the classrooms in 32 High Schools until permanent classrooms are erected.
In some cases the structures temporarily could form complete new schools.

speech.para: This is a shocking state of affairs. There has been no forward planning. There has been no body akin to the Australian Universities Commission available to guide the destinies of primary, technical and secondary education. This planning is badly needed in my own district where two of my children attend school. The James Cook Boys' High School and the Moorefields Girls' High School have shared in the past few years a lovely big assembly hall. Now we are told that it is to be divided next year into classrooms because these are so urgently needed. The same situation exists at Narrabeen. The assembly hall there is to be partitioned off and used for classrooms. This is happening in several schools over the State. There are many schools desperately in need of assembly halls, which are an integral part of a modern education, and the few high schools that have assembly halls look like losing them. I make a strong protest on behalf of the parents and citizens' organisations in my electorate, and on behalf of the teachers who have been ringing me in desperation to see if something can be done even at this late hour to forestall this loss of a very important segment of the education system.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr. Peters). - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

talk.start.para: .- It is not very often that I find myself in some agreement with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Whitlam) and the honorable member for Barton (Mr. Reynolds). I will at a later stage refer to some points of agreement and, of course, to some points of disagreement. I would like to correct a statement made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who tended to suggest that the only effort that this Government was making in relation to education was in connection with grants to the States for universities and to the Australian National University. Whilst the figures involved are very commendable and the efforts by the Government have been highly successful, it is estimated this financial year that, in round figures, S54 million will be expended in grants to States for universities and $19 million will be required for the Australian National University. These figures are contained in the supplement to the booklet, " The Commonwealth Government in Education ". The impression that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition wanted to convey to the Committee was that this was as far as the Government had gone. He had forgotten, of course, that the Government goes much further. It assists many Australian students. It provides capital grants for technical schools. It provides grants for science facilities, research projects, colleges of advanced education and education in the Commonwealth mainland Territories. It also gives international aid and there are quite a number of other incidental items. It is wrong to suggest that the only aid provided by the Government is for the universities because it is estimated that these other things will cost the Government this year $100 million in round figures. I just wanted to correct the impression that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition conveyed to the Committee.

speech.para: Education in Australia is of increasing importance not only to the individual but to the nation. The assistance provided by this Government in the field of education has been greater than any in our history. It has covered all sections of education, as I illustrated by referring to the document I just mentioned. But, particularly, the Government has been of great assistance at the secondary and tertiary levels. The Government's assistance to universities by way of grants, the provision of equipment, the building of new universities, and modernisation and additions to existing universities, is providing a more solid foundation from which Australia can advance, as advance it must, in the scientific, technological and executive fields. The executive field is often forgotten.

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable member happy about primary and secondary education?

- I will come to those matters later. Let me finish. The honorable member for Hughes will have his say. This aid will, of necessity, continue to increase, as will the number of scholarships which the Government has made available. In recent years the Government rightly has set a new pattern and provided enormous new opportunities in education. The Government has realised that if we are to take our place in world affairs it is essential that we develop as speedily as possible our potential in scientific and technical fields, and that if we are to increase our productivity and world trade, and if we are to expand internally our resources as rapidly as we would desire, it is incumbent upon us to ensure that we have trained scientists and technicians in all spheres of our national activities. However, it is not sufficient to provide the scientist and technologist, for on their own they can achieve little. Behind each of these must be highly skilled technicians and tradesmen. The Commonwealth Government, realising this and the advantages that must flow from this, has adopted the recent Commonwealth Advisory Committee's report on education. The acceptance of the most important recommendations in this report will mean that an additional 97 million will be spent in this sphere over the next three years.

speech.para: Until this Government took office, education was regarded as a province. of the States. The States, in turn, guarded their sovereign rights zealously. I want to say in relation to the inquiry which is suggested in the amendment that before the Commonwealth can go far in conducting its own inquiry into education throughout the whole of Australia it will have to cooperate with the States. That co-operation may not be quite as readily forthcoming as may be expected. After all, the States have a constitutional right for education and they guard their independence and their sovereign rights, as they should. Quite frankly, if this inquiry is a veiled attempt to get uniformity of education in this country I am dead against it. Every State should be able to decide and carry out its own curriculum in the manner in which it wishes. We do not want all the people in this country, no matter from which State they come, to have the same curriculum and be turned out like sausages to attend the various universities. We must have independence of thought and one way in which this can be achieved is by the independence of the States to have their own curriculum.

However, today it is apparent that the resources of the States cannot provide adequately for the growing needs of an increasing population of young people thirsting to expand their knowledge. The Commonwealth, having entered into the field of education in conjunction with the States, will undoubtedly be called upon to make greater contributions in this important field. In fact, the people of Australia have come to look to the Commonwealth Government to regard education more on a national level than hitherto. All children in this country should have an equal opportunity to use their ability and initiative, and they should be encouraged to continue in the secondary and tertiary levels of education. But in many cases, through the inadequacy of a basic foundation at primary level, much of our manpower potential is lost. In New South Wales there is an acute shortage of teachers, classrooms are overcrowded, buildings are inadequate, and the equipment necessary, particularly in technical schools, is outmoded or just not available. These conditions are not calculated to encourage our children to continue their education, nor do they encourage their parents to allow them to continue. Many trainee teachers are rushed through teachers training colleges and left to fend for themselves after an inadequate training period of two years, instead of the desired three years. They are sent to schools without the necessary specialised knowledge or a desire to improve their understanding of subjects which require additional study and post-graduate attendance at training colleges. As a consequence, they are not as highly qualified as is necessary to enable them to undertake the responsibility of providing thorough and proper instruction to the thousands of children who deserve the highest standards in an efficient and effective teaching staff to instruct them.

In New South Wales the shortsightedness of the previous Government, which was in office for some 24 years, has left the present Government an unwanted legacy. For four years the Wyndham scheme was left in the pending tray and was then introduced, without prior planning, to an education department which had insufficient facilities to cope with the expanded curriculum. This was at a point in time when, due to the postwar birthrate boom, there was a huge increase in the number of pupils at secondary schools. The scheme itself called for smaller classes and a greater diversification of subjects at different levels of study, thus requiring larger schools and a greater number of teachers. These were just not available. To its credit, the Liberal Government in New South Wales will be expending record sums of money on education this year in an endeavour to overcome the backlog. Unfortunately, it will take a considerable time before this can be achieved.
