Federal aid has assisted the State school system tremendously and also has helped the private schools, but I submit that this Government should go a step further. It is more than commendable to supply the necessary finance to build and equip schools and provide modern teaching aids, but all this is of little use if qualified teachers are not available to instruct children how to use the new facilities and how to absorb changing methods that are provided. This can result in a further waste of manpower potential which we cannot afford and, as the resources of the State Governments are clearly inadequate to cope with this problem immediately, I believe it is vital that the Commonwealth immediately lay the foundations for a sounder basis of education by assisting the States in their teacher training problems.

Concern is continually being expressed about the failure rate at all levels. I feel sure that this is due, in a great measure, to a shortage of highly trained teaching staff, which in turn does not allow a so.'id foundation on which to build. The Martin Committee recommended that the Government make a capital grant for teaching training and at least this recommendation should be adopted and applied as speedily as possible. However, I believe that the grants to the States for this purpose should be unmatched; that the Commonwealth should shoulder the responsibility for building the colleges after consultation with the States; that these teacher training colleges should be made available to train unbonded teachers who are willing to teach in the private school system; and that this tuition should be provided free. It is not only the State system which has an acute shortage of teachers-, because of pay and conditions the private schools are unable to attract the quality and the quantity of teachers which they too would like.

One can imagine that if the present state of affairs is allowed to progress, the additional strain placed upon the State and private school systems would be untenable. To guide Australia's development and guarantee its continued growth, we must ensure that the reservoir of young people who are willing to become the teachers of our youth are qualified to undertake this responsibility and have the amenities and equipment to fit them for this purpose. If this goal is to be achieved, more teacher training colleges are essential. By giving direct financial aid as I have suggested, the Government will be breaking into a new field of education, but from a national viewpoint we cannot stand by and allow this important problem of teacher shortages to continue. Whilst I have stressed the need for increased grants, I feel that I should impress on the Government that in the calculation of these grants, in all spheres, but particularly in the sphere of training colleges, consideration should be given to the particular needs of each State and grants should not be made simply because a certain State has a larger population.

If we are to bp nationally minded, grants must be based on the individual needs of the States. Further, I believe that both private and State schools are unable to meet the demand for the building of science blocks and technical school buildings and the supply of equipment. This scheme, as honorable members will recall, was initiated by this Government just a few years ago. What has been done has been commendable but it is clearly not enough, for at the present rate it will be some years before adequate facilities are available. If we are to harness the undoubted ability of our youth, we should increase our aid in this direction to a more practical level and so provide urgently needed graduates at the tertiary level. We should assist wherever possible in the provision of new buildings and new laboratories. This is a national problem and should be treated on a national level. I suggest to the Government that it consider increasing substantially the amounts that are now available for these purposes.

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable member voting for the amendment?

speech.para: Mr. BRYANT (Wills) 1.4.36]. - I think the honorable member for Bass (Mr. Barnard) has made a pertinent interjection. One would expect the honorable member for Phillip (Mr. Aston) to come over to this side of the chamber and to vote for the proposed amendment. But I suppose that is a little too much to ask. However, 1 do congratulate the honorable member. lt was refreshing to hear him speak for a quarter of an hour without once mentioning Communists. 1 want to correct him on one or two points. I understand the States have asked for an inquiry. The State Ministers in council have been co-operating with one another for a long time in an attempt to get the picture of Australian education clear. I am sure they would all be happy to participate and co-operate in any action which the Commonwealth wished to take in developing Australian education. Qf course, the problem we face is not new to our Federal system. What is needed is encouragement and co-operation, without indulging in too much coercion. One of the unhappy features of the present educational activities of the Commonwealth is what we might call the coercion of the States by a system of matching grants. Both the honorable member for Phillip and the honorable member for Barton (Mr. Reynolds) made a very good point when they showed that this method imposes a heavy burden upon the States.

It is becoming quite a thing for honorable members opposite to congratulate the Government upon its approach to education and to try to create an atmosphere of complacency, almost approaching smugness. But what are the facts? First, I understand that almost every university in Australia has had a cut back in what it regards as its necessary requirements. This has resulted from the report of the Universities Commission and the action on that report by the Commonwealth. This is a vital question. The requirements of the universities are submitted in the main by people who are skilled in their task and who know what they want - people who have an objective before them. It is a national misfortune that these requirements should be trimmed because of some Treasury or other requirement. 1 should think that at present our educational system is like Topsy - it is just growing. There is no overall plan for it. Nobody in the Government seems to be interested, and very little action can be taken in this Parliament unless there is some ministerial initiative. There is very little effort on the part of the Government to keep a proper eye on education or to give a national direction to it. I believe that until we have a full time Minister for Education in this Parliament we shall not get very far. I say this with all due respect to the present Minister in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research (Senator Gorton). He has another full time portfolio. Whilst I. might disagree with the way in which Ministers carry out most of their work, I will admit that they are faced with heavy tasks and that it is beyond the capacity of one person to handle two portfolios properly.

The honorable member for Phillip would seek to give the impression that the Commonwealth Government has done lots of things for all forms of education. This, of course, is quite untrue. So far as one can determine, nothing has been done in the broad sense for primary education. It may be possible to get children into schools; it may be possible to provide blackboards and chalk, and to put a teacher in front of every class; but there is no doubt in my mind that our primary schools are unworthy of this wealthy nation. There are large areas of neglect over the whole field of education in this country. In the matter of education,

I submit it is fair to say that the Liberal Party is a party of the blind. The Minister in Charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research is continually asserting that there is no crisis in education. I do not suppose what is happening is a crisis if it has been happening all the time. If we turn back the pages of history, we find that our parents and our grandparents before them all suffered from the deficiencies of the educational system of Australia. If a crisis is something which happens suddenly and then passes away, there is no crisis now. But things have been bad over large areas of the Australian educational system ever since efforts were made to establish universal education. To a great extent, the blame cannot be sheeted home to anybody in particular, because in the past we have not been a great and prosperous nation. Now we are. We are one of the richest and most secure nations of the world, and there is no reason why we should not have the best education system in the world. It is unhappily true that honorable members opposite spend a good deal of their time in comparing Australia with somewhere else, not only in relation to education but in relation to many other areas of public activity. We should be out in front because we have so many advantages.

I think it is fair to examine the education system in New South Wales. Until the return of the Liberal-Country Party Government about 1 8 months ago. New South Wales was undoubtedly out in front in many areas of education. It was matched in some areas by Tasmania, but, with its greater population and greater wealth, there is no doubt in my mind that it was far in front in universities and so on. I think the figures substantiate this. As New South Wales is a large State with a large population, it is fair to examine the education system there. Until recently, many of the secondary school buildings in New South Wales were almost up to the standard of such buildings in Canberra, but there has been a dramatic collapse in the last 12 months. I hope the people of New South Wales will remember this and that they will take appropriate action when they next go to the ballot box.

It has been asserted that education is the province of the States. It is a long while since anybody thought that education was exclusively the responsibility of the States. In 1945, this Parliament passed the Education Act, which set out a charter for the Commonwealth Office of Education. This organisation was subsequently established. The Australian National University was established by a Labour Government. The Commonwealth Reconstruction Training Scheme of the post-war period was followed by the Commonwealth scholarship scheme and other Commonwealth activities. So that many of the areas into which this Government has drifted are not necessarily new ones. Of course, increasing pressures have forced the Government to do much more than it intended to do originally. I entered the Parliament some 10 or 11 years ago. I can recall the first time when 1 heard the estimates for the Prime Minister's Department being discussed. I can recall the former Prime Minister's rather friendly, tolerant but slightly condescending approach to people like myself on this side of the House who raised the matter of education during the discussion of those estimates.

We find now that, as a result of continual pressure from the Labour Party and the public generally, the Commonwealth has drifted into the field of education. My complaint is that the Commonwealth is just drifting in this field instead of facing up to the problem and saying what it will do. There may well be differences between the approach of the Liberal Party and that of the Labour Party, but if the Government would step into the field with its Liberal philosophy, for what that is worth, and decide what it wants to do over the whole wide field of education, that would be of advantage to Australia.

Before moving to the amendment proposed by the Opposition, I should like to refer to the question of libraries. Some research has been done on libraries recently, and some reports have been submitted. I understand that it was estimated in a recent report that about 50c per head of population needs to be spent on library services immediately. The municipalities accept a large amount of responsibility for library services but the greater burden rests, of course, eventually with the State Governments. It is obviously impossible for those sections of government to do any more. The Commonwealth could easily find the S5 million or thereabouts which is necessary to give public library services in Australia a reasonable kick along. I think it is very important that this be done. Public library services are very important factors in the cultural and intellectual development of the nation. I hope that we shall have a chance to discuss libraries more fully in this Parliament at a later date.

Let me revert to the questions before the Committee at the moment - the estimates for this Department and the Labour Party's proposed amendment. We want an inquiry. Nearly everybody concerned with education asks for an inquiry. The State Ministers and various other authorities have asked for it. We have already established bodies such as the Universities Commission which could conduct inquiries. The honorable member for Phillip thought that this might lead to regimentation. I submit that nothing could be further from the truth. Much would depend, of course, upon the approach of the people who conducted the inquiry. We want co-ordination. We want something established in the field of research. We want greater knowledge. As the honorable member for Barton pointed out, there are areas of ignorance that are astonishing in the extreme. We have only to turn to the answers to questions which he has asked for proof of that. We on this side would like to see established as soon as possible a Commonwealth Department of Education, with its own ministerial head. There are areas of activity in education which can only be initiated by the Commonwealth. Effective educational research is one. The initiation of experiment in Australia is another. It is time that some government authorities, having behind them all the resources of the kind that are being used to establish various enterprises in Canberra in numerous fields, took some action in educational research, not only on the theoretical but also on the practical side. These questions must be looked into, for instance: What can we teach in a school? What can we do with this set of children? And so on. It is only the Commonwealth that is likely to be able to do this.

There are large areas of education that need co-ordination. The level of examination for entrance to universities is one. It may well be that there ought to be a national matriculation standard. Then again, we ought to aim at a status of education at which the universities will admit without further training anybody who has graduated from the schools. I believe that this sort of thing ought to be easily achieved in Canberra. The half dozen or so secondary schools in the National Capital ought to be of such a status as would allow the Australian National University to admit students on the results of internal examinations conducted by the schools themselves. Because Canberra is such a small unit, it would be possible to carry out here experiments of this nature. The Commonwealth, of course, can expand its ancillary services.

There is the question of television. We have recently received a report on educational television. The largest number of pigeonholes ever accumulated in administrative history must exist somewhere in Canberra to store all the reports that this Government has rejected after having called for them in the first place. I regard television as providing one of the greatest educational opportunities presently offering. The expansion of educational television services would do great things for Australian education. Only the Commonwealth can do what is required in this field. But again, as in so many areas, it pushes the issue aside. As has been mentioned by speakers on both sides of the chamber, teacher education is of fundamental importance. Until we have tackled the question of teacher education, until we have lifted it from the realm of the State administrative system and given responsibility for it to an autonomous body, in the manner suggested in the report of the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia, we shall not make satisfactory progress. I believe that honorable members on both sides of the Parliament would sponsor more or less the same policy - a policy of training teachers at government expense, no matter where they are to teach, in much the same way as doctors, lawyers and all the rest of the professional people who obtain their education with the aid of Commonwealth scholarships are trained.

Australian education needs a thorough going over. It has a number of disturbing features. It is still very conservative. I suppose that all education is conservative. This is because of the way in which, from generation to generation, we hand down the culture and mores of society. Our system of education, however, is worse than conservative. It is habitual. Let us consider the teaching of foreign languages, for example. We teach French. Why? It is principally because only 21 miles away, across the English Channel, lies the foreign country that happens to be closest to where our grandparents came from, and the language of that country happens to be French. I believe that we should continue to teach French. But it should not be the dominating foreign language taught in the Australian educational system as it continues to be. We live in Asia, and we are interested in the comments of people like the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt), who talks in theory about Asia. If we want some practical application of our association with Asia, let us try to expand the teaching of, say, Indonesian in Australian schools. This would not be easy. I believe that it could be initiated effectively only by the Commonwealth. I have mentioned languages, particularly French. But there are other areas to which we could turn our attention. Woodwork, for instance, is still the main manual craft taught in our schools, though we live in a mechanical and electronic society.

Our education system is still university dominated and examination ridden. Large areas of educational administration are still centralised and there are inequalities between States, between the sexes; between social classes and in relation to vital areas like education of the Aborigines, though only small numbers of these are involved, between races. One of the most tragic areas of wastage in Australian education is in the education of women at the higher level. The figures show that only 17.57 per cent, of males leaving school got through to the universities in 1965 and only 7.94 per cent, of females. This means that there is a tragic wastage of female talent. I think that last year there were something like 56,000 young men in Australian universities and only about 20,000 young women. What happened to the other 36,000. young women who should have been at the universities? They were Australians of equal talent, equal social status, equal capacity and equal merit. They were in every way fundamentally equal to the young men except that they were of a different sex. The fact is that last year 36,000 young women who passed through the secondary schools did not reach the universities. This is not only a political question. It is a social question the determination of which rests not just with this Parliament but more directly with the people of Australia. Here is a great body of human talent that goes to waste and remains untrained.

These matters that I have mentioned are some of the problems that pose challenges beyond the scope and capacity of the State governments. They are beyond solution by State Parliaments and Ministries. Only effective national action taken at the Commonwealth level will enable Australian education to achieve the standards to which this nation, I believe, is entitled.

talk.start.para: . - Mr. Deputy Chairman, 1 wish to deal solely with one item in the estimates now before the Committee - the grant for the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I would like on behalf of the Institute to express to the Government appreciation for what it is doing. I also express my own appreciation to honorable members for allowing me to be one of their representatives on the Council of the Institute. The other is the honorable member for Fremantle (Mr. Beazley). Honorable members will have received and will have noted the contents of the annual report of the Institute. The latest report can bc read with a considerable measure of satisfaction.

speech.para: Two aspects of problems relating to the Aborigines are before us. as Australians. One is the problem of welfare and the advancement of the Aboriginal people, involving the raising of their standards and matters of that description. The other is the question of scholarship and academic research. The Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, which was established under an act of this Parliament, is concerned only with the question of scholarship. Policy questions are, by design, excluded from its consideration. I do not, of course, minimise the importance of these policy considerations. As honorable members will know, I personally take an active interest in all problems of Aboriginal welfare. I hope at some other time during the consideration of these estimates to have an opportunity to discuss other aspects of these problems. But this is not the time to speak of them, for the Institute of Aboriginal Studies is not concerned with the relevant kinds of activity.

Nevertheless, I believe that the Institute's programme will help in the solution of the problems of Aboriginal welfare. The Institute's investigations will uncover some of the impediments to advancement. These impediments are very largely of a psychological nature. Anything that gives us a better understanding of the difficulties involved will enable us to cope with them more adequately. In saying this, Sir, I do not imply that Australia should indulge in too much self commination. This problem of the raising of the standards of primitive people has bedevilled policy not only in Australia but also in other countries. Our approach to these problems is in some ways related to the study begun in the United States of America nearly 100 years ago by the ethnographic studies instituted under government auspices. If by this approach we can throw a little more light on some of these problems in Australia, we shall concurrently throw a little more light also on problems overseas. Therefore, though what the Institute is doing is not directly related to welfare, it may help indirectly.

Having said that, may I turn to a review of the Institute's proper activities in the world of scholarship. I believe that what we are doing is of importance. Indeed, I am sure that if honorable members examine the latest annual report, they will agree that the Institute's work is of world importance. There are few things in the academic field in Australia which are of world importance. Perhaps one would say, for example, that Sir Macfarlane Burnet's study of viruses, Sir John Eccles' study of neurology and some of our studies in radio astronomy are of world importance. But, in terms of scholarship, there is not much in Australia that is of world importance except this study of the Aboriginal people. This is perhaps the only place in the world where a study of the economy and sociology of a pre-agricultural people, uncontaminated by contact with agricultural societies, may be carried out. There is probably nowhere else left in the world where this can be done. These are vanishing and evaporating opportunities. Australia has for the whole world a special responsibility with regard to them and one which, I am glad to say, this Government is facing up to. I think honorable members will concede that the Government deserves great credit for what it has done in this regard.

Let me mention one or two matters which may be of interest to honorable members as they are typical of the kind of programme we are carrying out. I say first that we ourselves do not so much carry out programmes on our own initiative as encourage and help those in universities and elsewhere who are engaged in this field of Aboriginal studies. Our method, which is enjoined on us by the Act of Parliament, is to co-operate in this matter. We ourselves have some workers full time in the field. We have our library, our sound and film archives and our central intelligence agency but we are endeavouring to co-operate with universities and other learned bodies and individuals in this sphere and to augment their work.

I shall give an instance of what I mean. I refer to the excavations at Koonalda near Eucla on the border of South Australia and Western Australia. Here is a site which was discovered and the importance of which was seen, not by the Institute, but by a Dr, Gallus of Melbourne, a man to whose initiative and persistence a great tribute is due. The Institute has been able to give to Dr. Gallus funds to enable him to carry out his researches. This has enabled specimens to be carbon dated which would tell us their exact age. Recently, because of the importance of this site which Dr. Gallus first investigated, we have decided to set up a committee to co-operate in the investigation of what is probably the most important archaeological site which has yet come under investigation in Australia. Dr. Gallus will be on that committee.

Here, in a dark cave 250 feet underground, we are finding Aboriginal artifacts which can be dated some 20,000 years back. The information gained will answer a great deal of the previous speculation about the origin of man in Australia and the length of time he has been here. We are not by any means to the bottom of the deposit. It may be that in the excavations we are sponsoring and which will be carried out in the very near future we shall find even older deposits. I would say that this is the most important archaeological site currently under investigation or perhaps ever discovered in Australia. It is one the full potentialities of which are unknown. It will to some extent reverse ideas about the provenance of man in this part of the world.

Let me take a subject that is quite different - the subject of Aboriginal music This may seem a far cry - a little far fetched - but what I am going to say is what has been told to me by Professor Jones, Professor of Music at Monash University, Melbourne. Professor Jones is perhaps the man most competent to give an opinion in this regard. We are sponsoring some investigations by Dr. Catherine Ellis. Professor Jones thinks that she has a better than even money chance of establishing a new theory of musical intervals which will be applicable to the origins of ail human music. Professor Jones says that if Dr. Ellis does this - he thinks she may well succeed - she will do for musical theory what Einstein did for the theory of physics; she will, overturn a great number of accepted ideas throughout the world. Already she has tried to correlate some of her Australian investigations with African observations. This is something which the Institute is sponsoring. If it comes off it will be of world importance.

Let me take the field of linguistics. Here Dr. Capell of the University of Sydney has produced, for the first time in Australia 1 think, a satisfactory handbook summarising what we know of the 700 different Australian languages. Of that number 1 think we can still retrieve about 400. It may be that 300 which are known through descriptions and rudimentary vocabularies collected in the last century have vanished. But it is very important for us to do this work because it will throw light on the origin of human language - not just Australian language, but human language. Unless we record these languages now they will be lost forever. It may well be that as a result of our setting out these things and our investigations, new theories on the origin of human language applicable all over the world will be formulated and accepted.

Let me take the matter of sociology, itself. Honorable members may be familiar with the work of Professor Berndt, a Western Australian member of our Council who has carried out investigations in Arnhem Land. His book, " Djunngawahl ", on Arnhem Land will give to those who read it a completely new perspective of what primitive ceremony is about. It will enable us to understand things that have never been understood in regard to such matters as the Eleusinian Mysteries. This is of world wide importance. The book was published before the Institute came into existence, but the Institute is now filming related ceremonies of North East Arnhem Land. We have an organisation in the Northern Territory engaged in this filming work.

I would like to have said more on this subject had time permitted. I commend to honorable members the report which is in their hands. It deals in greater detail with some of the things I have referred to and discusses also a number of things I have had to omit due to lack of time. I think that the Government is to be commended for the support it has given to the Institute. 1 hope that honorable members will agree with me that the report in their hands reflects credit on the work which it has done to date.

talk.start.para: .- -I rise to support the amendment that the proposed expenditure for the Prime Minister's Department be reduced by SIO as an instruction to the Government to conduct an inquiry into all aspects of education, primary, secondary and technical, and to accept the Martin Committee's recommendations on teacher training. The motion is identical with resolutions that have been moved here regularly by the Opposition since 1960. The Government has always resisted them. In other years, every honorable member on the Government side has consistently voted against the Opposition's amendment. A succession of excuses has been offered by the Government for its rejection of the amendment, in which the Opposition has proposed that a competent committee of inquiry be established by the Government to investigate all aspects of primary, secondary and technical educations. In the opinion of Opposition members, none of the Government's reasons has been valid. The reasons have not been accepted by the Australian Labour Party and indeed have not been acceptable to the representatives of the various teachers' organisations and parents and citizens organisations, who have continued to press the Government for the establishment of a committee similar to that consistently sought by the Opposition.

speech.para: In addition to the requests of educationalists, there have also been requests from the State Ministers for Education. Only a few years ago, the absence of such a request was one of the reasons given by the former Prime Minister for the rejection of the proposal that a committee of inquiry be established. The Prime Minister said that, unlike the Martin Committee, the request had never been made by the State Ministers. This excuse is no longer valid. Since 1963, the State Ministers have most certainly requested the Commonwealth to establish a committee of inquiry. Indeed, all the State Premiers have made the request to the Government and they have been supported by the Australian Education Council, which consists of the State Ministers and the State Directors of Education. As far back as 1960, the Council submitted a report. It revised the report in 1963. In both reports, it outlined the great need not only for a review of the education system but for a review of the amount of money that would be required in the immediate future to overcome the difficulties of the various State education authorities.

The Commonwealth has already conducted inquiries into university and other forms of education. As I have already said, the former Prime Minister accepted the proposal for the establishment of a committee to examine tertiary education, and much good has flowed from the recommendations of that committee. The reports of the Murray, Martin and Currie Committees have been before the Parliament. They have provided invaluable information to honorable members and also to various State education authorities. Although the Murray and Martin Committees were not empowered to deal with the broader aspects of education, they certainly intimated to the Government that it would not be possible to correct the difficulties at the tertiary level and some of the anomalies that existed when these Committees were making their investigations without giving some consideration to the basic weaknesses at the primary, secondary and technical levels. But the Government has consistently ignored this advice.

We believe that today a national assessment is needed. It should now include the needs of the non-State schools. All States today are providing sums of money from State budgets to assist the non-State education system. But despite this involvement very little information is available to the Commonwealth and the State education authorities about the difficulties in this field of education. An inquiry would show that a wide gap exists between the requirements of education at the primary, secondary and technical levels and the availability of finance from State sources. What are some of the difficulties? I think every honorable member realises that the schools are short of qualified teachers. Many teachers are inadequately trained or qualified to teach at the levels at which they are being used. The States are finding it difficult to provide the accommodation needed to meet greatly increased enrolments. There is a large and growing accumulation of makeshift, substandard and obsolete school accommodation. It is totally unsuitable and undesirable for the purposes for which it is being used. All honorable members have seen the conditions that now exist in schools in the various States. Indeed, the honorable member for Phillip (Mr. Aston) this afternoon referred to the need for additional finance to be made available by the Commonwealth to the States. This was one of the very few speeches I have heard in recent years from honorable members opposite in which recognition has been shown of the greater need now than ever before for a more active participation by the Commonwealth in education generally.

The honorable member for Barton (Mr. Reynolds) referred earlier to the lack of essential equipment in schools. This equipment is in short supply in most of the States. The schools lack libraries and gymnasiums, and these are required in increasing numbers. The Government has 'shown over a number of years in the Australian Capital Territory that it accepts the principle that secondary schools need adequate gymnasiums and other facilities. These are essential under the present school curriculum. For instance, students need a place in which to meet when they are not engaged in the study of school subjects. But provision is very rarely made for this in our schools. The States must provide additional accommodation in schools and it is no longer possible for them to provide for extracurricular activities. They must meet the urgent requirement to replace obsolete and sub-standard buildings and equipment in the schools.

I think that the Government is aware of these difficulties, but it chooses to ignore them. It knows that the States are now spending more on education than ever before. Education is probably the largest item of expenditure in all State budgets. It has increased substantially in recent years. Parents have been pressing for more effective schooling over a longer period. I think it is a disgraceful state of affairs that one must acknowledge in this Parliament in 1966 that some States still maintain a school leaving age of 14 years. The leaving age was raised to 16 years in Tasmania some years ago, and it was altered to 15 years in New South Wales. All States have passed legislation to increase the school leaving age from 14 to 15 years but none of the State instrumentalities has been able to implement the legislation because of the shortage of finance. They know that immediately they implement the legislation they will be confronted with difficulties additional to those now being experienced with accommodation and essential equipment. So we have the situation in the Commonwealth where one State has a school leaving age of 16 years, another a school leaving age of 15 years and the remaining States are still struggling, as they have done for the last 20 to 30 years, with a school leaving age of 14 years. The States have attempted to cope with the demand for increased enrolment at a time when enrolments have been increasing rapidly. Not only are initial enrolments increasing, but some students are remaining for the senior years in technical and secondary schools. Between 1958 and 1963 the number of full time students in the 15 year age group increased from 53 per cent, to 65 per cent, of the Australian population; the number in the 16 year age group increased from 26 per cent, to 37 per cent.; in the 17 year age group from 16 per cent, to 23 per cent.; and in the 18 year age group from 9 per cent, to 12 per cent.

In a publication prepared by the Australian Educational Council and relating to the needs of Australian education it is pointed out that to meet the needs for general edu cational purposes by the end of the next four years $516 million will have to be expended and that the States in that period will be able to provide S320 million, leaving a deficit of $196 million. Yet the Government continually rejects the proposition submitted to it that there is a need for a more active financial participation by the Commonwealth Government in education generally, particularly in respect of the need for a committee of inquiry. One of the principal reasons why the Commonwealth has rejected the proposal to establish a committee of inquiry has been its desire not to become involved in the question of state aid, but I point out that the situation changed in 1963. It has been suggested, probably unkindly and unfairly, that in 1963 the Government entered the state aid field for political purposes. It provided state aid in the form of science laboratories and equipment and it has continued to provide finance every year since for the same purpose.

The reimbursements of interest on capital borrowed for the erection and extension of non-state schools, in the Australian Capital Territory for example, has risen in recent years- from $3,000 in 1958 to $180,000 in 1964. This has been a substantial increase, yet the Government has resisted becoming involved in any way in any investigation into the needs of non-state schools. A similar situation applies in the States, although I believe that Tasmania does not provide this kind of assistance - repayable interest on money borrowed for the erection and extension of school buildings. The Commonwealth should not be deterred by this kind of argument. Again, there is the question referred to earlier by the honorable member for Barton (Mr. Reynolds) about teacher training. The Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia made sensible recommendations concerning the need for teacher training in Australia. Its recommendations have been supported by the Australian Teachers Federation. It has been pointed out that as far back as 1963 State schools alone needed an additional 6,000 teachers.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Hon. W. C. Haworth). - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

talk.start.para: .- In the first instance, I also should like to refer generally to the matters contained in the Bill that deal with educational activities. I congratulate the Minister in charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research (Senator Gorton) on the manner in which the Commonwealth is proceeding in the educational field and, in particular, on the recent spectacular announcement that $610 million is to be spent by all governments on tertiary education in the period 1967 to 1969. This admirably reflects the increasing role that the Commonwealth is playing in this field, for nearly half of the money for universities and colleges of advanced education will come directly from this Government. Regarding the colleges of advanced education I refer to the first report of the Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Advanced Education, and in particular to chapter 8 which is headed " Liberal Studies in Colleges of Advanced Education ". In paragraph 4 of that chapter the following appears -

quote.para: The problem of liberalisation is perhaps more intense in .Britain, whose educational system we have broadly followed, and in Australia than in most other countries. For the secondary school student has usually for a period of two years taken a specialised course before he reaches university or advanced college. This disability is now being recognised among Australian educationalists.

speech.para: That paragraph, as can be seen, deals with what is generally known as specialisation or overspecialisation in education. I believe that overspecialisation is a vice in Australian education which has worked its way back down the pipeline from the universities, where for the best pupils it can do little harm, to the secondary schools, where for all but the best students it can be disastrous. This is not simply a dry, technical question of unbalanced curricula and paper requirements for university entrance; rather it is a matter of the colour and texture of our national life.

The separation of science from literature is a serious danger, but it is only one danger among many that come from overspecialisation. The price that we pay for young historians who will give up all but a nominal smattering of science at the age of 15, or engineers without a word of any tongue but their own, is paid not only in a cultural schism, but is paid in national inefficiency. The manager who is slow to grasp technological innovations, the salesman who fails to understand foreign markets, the narrow-minded governmental official - all these and many more - are the products and the victims of overspecialisation and what can be termed undereducation. Since we have to make our own way in the world with few resources but our wits we cannot affort to be undereducated. If honorable members do not believe that we are overspecialised or undereducated as a nation I suggest that they ask one of their well informed friends to tell them exactly how steel is made, or the current state of the theory of evolution, or how foreign trade is financed. Only if they have a steel man or a biologist or a banker among their friends will they get an answer because if it is not our subject we just do not know.

Continuing my discussion on matters pertaining to the Advisory Committee on Advanced Education, I should like to add a couple of points regarding the grants which are made by the Commonwealth. Before doing so perhaps I should say, by way of explanation, that in 1965 the Commonwealth set up the Committee to which requests by the States for financial assistance are referred. The Committee, which gives expert advice on the distribution of the money available, is charged with advising on the proposals from the States from the interim capital grants recommended by the Tertiary Education Inquiry Committee. It may be recalled that for the 1967-69 triennium the Commonwealth Government announced that it would provide up to $8 million a year for capital expenditure on these colleges and up to S8 million a year for recurrent expenditure. These grants are conditional on the States providing finance on a $1 for $1 basis for capital expenditure and a SI Commonwealth to $1.85 State basis in respect of recurrent expenditure. Commonwealth financial assistance for recurrent purposes is directed to the increases beyond the level applying in 1964-65.

I have stated that I want to mention two points regarding this matter. The first relates to recurrent purposes. I believe the choice of the base year 1964-65 reacts unfairly against the State of Victoria because in that year Victoria's development in this direction was much greater than development in other States. I think this was generally acknowledged in the Martin report. A vague recollection tells me that Victoria was spending approximately 13 times what was being spent in New South Wales and almost 54 times what was being spent in other States. Secondly, again on the recurrent side, the system of the Commonwealth contributing SI for every 1.85 contributed by the States appears unrealistic and unfair to Victoria. The basis is analogous to that used in the university system wherein the amounts paid by way of university fees are relevant and taken into account. However, in technical education there are little or no fees. Consequently, the systems are simply not analogous and the present system reacts unfairly on Victoria. These are small but significant points. They in no way detract from the excellent assistance the Commonwealth is now providing.

A further reference I wish to make in the short time available to me is to the Advisory Committee's report. The latter portion of conclusion No. 1 1 in chapter 8 of the report under the heading " Conclusions " is in these terms -

quote.para: We look to the colleges to produce diplomates who will not only serve the community through their professional knowledge and capacity but who will exercise their talents over a wide range of activities including community service.

speech.para: I stress the words " including community service ". A great deal is said today about the role of young people in the community and the duties of Federal and State Governments towards them. I have always believed that young people in turn have a duty not merely to the respective Governments but in particular to the societies in which they live - societies, particularly in Australia, which are providing them with great rights and opportunities. If we accept the philosophical approach to government which is based on a rights/ duties concept - that everyone has certain rights within the society but everyone also must execute corresponding duties - I should imagine there is no other group in the community which has a greater obligation to society than the young people of today. They are receiving far greater rights and opportunities than perhaps any other appropriate or analogous age group has had in the history of Australia. This does not mean that the Government can say: " It is up to the youth of Australia to participate in community affairs". Nevertheless, we should give the incentive because there is little point in training boys and girls to earn a good livelihood if we do not assist them to be good and useful citizens and to live good and useful lives as well. At present, as the Appropriation Bill reveals, the Commonwealth Government makes grants to the scouts and guides organisations. It also makes a grant of $9,000 to a body known as the National Youth Council of Australia. 1 should like to say a word or two about the National Youth Council of Australia. It was formed in 1960 as a representative body of Australian youth organisations to provide a common meeting ground for these groups. A major role of the Council is to make representations at the national level to government and other bodies on matters of concern to young people. The Council also carries out a wide variety of other work. It assists in the development of youth activities and the extension of work with young people; it provides a medium of exchange for ideas and experience in youth work; it arranges for the representation of Australian youth at overseas and international youth gatherings; and it stimulates creative thinking by young people. The National Youth Council also encourages active co-operation between youth organisations. Matters of common concern which they discuss include, I understand, the increase in Australia's teenage population and the problems associated with this rise, and the necessity for an interchange of ideas between Australia and the youth of other nations, particularly nations in the Asian area. It is, therefore, a body highly deserving of support from the Commonwealth Government for it represents and encourages active co-operation between a wide variety of youth organisations comprising people from all walks of life.

The Council, together with another organisation with which J am personally connected - the Young Australian Foundation - has, I believe, proved itself in this sphere of youth activities and youth work. Although the Young Australian Foundation does not receive a direct grant from the Government, I feel its role in the community is not one which rivals the National Youth Council of Australia. Indeed, they appear to be working hand in hand. It is providing for young people to participate in community affairs. I would direct the attention of the Government to the role of these organisations, particularly the role of the National Youth Council of Australia, and hope that at Budget time next year when it is considering the amount that it will make available to the National Youth Council, it will consider increasing the present allocation.

Before concluding I should like to get off my chest one brief matter relating to education in Australia. We hear today incessant cries for greater opportunities for people to go to the university and acquire a university education. This is good and indeed necessary if Australia is to play her role in the future particularly in South and South East Asia. However, an important factor to realise in this intellectually minded age is that schools and universities do not hold a monopoly of education. A thorough trade training can do as much to bring out the best in one kind of boy as a thorough academic training can for another, in emphasising the need for academic education - I remind the Committee that I have the privilege of speaking as a university graduate - 1 think that we inevitably risk the growth of academic snobbery at all levels. Perhaps a little of the traditional respect for character as opposed simply to intellect would not be a bad thing.

talk.start.para: .- During this debate on the estimates for the Prime Minister's Department 1 would like once again to direct some remarks to the subject of education. The Opposition is endeavouring, generally speaking, to focus attention on education deficiencies, whether at the primary, secondary or tertiary level. We have introduced an amendment for the purpose of stressing that there is an urgent and apparent need for an inquiry into all aspects of education, including those which were spoken of by the honorable member for Kooyong (Mr. Peacock).

speech.para: It was my privilege to move an amendment as long ago as 1958, in terms almost identical to the one now before the Committee and designed for the same purpose. In every subsequent year without a single exception we have continued to urge the Government to have a close look at the needs of education. The fantasy that there are insurmountable constitutional barriers to Commonwealth action in this field, which the former member for Kooyong used to talk about a decade or so ago, disappeared down the drain completely with the innova tions brought about by the Murray Committee on Australian Universities and the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia, from which some wonderful benefits have been derived. But we fail to see why it is that the Government is so adamant about assisting only the top level of education - although even at that level there is still a great deal to be done - when the foundations of the edifice are obviously in such a shaky and unstable condition. I do not think anyone would quibble with the contention that they are in such a condition. I know that as the elections approach and the parent-teacher organisations, the teachers' federations, the mothers' clubs and nursery clubs send their deputations to members representing all political parties, the contention will be general that there is a problem in education and that something should be done about it. But for many years amendments moved by the Opposition for the purpose of having something done about it have failed to receive any support from the Government.

Why is this so? Will the speaker who follows me say whether he believes that the Commonwealth has a responsibility in the field of secondary and primary education or whether he considers there must be some sort of artificial line drawn so that only the tertiary level of education will benefit from Commonwealth assistance? I do not disagree with the honorable member for Kooyong about the great need for higher education. This is the era of computers and electronics, atomic energy and space, of the group of topics that some people talk about as cybernetics. There is a fantastic time ahead for Australia and Australians. There is a great obligation on us to equip ourselves with these modern techniques which have applications in so many important fields. If we care to obtain from the Library books on the application of computers in the health field, for example, we find that it will probably not be very long before we ourselves will be computerised. We will be diagnosed and the information gained from the diagnosis will be stored in computers. A doctor in years to come may find himself in an operating theatre performing a cerebral operation. He may lack training in a certain direction but he will probably be able to press a button and sain knowledge - not just by way of the written word but from computerised information, films, records and things of that kind - derived from an operation performed in Vladivostock or Vienna or somewhere else many years before.

There are many novel ways in which we will gain benefit in the future. We will benefit, for instance, from space exploration. I have read, for instance, that Qantas Empire Airways Ltd. is now thinking about sending space ships or tankers to Venus, the surface of which is said to be a sea of methane gas, and that these tankers will ultimately bring back petroleum or some substance from which petroleum can be derived. I have read that meteorites the size of Tasmania may be pushed out of their orbits by what are called retrorockets and brought down in the North Sea or in central Australia, and that we will then take minerals from them for the benefit of mankind.

We have in Australia a great food and mineral arsenal, and not just for this country alone. We have a large part of the world's wealth and we have only 1 2 million people. It is imperative that we should be equipped, and better equipped than any other group of 12 million people, to give an account of our stewardship. So I would not want the honorable member for Kooyong to get the impression that he is alone in his concern about these matters. It is shared by honorable members on both sides. But there is still not enough being done towards the development of our educational potential, towards the provision of educational opportunities for the young people of Australia.

We have been debating the Budget and we are now debating departmental estimates which make up a Budget of $5,930 million. There is an extra amount of, I think, $274 million collected in taxation. But an infinitesimal additional amount is going towards education. Yesterday I said something similar to this when we were discussing health matters. I said that the sense of priorities is very bad. I made that remark in regard to aged Kid invalid people and handicapped children, and I make exactly the same comment about this subject of education. There is insufficient concern about and emphasis upon this important matter. In my own State the Assistant

Minister for Education, Mr. Fife, who is on the other side of politics from me but has the same kind of concern about education as I have and as most honorable members here would have, said that education in New South Wales is near the breaking point. There is a feeling of urgency about this subject that we seem to be unable to get through to this Government. It is wonderful to talk about academic and philosophical matters, but there are some fundamental things that we must get down to first. We would like to join in with the luxuries after the vital and elementary things are done.

We are going to have an election shortly and education will be an issue of the day. Once again we are going to be asked as candidates whether we believe in the Commonwealth assisting primary schools, secondary schools and technical colleges around Australia. I do not know where honorable members on the other side of the Committee stand generally on this, but the Minister for Health (Dr. Forbes) has made his position clear. A statement by the Minister was reported in the "Australian" of 8th June 1966. The report read -

quote.para: Education has done pretty well in the past 10 years in getting its share of the national cake, the Federal Minister for Health, Dr. Forbes, said yesterday.

speech.para: The Minister seems to be complacent and satisfied. He is not an angry young man about this matter. The report said further -

quote.para: There was no doubt, he said, that increasing direct expenditure by the Commonwealth on education would lead to increasing direct control. This would mean the dead hand of bureaucrats and M.P.s in Canberra on the education system.

speech.para: Apparently this kind of hazard did not exist in respect of the tertiary level of education, the university level. It seems that the Minister is happy to do something about that - and let me say in all fairness that a considerable amount has been done about that. Has there been any wail about the dead hand of bureaucracy or about the crippling effect of parliamentary influence in universities? How can we manage to get our argument on this point over into the area that has been neglected by the Commonwealth? Does the Minister speak for every honorable member on the opposite side? Is this the view of the Government? Is there any honorable member opposite prepared to follow me and say: "As a member of the Liberal-Country Party Government, the Holt Government, I declare on behalf of the Government and on behalf of our Parties that we will never engage in direct assistance to the States for primary and secondary education "? If any honorable members opposite do say this, they are at variance with the Premiers of the various States who belong to the same political parties as they l.o. The State Premiers met in 1953 and asked for an extra S90 million. Liberal Party Premiers, Labour Party Premiers - the lot of them - said: " We want a national inquiry. We want the Commonwealth to conduct this on our behalf to ascertain the needs of education at every level. Until this is done we want an emergency grant for primary and secondary education of S90 million." Do honorable members opposite intend to effect a split in their party organisations by saying they do not stand for what the Premiers want? If honorable members opposite do stand for it they should support the Opposition in its amendment. lt is not good enough to say that the Commonwealth has spent a lot of money on education. We know it has spent a lot, but what has that to do with the problem that prevails? The question is: Is the Government going to spend enough to alleviate the great difficulties being experienced by Australian families? lt is true that the Minister in charge of Commonwealth Activities in Education and Research (Senator Gorton) recently tabled the third report of the Australian Universities Commission and the first report of the Commonwealth Advisory Council. I think these particular milestones in the educational spectrum are of great significance. They show us the value of having some objectivity, some examination of the problem, some opportunity to work towards things. The Murray report and the Martin Committee report are also beneficial in that regard. lt is true, too, that the Minister announced that $610 million would be provided for the triennium. But the honorable member for Kooyong withheld the information that this sum would represent an increase of $190 million over the last triennium expenditure, which was $56 million less than the Universities Commission recommended. He failed to make that point. So even in this area of education, to which, he fairly contends, the Commonwealth has made a reasonable contribution, there is still an element of failure. The Commonwealth has not done what an expert authority contended should be done. I believe that in making its recommendations the Committee would have had regard to the other obligations of the Commonwealth in the educational sphere and in other areas of government activity.

With the limited time at my disposal I will not be able to go into these things in great detail. But it is apparent that insufficient is being done. Building costs in universities are up by 10 per cent, since 1964. I have not calculated this myself, but I think the increase made available for education generally amounts to one-third of one cent in each dollar spent. This is the additional allocation to education - the measurement of the Government's real concern on this score.

I think J should contrast the position in Australia with that in some other parts of the world. On the university front, having provided adequate facilities, the first thing to be broken down is the economic barrier that deters many students from taking higher education. In Washington, President Johnson announced a short time ago that $56 million was available for qualified students who could not attend college without financial help. Grants of from $200 to $800 each would be made to some 130,000 students in the fall semester of the 1966-67 academic year. This is in sharp contrast to the scholarship position in Australia this year. This year 61,619 scholarships were applied for and only 9,992 were awarded. I think that 51,627 missed out. Only 16 per cent, of the applications were successful in obtaining scholarships. So this is one area where there is neglect. But there are so many others. T wanted to talk about the deficiencies in teacher training, deficiencies in the provision of buildings in all States, and the deficiencies in respect of things like libraries and playing fields. Surely there is not much need to labour the point. The Commonwealth will have to face up to these responsibilities i.n the very near future.
The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN__ Order!
The honorable member's time has expired.

talk.start.para: .- I rise to oppose this amendment moved by the Opposition to the Appropriation Bill. I find the amendment itself a curious document. First of all, it is, as one would expect from that source, worded in extravagant language. It expresses carping criticism. It is politically belligerent. It expresses " condemnation of the Government for its failure to conduct an inquiry ", and so on, and " for its failure to make adequate provision for teacher training ". It contains this curious twist of proposing to reduce expenditure by the Commonwealth on education by a certain amount. As to the reduction proposed, a little bit of new thinking about it might have suggested that the amount be rather increased by $10.

speech.para: But leaving that matter on one side: We have been listening to a speech in which the honorable member for Hughes (Mr. L. R. Johnson) has spoken about scholarships in secondary schools being neglected. That, of course, is belieing the whole situation of the secondary education sphere and misrepresents the way in which the Commonwealth has been increasing its interest and the number of scholarships available. To give an illustration of this: I was recently at a fine ceremony conducted by the Ashfield Returned Services League branch. Every year this body raises some thousands of dollars to make scholarships available to the brighter students in the schools in its area. OVer the years it has made a considerable contribution to education and to the encouragement of outstanding students. This year the President of the Ashfield R.S.L., in making his speech to the gathering commented that the Commonwealth Government had pretty well put the R.S.L. out of business in this field. He said that so many scholarships had been granted to students in that area that the R.S.L. had difficulty in finding students of merit to whom the R.S.L. scholarships could be given. This was not my comment. It was the comment of the President of the R.S.L. at Ashfield, which he made publicly at a gathering.

That is just one instance to illustrate the extravagant language in which this amendment has been put. I believe that the Opposition seeks to make a political football out of this subject, which ought to command the highest level of debate and the most constructive and most statesmanlike thought that it is possible to bring to it. Apart from that, I personally find no quarrel with the general philosophy behind the practical aspects of the amendment proposed. Some of the concepts envisaged in the amendment are those to which Government supporters, I am certain, have been directing their attention. Our hopes, like those of honorable members opposite, lie in the possibility, indeed, the inevitability, that before very long the National Parliament will have to take increasing responsibility in education right across the whole spectrum of the field, lt is becoming increasingly evident that it is not possible for the Commonwealth to continue giving assistance to particular sections of education without running the risk of throwing other sectors into imbalance. For example, in helping the universities and then only partially fulfilling the suggestions of the Martin Committee in regard to other tertiary institutions, it is seriously impairing the standing of the teacher training field. The States, naturally, in response to a Commonwealth lead on finance tend to spend in those fields of education which attract matching grants from the Commonwealth. To make matters worse, the better paid and better equipped fields then begin to attract staff away from other very necessary areas such as teachers colleges.

There is undoubtedly a great deal for which this Government is to be commended in its tremendous work in bringing the universities to such magnificent shape. This is something that goes to the credit of the Government. But the Government also, as I have indicated, has an expanding responsibility and concern for the educational field as a whole. But my plea this afternoon is that the Commonwealth reconsider the necessity to give a balanced rather than an ad hoc approach to the whole field of education. There is no question that past action has been warranted to rescue specific sectors from dangerous conditions. However, it is becoming clear that the needs of education in yet other spheres are so serious and so large that no ad hoc or piecemeal approach can be safely considered.

It has been said of the Commonwealth with regard to teacher education, and defending what I hope is a temporary suspension of the recommendations of the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia in this regard, that the widely differing backgrounds and patterns of teacher training in the States are among the reasons why the Commonwealth has not seen a clear way to buy into this field. In act, there has been such a wide divergence of qualifications, of period of training and of the kind of patterns which are seen in the various States with regard to this subject that the Commonwealth, rightly J think, has considered that there was room for a good deal of putting one's own house in order at the State level before it became possible for this Government to lay down lines of approach to the question.

That, I believe, is something which is rapidly being outpaced and outdistanced by the tremendous and growing crisis in teacher education. When one looks at the kind of figures that have been presented to the Australian College of Education recently and the kind of qualifications of teachers generally in Australia, I believe there is room for alarm. Professor Connell has summarised this for the nation and has done a magnificent job in doing so. I believe that perhaps he has oversimplified the matter and has brought certain groups together in a way which does not adequately or fairly reflect the entire situation, but let me quote some of the figures which to me are quite alarming.

Of the 100,000 teachers in Australia, a figure which is growing at the rate of 5,000 each year - 80 per cent., of course, are in government schools - but less than 20 per cent, have university degrees or less than half the secondary teachers have university degrees. About one fifth have reached less than matriculation standard. I add here that there are reasons for this, such as through some teachers not going on to do university degrees because of the nature of the course they were pursuing, having preferred to do other than a matriculation type secondary course. Nevertheless, it is a sobering thought. Only two thirds of all the teachers in the nation ever went to a teachers' college, and 8 per cent, had no training at all as teachers. That figure, of course, includes teachers of music and home science and many other things for which specialised training has been given. Nevertheless, in this new approach and this new age there is a demand for a greater degree of professional training. Only 3.5 per cent, have a higher degree of any kind and this percentage will probably fall. About one-sixth of the teachers in secondary schools have had no university training of any kind in the subjects they are teaching. Even in the vital subjects of mathematics, physics and chemistry, less than half the teachers taking students for matriculation have not majored in those subjects in their own training. As I have said, there are valid explanations for some of the statistics I have quoted. But it needs no words of mine to stress the seriousness of that summary, not only for individual girls and boys but also for the nation as a whole. I am sure that most thinking people in the nation would applaud Professor Connell's addition to the charter for teacher training in the report that there should be an uncompromising statement that entry to school teaching must be by means of a properly constituted course of training.

I believe there is reason for us to give some consideration to professional developments taking place within the teacher training field. There is increasing awareness of the need for teachers to be like other professional people with their own standards recognised throughout the nation and their own professional standing in the eyes of the nation. This is something to which I believe considerable encouragement must be given because, while it is true that the States have differing backgrounds and differing patterns of operation in many cases, this is not because of present requirements but has to do with the past rather than the future. In fact there has been remarkable unanimity as regards the hopes and visions for the future evident in, for example, the work I have quoted of the Australian College of Education on nationwide teacher training requirements.

There are grounds for believing that united rather than uniform approaches are possible and ought to be encouraged. I believe that in many fields sufficient investigation work has already been done. The amendment speaks a great deal about conducting inquiries, but we have already had a large number of inquiries. One was conducted by the Australian College of Education which I have already cited. There is the work of the Australian Educational Council which has been printed and has been long in our hands and well studied. There are many results of these inquiries already to hand. A great deal of searching has been done and I believe sufficient has been produced to show that there are obvious needs, both urgent and massive, in some sectors. In some of these, for example in New South Wales where the Wyndham scheme is about to increase vastly the number of students in secondary schools, coming into operation most viciously, if I may use that word, next year, these effects are so serious that they threaten the structure of education itself. So I make this plea in the light of all that has been said this afternoon that the Commonwealth should take the lead in the entire field of education. To continue aid at the tertiary level without regard to priorities as to the use of funds relative to other levels could be as short sighted as building an elaborate treatment plant and smelter without first making sure that there were supplies of ore of a grade to warrant the construction of the plant.

So I sympathise with the proposition that there should be emergency grants, that there should be provision made for some of these crises which undoubtedly exist in the whole field, such as in New South Wales secondary schools which I have mentioned, and in the field of teacher training where the recommendations of the Martin Committee in my view should be implemented as soon as it is humanly possible to do so. Also, whilst we have had in the past many reports from committees of inquiry, I feel that " inquiry " is the wrong word to use here. I would much sooner see a committee set up in an advisory capacity to the Commonwealth with regard to the complete field of education from kindergarten. Indeed, it could advise on education upwards from the pre-school level, where a tremendously important job is done in forming attitudes, psychological approaches and the social attitudes of children to education. This is something on which such a committee should report to the Government. This committee should have representatives of the Universities Commission on it, but it should also have available on its strength the best statesmen in educaion.
The quantum of money needed for such an approach to education staggers the imagination. It must certainly frighten the

Treasurer and it certainly gives a responsible government reason to pause. A very great amount of money wm be needed to give this nation the kind of educational pattern that it requires to bring it into line with other and vaster nations in the western world. If this is to be achieved I cannot see that it can come about without some increase in taxation. If this is so, then it is also my opinion that the nation is rapidly getting to the place where it is ready for an honest, frank statement on needs. It is my opinion that it will be supported. In fact, it is often felt that a massive plan to take the field of education out of its present piecemeal existence into a semblance of order and security would be a valuable and attractive policy to put to the people, because I am sure that the majority of people in the nation realise that, while some are making tremendous sacrifices in the field of defence, we should not ourselves boggle at or shrink from making demands for a degree of sacrifice from the nation as a whole for a field which is so intimately connected, not only with the wellbeing and development of the nation but also with the defence and strength of the nation in years to come.
