talk.start.para: .- I wish to speak briefly tonight on two aspects of the estimates for the Prime Minister's Department. One relates to education and the other to Commonwealth and State relationships. Other honorable members have emphasised the extreme importance of education to the future development of this country. In fact, various surveys that have been made have shown that people in Australia are more concerned with education than they are with some of the problems of defence. This is understandable, because parents are concerned with the education of their children, and many children in country areas, because of insufficient secondary industries, are destined to spend most of their working lives in the capital cities.

speech.para: According to some of the authorities, educational standards in Queensland are being progressively lowered because of the major problems confronting the educational system there. The per capita expenditure on education in Queensland is lower than that in any other State. Because education is such an important facet of our lives, the per capita expenditure on it should be the same or nearly the same in all States, but in Queensland the expenditure is much lower than in the other States. So bad has the position become that a conservative section of the Queensland Teachers Union is actually considering whether its members should take the drastic step of striking. In fact, the Mackay branch of the Union recommended that the teachers should go on strike.

The crux of the matter, of course, is lack of funds, of Federal funds in particular, to stimulate activity in relation to education. As has been explained by other honorable members, the main problems concern the recruitment of teachers, teacher training and the condition of teachers. There seems to be little appreciation here of the importance of teacher training and of the importance of recruiting the right type of teachers. Wc are inclined to attach too much importance to university training and not enough importance to primary and secondary education. How many of us in this House who have had the privilege of university training realise how poorly equipped we were in some disciplines because of the lack of basic, fundamental training in certain fields? This is possibly more often the fault of the student than of the teacher, but in many cases the teachers arc poorly equipped to train students in the best way.

This is certainly the position in Queensland today. The Queensland Teachers Union and other organisations there are quite alive to the problem. They recognise the urgent and very important problem presented by the lowering of standards. Tn many cases, average students are receiving marks which indicate that they are not getting sufficient training, and students with a high I.Q. are relegated to lower positions because of unsatisfactory teacher training methods. In saying this, I am making no attack on the teachers themselves; I am attacking the educational system. Surely that system warrants very much more effort than has been put into it hitherto. The future prosperity of this country is becoming more and more dependent upon tech nology, and the success of technology depends largely on the way in which we train our technicians. Whether they may be agricultural scientists, businessmen, economists, librarians - whatever they may be - their basic, fundamental training in the primary and secondary schools will be of the utmost importance to them.

In this country we spend a fair amount of money on helping sub-normal children. That is a very good thing; more should be spent on it. But how much money do we spend on helping the top student, the student with a high I.Q. or the student with the high degree of common sense who is prepared to learn and has the ability to go a long way? Usually these students are accommodated in the crowded classrooms that we see so often, and as a result their education must suffer. Because of the rejection of the recommendations of the Martin Committee on the Future of Tertiary Education in Australia relating to teacher training, we see a marked deterioration in the quality of teachers, certainly in Queensland. I regret to say this, but the type of teacher being recruited today is nowhere near as high a standard as was the case some years ago. At one time, teaching was an honoured profession. Today, however, if one fails to obtain a Commonwealth scholarship or is unable to attend a university, one seems to finish up being a teacher.

talk.start.para: - That is a shocking indictment of the teachers.

- If the honorable member cares to read the official organs of the teachers' unions, he will find those exact words. As I said before, education is basic and fundamental to the scientists, the administrators and the businessmen of this community. We should heed the advice that has been given from both sides of the chamber with respect to education during the course of this debate today.

speech.para: I should like to say a word or two about Commonwealth and State relationships, because a major function of the Prime Minister's Department is the maintenance of harmonious relationships between the Commonwealth and the States. The Prime Minister's Department is responsible for inter-departmental co-ordination in government, administration and economic affairs, and for communications between the Commonwealth and the States. The usual method of approach to the Commonwealth is via a Premier. The matter is then processed by the Commonwealth and transmitted back to the States by the Prime Minister. Taking developmental projects as an example, if a project is submitted by a State to the Commonwealth, the Prime Minister's Department is the department really responsible for the determination or interpretation of final policy on the matter. I believe that relationships with the States are progressively worsening under the present system, where we have the unsavoury spectacle of the States begging for funds each year. One major reason for this is the imbalance in the economy caused by what I have termed the octopuslike growth of the cities, and the ever increasing demands on the Commonwealth for funds to cope with this self-generating growth. With the limited finance that is available, it is becoming increasingly difficult to meet the urgent demands of the States for funds to meet their financial commitments.

If one can judge by newspaper reports of the views of Sir Henry Bolte, Mr. Askin and the other State Premiers, it is certainly right to conclude that CommonwealthState relations today are not smooth. One of the reasons for this, obviously, is the arrogance of the present Commonwealth Government towards the States. It seems that this Government's arrogance is replaced by humility only when it runs into electoral reverses. This was clearly demonstrated after the 1961 general election, at which the Government suffered a very serious setback. After that election, we saw the Commonwealth playing a more realistic role in Commonwealth-State relations. It actually began co-operating with the States and co-ordinating its activities with theirs in determining priorities for the allocation of funds so as to ensure the maximum development, the maximum return and the maximum benefit for the States. As a result, we saw stimulation of the economy between the general elections in 1961 and 1963. At that time, Commonwealth-State relations appeared to be good, if one judges by the statements of the Premiers that were then reported. During that period, the Prime Minister's Department had a major hand in formulating policy on many projects relating to the standardisation of rail gauges in southern Australia, coal ports, beef roads, land development and the Ord River scheme. After 1963, however, the position again deteriorated, just as it is deteriorating now. Once again we read reports of criticism of the Commonwealth made by Sir Henry Bolte and Mr. Askin.

Let me illustrate what I describe as the Government's arrogance by reference to answers that have been given recently to questions asked upon notice. 1 recently asked a question about a proposed Queensland project that has been mentioned frequently in the newspapers in the last three years - the Nogoa River irrigation project. I asked when the Prime Minister's Department received the Queensland Premier's request for evaluation of the project and what was the position relating to the investigations that had been undertaken. The reply, which I received yesterday, was -

quote.para: Tt is not customary to make information of this type public without the prior agreement of the State Government concerned.

speech.para: The truth, of course, is that the Commonwealth has done nothing about the matter. We could go right through a list of projects that have been referred to the Prime Minister's Department. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr. Whitlam, recently asked a question upon notice seeking information about the project for the border rivers between New South Wales and Queensland. The reply that he received yesterday was almost identical with the answer to my question about the Nogoa irrigation project, for it was in these terms -

quote.para: Information of the type requested by the honorable member is regarded by the Commonwealth Government as confidential between itself and the State Government concerned unless it is mutually agreed to make the information public.

speech.para: That information is made public in the newspapers. One has only to read the daily Press to see it. The truth, again, is that the Commonwealth has done nothing about the matter. This sort of attitude on the part of the Commonwealth does not bring about good relations with the States. I recently asked upon notice -

quote.para: What is the name of each water conservation project located north of Brisbane for which the Queensland Government requested financial assistance . . . ?

speech.para: The answer that I received from the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt) was -

quote.para: Information of the type requested by the honorable member is regarded by the Commonwealth Government as confidential . . .

speech.para: One has only to read the particulars of payments made by the Commonwealth to the States to learn the answer: Absolutely no money has been made available to the State by the Commonwealth for this purpose. I he Commonwealth has made available to the States S900 million, but not one cent has been allocated to Queensland for water conservation projects. This is a disgraceful indictment of the present Commonwealth Government.

talk.start.para: . - Mr. Chairman, I want to devote my remarks to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. This afternoon, the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) discussed this subject. I pay a tribute to him because it was his persistent advocacy in this chamber that led to the establishment of the Institute. Both he and I have the honour to represent the House of Representatives on the Council of the Institute. I stress again that although Australia as a country now has 180 years of history, the establishment of this Institute recently represents only the third serious effort at a governmental level to record the customs of the Aboriginal people and to seek to understand the Aborigines. The first attempt was made by the Queensland Government at the turn of the century when it commissioned Roth, the anthropologist. The second was made by the Government of South Australia which, in the days when it was responsible for the Northern Territory, commissioned the Baldwin Spencer expeditions. The third attempt has now been made by the Commonwealth by the establishment of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, which finances universities and individuals in recording the languages, the music, the customs and the like of the Aboriginal people.

speech.para: The amount of the grant made to the Institute represents a test of whether we are a people that recognises the value of other people, of whether we recognise the value of unique thought structures, of whether our attitude to an immemorial culture amounts to ignorant contempt, as has been the situation in the past, and of whether we can understand that knowledge of a thought life utterly different from our own in its roots and origins may throw light on all human psychology. In a way, the amount of the grant made for the Institute is a test of whether we can appreciate another people and of whether we are capable only of a kind of cultural genocide. In the smugness of our aim of assimilation, there arises a doubt: Should we not, before the Aborigines vanish, record their languages, music, art, dances, ritual, beliefs, philosophy, artifacts and customs? The crass, dull ignorance of the past - the proud ignorance that we have had with respect to another people - still manifests itself in a million ways. We are the last generation to have a chance to undertake this recording of the features of the life of the Aboriginal people, and posterity will not forgive us if we miss it.

One of the many respects in which people of about the age of 20 today are superior to our generation is in their desire for this kind of anthropological knowledge. It is a feature of the universities today that there are hopeless queues of as many as 200 or 250 anthropology students seeking one book that has been set for a tutorial. I realise that the purpose of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies is to record what may be called new knowledge of the Aboriginal people. But the numbers of trained anthropologists who can do this work will underlie the work of the Institute. It may well be worth the Commonwealth Government's time for it to take a look at these hopeless queues of anthropology students seeking books in the universities and to see whether it can do something to increase the supply of the required material. 1 see the distinguished Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes) entering the chamber. He was an effective member of the Select Committee on the Voting Rights of Aborigines. Those of us who had the opportunity to serve on the select committee which heard the grievances of the Yirrkala people came across an astonishing fact. Honorable members will recall that one of the stipulations laid down by the Parliament in passing the resolutions which set up the committee was that we should hear the Aborigines through competent interpreters.
This ii precisely what the Commonwealth Government never does. It remains deaf to the thousands of Aborigines of Arnhem Land because it is without linguists.

I remember the evidence of the Aborigines given to us through interpreters. The elders of the tribe were orators of great dignity. They answered questions with considerable penetration. The Commonwealth's welfare officers who sat listening to the proceedings confessed afterwards that they were utterly staggered by what they had heard. They had no idea that the Aborigines thought this way or held these opinions. This was because the Commonwealth had nobody who could hear Aborigines speak in their own languages. All it had were people who were in contact with Aborigines struggling to express themselves in English. In a sense the Commonwealth Government was proud not to know their languages. It was proud to have schools which could be conducted only in English, where Aboriginal children must conform and try to obtain their fundamental education in a language in which they did not think. This is part of our arrogant assimilation policy.

The Aborigines demonstrated how they were not listened to. They described how the chief welfare- officer of the Northern Territory would rush in by aircraft and how, when they were trying to talk to him. he would constantly look at his wristlet watch. It was devastating evidence. I believe young people today do want the humility of listening to these people because they have a great many things to say which are interesting. In spite of our ignorant contempt for them, Aborigines are regarded by anthropologists as the intellectuals of the primitive world. But the Aborigine is a transcendent thinker, to use the terminology of the philosophers. He insists on an explanation for everything. The native of New Guinea is an immanent thinker. He lives for the moment. He has easily conformed to our money economy. He has moved from day to day. readily adaptable. But the Aborigine developed one of the most elaborate thought structures in human history. Everything had to be explained. Every physical feature and its origin had to be explained. The origin of the animals had to be explained. Some tribes, such as the Loritja initiated their youth by making them learn a saga of 1,000 verses which explained the origin of everything - where water was to be found, where the best hunting was, and the use of trees and plants - so that the whole of their history, religion, economy and geography was taught in the one stage. These transcendent thinkers tried to explain everything, including their position in the universe, with their art, corroborees and dancing. They were an utterly isolated people, except for contact with those whom we would now call Indonesians, and this was intermittent contact by the coastal Aborigines of Arnhem Land. Otherwise they had no contacts. Living isolated, in many cases in thankless deserts, they developed a philosophy and a way of life which enabled them to survive in the most grim conditions.

This attitude to other races is the true test of whether there is anything new in our community. I believe there is something new in modern Australian youth. Lots of people think they are producing something new. But the Red Guards, for instance, in China are a throwback to the Boxers in their contempt for barbarians and foreign devils and their rejection of all external ideas. They are really reverting to the past in China and not producing something revolutionary and new. I am not sure whether our assimilation policy is not anything more than a reversion to our own arrogant past whereby we assumed that the Aborigines had nothing worth preserving, and that they must conform to us. We called this " assimilation " and said it was a new and enlightened policy, but it is precisely the way we have acted for 1 80 years.

Nearly all of the a priori assumptions made about the Aborigines were false. The attitude to the Aborigines is a test of whether there is any real change among Australian people on race issues. We believed, for instance, that the lives of Aborigines were drab. I will not suggest that the lives of fringe dwellers are not drab, but they to a large extent are deculturalised We have assumed that the lives of the Aborigines were drab, but they were rich in ritual. They had a whole hypothesis of creation which gave them immense satisfaction. Literature seemed utterly absent and certainly there was only the literature of drawings. But there were word of mouth sagas of great complexity, great length and great penetration. They appeared to have no records but their corroborees are complex records of their whole past. They seemed to own no land, and how happy we were about this. We said that the Aborigine was a nomad, so he may as well move to some other place whenever we wanted his land. We have precisely that philosophy today whenever minerals are discovered on reserves. We know that in South Australia the first move in the history of the Commonwealth is being made to acknowledge some kind of tribal title to land. It is having a grisly time with the Legislative Council. The Aborigines seemed to own no land and not to be concerned about it, but the whole relationship of every individual was to some particular piece of land. His origins were believed to be in the earth spirit, in some particular piece of land in some particular place. Relationship with this land and its features was an absolutely major part of his life.

Although the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies does not deal with Aboriginal policy, I believe that it is injecting, rightly, into the Australian community a new sensitivity and a new appreciation. It has come almost too late, but I do not believe it is entirely too late. I believe that what has been done already by the musicologists, the film men, the linguists who have produced dictionaries and whole volumes of verses and those who have studied their social life through the Institute has contributed to a vital part of the history of this country. Australians of the future will regard the Aborigines as a part of the history of this country even if Australians of the past have not regarded them as being of any significance. More and more we are coming into contact with neighbours who will regard our relationship with these people as a test. I believe that a basic enlightenment of policy is possible if the Commonwealth Government realises what a treasure it now has in its hands in the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.

talk.start.para: .- In speaking to these estimates, I want to express my appreciation of the courtesy and co-operation extended to me by officers of the Department of Social Services in Western Australia during the time that I have been a member of the Parliament. These people are criticised for what they do or do not do at times, but if the actions or attitudes that give rise to the criticism are closely examined it will invariably be found that the officers have been bound or limited by the policy of the Government, the instructions of the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Sinclair) or the Act itself. In fact, the criticism should be levelled directly at the Government and not at the officers of the Department, because they have no control over government policy. The officers are obliged by the policy of the Government to refuse or reduce social service payments and this in turn causes the applicants or recipients some suffering or inconvenience. As a result, the officers are often condemned for a policy over which they have no control. For instance, the recent instruction by the Minister in relation to the abolition of cash payments went out over the signature of the Director in the State, and as a result the Director copped the blame, when actually it was no fault of his. However, where the Department's officers have a free hand I have always found them helpful and co-operative in attempting to bring about the desired results. I certainly appreciate their help.

speech.para: Recently we had before us the Social Services Bill 1966, the contents of which were described by the Minister as measures representing an acceptance of the responsibility of the community to provide for its less fortunate members. I feel quite sure that the general public would take offence at those remarks. The Minister was not expressing the real views of the people. The opposite would be the true position. The measures contained in the Bill were very few and provided for small increases in isolated instances and certainly did not represent the general community's idea of acceptance of what the age, invalid and widow pensioners should actually receive. 1 say, as a member of the community, that they certainly did not represent my feelings of responsibility in that regard. They may, and apparently do, represent the feelings and attitude of the Liberal Party and of the Country Party, but quite certainly the Australian Labour Party does not agree that the Parliament measured up to its responsibilities in that Bill. The Minister went on to say - and 1 agree with him in this regard - that the measures in the Bill represented a continuance of the Government's policy to provide assistance to the less fortunate. I think we would all agree that making small increases to a few items only of social service, and at the same time completely ignoring many other items, is certainly a continuance of Government policy. It is also completely in line with the thinking of Government supporters.

If we examine the statement attached to the Budget speech we find that out of a total of 35 items of social service - and I exclude the health items - only 11 were adjusted. What the Minister really told us was that by making additions to about one third of the social service items he was carrying out Government policy. He also admitted, of course, that by making the very meagre increases to those few items he was carrying out Government policy in relation to financial assistance to pensioners. I have no argument with the Minister if he feels obliged to admit that inadequate pensions and allowances and discrimination between pensioners is Government policy and has the blessing of Government supporters. If he feels he should make that quite clear, that is O.K. by me, but I take exception to his claim that the general community accepts the Government's policy in that regard, because that just is not so. It certainly is not the attitude of members of the Opposition. The point remains that the Minister has admitted, apparently with some pride, that the recent Social Services Bill represents Government policy.

It is very important that we examine Government policy. One could take the married pensioner couple rate as a fair example. In 1962 both pensioners received 5 5s. a week. In 1963 the pension remained the same. In 1964 it was increased by 5s. a week to 5 10s. a week. In 1965 there was no increase. This year there has been an increase of 7s. 6d. or 75c. Over this five year period the pension payable to a married pensioner has increased from 5 5s. or $10.50 to 5 17s. 6d. or SI 1.75- a total increase of 12s. 6d. or Si. 25. By my reckoning this amounts to an average of 25c a year. Thus we have the interesting, although rather frightening, position of the Minister telling us clearly that he is continuing Government policy and, this being so, that married pensioner couples in Australia can look forward to receiving an average increase in pension of 25c each year while this Government remains in office. This, of course, applies to age and invalid pensioners. In referring to invalids I point out that during the five year period I have mentioned there was also an increase of 1.2s. 6d. or $1.25 in the wife's allowance, so here again there was an average increase of 25c a year.

The maternity allowance has not been increased since 1%2. Child endowment has not been increased in respect of the first or second child, but the payment for children beyond the first two has been increased by 50c. The Minister draws attention to this as being the Government's policy. Over the five year period the A class widow's pension has been increased by $2, or 40c a year. The B and C class widows have received a total increase of S2.50. or an average of 50c a year. This is the continuation of Government policy. These people can expect the same treatment over the next five years if they are prepared to allow the present Government to remain in office. We find that the unemployment and sickness benefits have not been altered; they remain as they were in 1962. I emphasise that the average increase in social service payments during the last five years has been 25c, 40c or 50c a year, and that some benefits have not been increased at all, yet the Minister referred to the measures in the Social Services Bill as being the acceptance of a responsibility towards pensioners and a continuance of Government policy. This means that next year, under this Government, married pensioner couples can expect to receive a further 25c increase in their pension. Perhaps the increase will be 50c, or even $1, but if they should happen to receive a SI increase next year they must bear in mind that they will have to wait until 1970, or perhaps 1971, before they get a further increase, and then it will be only 25c. That is the outlook for pensioners while this Government remains in power. This is Government policy, as the Minister told us, and it is the policy the Government intends to continue. Of course, if the Government is returned it will take the election result as meaning that the people of Australia, including the pensioners, support its policy, and therefore the people cannot expect any different treatment.

The wage and salary earners and their wives would be well advised also to look at this Government's policy and to give serious thought to the social services situation. If a breadwinner suffers an illness, or an accident for which he is not entitled to compensation, or is not able to get employment, he will receive from the Government the same rate as applied in 1962. The Government has had the opportunity of increasing all social service benefits, but it has failed to do so. No doubt the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt) in his election policy speech later this year will promise some increases in social service payments. If he does, I suggest that pensioners and other recipients of social service benefits, and those who expect to become recipients in the future, should not fail to remember that just before the 1963 election the Government made such a promise. After being elected the Government increased by only 5s., or 50c, the pension paid to married age and invalid pensioners and widows. It failed to do anything more about pensions until recently because we are now on the eve of another election. The Government will follow that same policy if it is elected again this year.

The fact of the matter is that the Government's policy is driving more and more people into a state of poverty. Immediately a man or woman is obliged to go on the pension he or she faces an existence of near poverty simply because this Government is not treating them as it should. Just because a person is unable to continue working for a living is no reason why he should have to depend on charity for an existence. But that is what is actually happening. A survey carried out last year proved that thousands of pensioners depend regularly on free meals and other help from charitable organisations to avoid slow starvation. It also showed that thousands of pensioners have to depend on charity to obtain blankets for the winter otherwise they would sleep cold or not sleep at all. The blanket appeal is an annual event in Western Australia - I imagine it would be in other States as well - made necessary because of this Government's attitude to pensioners. The survey proved further that only a very small percentage of pensioners have refrigerators, washing machines or electric or gas stoves. The majority of those who happen to have a wood stove, the survey proved, were unable to purchase sufficient wood for their requirements. This Government after 17 years in office still has pensioners depending on charity.

The Government made a great song and dance about, and apparently expected great applause for, introducing a rent allowance for single pensioners. This was later extended to include married pensioners in cases where the wife did not receive a pension but received a wife's allowance. According to the Government, this was a great step forward. I took the trouble to ask a question about this matter and received a reply dated 30th August 1966 which indicated that only .1 6.5 per cent, of the total number of pensioners receive an allowance. In other words, 16.5 per cent, get something and 83.5 per cent, get nothing. And this is what the Minister has put forward as the Government's policy.

More recently Government members have endeavoured to support their attitude towards the present inadequate pensions by measuring the present rate as a percentage of the basic wage. They have taken the basic wage in 1949 or some such far off year as a measuring stick. As 1 have said before, no-one can successfully argue that the pension, in relation to the basic wage or anything else at any particular time, was actually sufficient for pensioners to live on. Everyone knows that over the past 15 years and more the basic wage has gradually lost its value in relation to the cost of living.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- The honorable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. Collard) has been rather critical of this Government's performance in relation to pensions. I expect that these fulminations from honorable members opposite will continue throughout this debate because we must remember that we are on the eve of an election and they are casting around frantically, desperately, for some issue on which they can seize which may have some appeal to the public at large. All 1 say in this regard is that we should let the people compare the performance of this Government, which has provided one of the finest pension schemes in the world, with the miserable performance of the Ministry to which the honorable member opposite who is now interjecting belonged when Labour was in office so many years ago. The Labour Party then had an opportunity to increase pensions - no -one was inhibiting them - but the fact is that during their term the pension was reduced on one occasion. I do not think they can be very proud of that.

speech.para: I congratulate the Department upon the way in which it has managed its affairs during the past year and, in particular I compliment the Minister for Social Services (Mr. Sinclair) on his efficient, intelligent and if he will excuse me for saying so, his liberal administration, of the Department. I have always had the greatest admiration for the way in which he has managed the Department of Social Services. I have had no cause for complaint. In fact, I have always received the most courteous attention when I have come to him with a problem. [ congratulate him further on the recent pension increase of $1 a week for single pensioners and $1.50 for a pensioner couple. This will help considerably people who admittedly are often living under considerable difficulties. This is a problem which is exercising the minds of all honorable members at the present time. However, we must not lose sight of the fact that pension provisions in Australia are amongst the best in the world. We must remember also that there is only a limited amount of money in this country available for the provision of all services and that if we increase pensions there will inexorably be an increase in income tax.

This Government has had a very lively sense of responsibility to the community. We must not run the risk of inhibiting the economy by imposing too heavy a tax burden upon it. Honorable members opposite laugh because they are the greatest exponents of crushing and crippling taxation of any party in the world today. However, despite these problems and the almost certain result of increased income tax, is there any justification for broadening the eligibility for pensions? I believe that for many reasons a case for this can be made out. First, a liberalisation of the means test would enable some who are in difficulties to supplement their incomes, and it would help to overcome many anomalies. Some of the anomalies in respect of, for example, superannuation, are beyond my comprehension because, as I think is fairly well known, there is no difference between the income received by a person who took up, say, 10 units of superannuation and thus paid an appropriate contribution rate during his working life, and that received by a person who took up only 3 units. This anomaly cannot be very pleasing to the former superannuitants when they reach retiring age.

There are other points as well. The present system discourages thrift and encourages people who have saved during their working life to spend some of their savings before they retire. There is also the philosophical question upon which I will not take any side, as to whether the elderly who have paid income tax and who have worked throughout their active life and raised a family should not be granted some concession in the form of a liberalisation of the means test. 1 believe a case can be made out in that respect but obviously it is utterly impractical to remove the means test at one stroke. The increase in taxation would be crippling and 1 am sure the economy would not be able to stand up to the severe strain which would be imposed upon it. These are the things we must consider. 1 have a suggestion which may assist in easing the means test without imposing this completely crippling degree of income tax upon the community. I believe that we should grant a half pension to those of eligible age irrespective of means test.

talk.start.para: - That is what they are getting now.

- Then they must have been receiving only a quarter pension when you lot were in power. As I was saying, a half pension should be given to all the people of pensionable age irrespective of means test, but those who are presently unaffected by the means test would naturally be still entitled to a full pension. I have some relevant figures before me. They may not be the latest figures but they are the best I could obtain. They show that there are in Australia 384,150 males and 509,693 females of pensionable age. Of these, 184,189 males and 443,911 females are actually receiving pensions. As I have said, these figures may not be exact, but they give a pretty reasonable guide and they would not be very far wrong. This means that about 200,000 males and 65,500 females of pensionable age are not receiving pensions at the present time. I might point to the highly significant fact that of the females of pensionable age only a very few are in fact working. I mention that because these females would be better able to work than the males. We know full well that the female of the species is made of more substantial fibre than the male. I am sorry to say this, but it is true. I think that if all these people of pensionable age were given a half pension and had the proper motivation, a lot of them would work. We know that in our present situation in this country we need workers, and especially skilled workers, and these people would be mainly skilled workers. As I said in my speech on the Budget, a good proportion of these older people are well able to work and perform creditably in almost any sphere of activity.
- Would you look for another job at 60 years of age?

- The honorable member for Barton might like to retire at 60. In fact, he might be retiring from this Parliament at a much earlier age, but whether this has coloured his thinking or not I do not know. But the point I am trying to make is a serious one, and I wish honorable members opposite would not stick their heads in the sand but would give my proposal consideration. It is very important to these older people that they should work. Many of them lose all motivation on retiring and simply run to seed. 1 have a very apt quotation before me. It is from a doctor, Dr. Alex Johnson, who said -

quote.para: The danger of " acting old " is a very real one and doctors have a responsibility to help elderly patients keep morale and hope high. When a patient is convinced that he is done for he has said goodbye to health, happiness and purpose. This slate of affairs is all too common and prompts the cliche " We ripen or we rot ".

speech.para: I believe that we should try to motivate these people to work. I am not suggesting that we should compel them to work. If we can motivate them to work we will save them from rotting and we will assist the community very considerably by increasing the available work force, which is something that is sorely needed in the prosperous Australia of today.

I shall give honorable members an idea of what this would mean, and the figures 1 give are quite possible of achievement. If we provided the right motivation, we could have 45,000 more males and 60,000 more females of pensionable age working. I believe these figures are conservative. I know it is difficult to give an accurate estimate because many people of this age would be quite unable to work. But I have studied statistics and I believe these figures are quite capable of achievement.

How do we provide the motivation? We do it. first, simply by removing the means test. This would provide motivation because they would know they would still receive a half pension and associated benefits even if they continued to work. They must be motivated also by encouragement and by suitable information services. The Commonwealth Employment Service must be brought up to date in regard to this matter. This sort of thing is done in other parts of the world, and where it has been done it has proved very satisfactory. The Commonwealth Employment Service must have specialists trained in advising old people. One reason why old people retire altogether from work is that they lose a job and find it hard to get another one. A person may be misplaced once or twice. This may be done in all good faith; the Commonwealth Employment Service does a magnificent job but it must have expertise. After a person loses a couple of jobs he is inclined to say: " I will give it away.". But if such people are motivated correctly and placed correctly, and if there is a scheme instituted such as those in existence in other parts of the world, under which old people are constantly being retrained for jobs - and this does not involve a great deal of training - then I believe we can easily achieve the numbers I have quoted and perhaps many more.

If we did this we would save the taxpayer in aggregate 105.000 half pensions, but on the other hand there would be 265,000 more people who would be receiving half pensions. In other words, there would be a net increase of about 160,000 half pensions. These would amount to about 55 million a year, which the Government might theoretically have to find. But the taxpayers would not have to find the full amount of $55 million for the simple reason that many of these people would be paying income tax and a substantial amount of money would be returned to revenue in this way. I believe that if we are eventually going to eliminate the means test completely, then the worker will have to find the necessary money throughout his working life. We all know there is no Santa Claus. As I have said before, and as every responsible citizen knows, this is an expensive business. We cannot afford to cripple the economy, which is carefully and skilfully but delicately balanced. If we did not make people contribute throughout their working lives we would impose crippling burdens.

The point I make is that if we instituted the scheme I propose and at the same time commenced a contributory scheme, the taxpayer would have to contribute very little indeed towards a system which would give a half pension to all people of pensionable age in the community today. I think that in doing this we would not only be correcting many anomalies but we would also be performing a social good deed, in that we would re-motivate people who at present are not ripening but are rotting in the community and who could be happily performing a useful task.

talk.start.para: .- We are discussing at present the estimates of the Repatriation Department and the Department of Social Services, and I want to speak first about the estimates for the Repatriation Department. Let me say, first, that as our present legislation stands, the repatriation services in this country are among the best in the world, although sometimes the Act is not administered according to what we believe to be the letter of the law. I have had an opportunity, as a member of the Public Works Committee, to visit repatriation hospitals and I believe they are doing a creditable service. Ex-servicemen are being given good treatment by their fellow Australians - and rightly so. If a man is prepared to offer his life in the defence of his country I believe we should be prepared to support him for the rest of his lifetime if he is incapacitated because of that war service. But I believe that many of the anomalies that exist under the present legislation have not been cleared up by the Government although it has had 16 or 17 years in which to do so. It may be difficult to remove many of these anomalies, but I believe that the Minister and the officers concerned should be prepared to settle down and tackle the problems effectively. It is all very well to grant a few dollars extra on this occasion to some of these people, but why not clean up the anomalies that have existed over the years? The Government should bring in legislation to clean up these matters.

speech.para: There are quite a few ex-servicemen suffering at the present time from heart complaints, lung complaints and cancer. Whether or not they form a bigger proportion of ex-servicemen than such sufferers among civilians form, I am not prepared to say; but I know from experience that young fellows who served with me are suffering from heart complaints now when they are not yet 50 years of age. They live in the north and are classified by the doctors as not being permanently incapacitated. They can earn a living but they cannot lift anything more than 15 or 20 lbs. When they live in areas such as north Queensland, and back country areas of any State at all, how can they get a job that will not involve their having to lift a weight of more than 20 lbs? It is all very well for doctors to say that they can do light duties. If they move to the south, to the cities, they can get jobs as lift drivers or at some other light duties. But what do the doctors expect them to do? Do they expect them to sell up the homes for which they have saved all their lives? Do they expect them to sacrifice their homes? They would have to sell at a loss and would have to buy new clothes for for their wives and families, because clothes they wear in the north would not be suitable for the southern cities; so new clothes would be another added expense for them.

I have put cases before the Minister for Repatriation and the Repatriation Department, and the Department will not put the people concerned even on the intermediate rate pension. It puts them on the 100 per cent. rate. These people cannot live on the 100 per cent, rate when they have a family. They want to work. They are prepared to work. I know of several cases where the persons concerned have tried to get employment and have worked for a week, a fortnight, three weeks or a month, but eventually, because of the strain, they have been taken to hospital again, treated for another three weeks and then discharged. This is happening time and time again. I could give details of the individual cases if required. These men have been before the Repatriation Board but they say the same reply comes back to them: " Come down south where you can get a job which is suitable for your condition ".

I appeal to the departmental officers and the Minister to consider the conditions under which these men are forced to leave their homes. If they are forced to leave their homes in the north, sell them at a sacrifice and move south, they are forced to buy other homes at inflated prices. They have to buy somewhere near the city or the suburbs where they can find light work. They have to suitably clothe their families, resettle their children in schools and help them to find new friends. It is not a problem easy for these ex-servicemen to solve. I think they deserve consideration in regard to these matters.

I think that if a survey were taken we would find that ex-servicemen suffer more from heart complaints than do civilians of the same age. I am talking about men who have been in the thick of war - men who have suffered bombing and explosions, and not particularly those who have been fired at; many ex-servicemen were fired at during the early stages of the war. But when the bombing was terrific, when we had no protection and had to suffer bombing attacks from superior air power, it was a tremendous task to try to keep from breaking, from letting one's spirit crack, to keep on one's feet and to lead or be part of the team. It was a difficult job and it must have been a strain which must eventually tell upon a man. This kind of thing may not have affected ex-servicemen as soon as they returned to normal life, but it must do so as they get older.

I find that this is happening to quite a few of the younger ex-servicemen from World War II who are not yet 50 or who are in their early 50's. Some of them died in their early 50's because of heart complaints, but these complaints were not accepted by the medical profession as being due to war causes. What would cause this kind of complaint in such a case? Surely the experience during the war of such treatment as I have described would affect their systems and bring on heart complaints or nervous complaints which would affect their lives eventually. I appeal to the Minister and to the departmental officers to consider this matter again. The people I am talking about do not wish to be placed on the T.P.I, rate. They want to work, but in the areas in which they live they cannot find suitable jobs, although they try hard. In every case that I know of in my electorate they have tried hard to find suitable work. I found that they worked for at least three weeks and were then back in hospital again, put out on the labour market again and then had again to seek a suitable job. But such jobs are not available in that area, and these people cannot be expected to pack up and leave just like that.

There are quite a number of anomalies that could have been cleaned up. I do not have time to go through the lot. Consider the case of the T.P.I, pensioner. These men are entitled to a lot of concessions, such as free television licences. But after the pensioner's death his widow is not entitled to them. Why? Why has she to pay the full television licence fee and lose the other concessions that she had when he husband was alive? All these anomalies will be brought out later on, but they should have been cleaned up years ago. They do not concern only war widows. I will refer to social service benefits in a short while, if I have time. All these anomalies should have been cleaned up, and to do so would have cost the Government very little.

The other matter I want to talk about refers to Boer War and First World War diggers. I will not harp on this subject, because I spoke on it recently. I have been through our repatriation hospitals and there is accommodation available in them. Extra staff and extra beds would not be required to look after these diggers. All that would be required would be extra food. That is all that would be required to provide free hospitalisation for these men, given to them whether or not their complaints are war caused. Someone said to me recently that this would cause a sorry state in our repatriation hospitals because if any of these men got a boil he would enter hospital. This is not so. These old diggers will not enter hospital unless it is necessary. They are not the type who would seek hospital treatment unless it was necessary. They were a tough crew and they proved this over the years. I do not believe it would cost very much to accede to the request made by the Opposition during the debate on the repatriation legislation recently and provide free hospitalisation for Boer War and World War I diggers. There are not very many of them, and surely they are entitled to this. This is another anomaly that should have been cleaned up by the Government and which would not have cost very much to remove. It would not have meant the provision of extra staff or extra accommodation in the hospitals because sufficient staff and accommodation are already available. After all, a lot of them are passing away every year. I believe the repatriation hospitals could accommodate all Boer War and World War I diggers even if they went in at the same time. It would not overtax their capacity. This is one matter the Government should have considered. These problems may be hard, but why are they not tackled? Why are they pushed aside? There is no justification for that. The departmental heads as well as the Minister are to blame if the problems are not tackled. If a problem is hard it should not be put aside in the " too hard " basket. That is all very well and it has been done before; it was done during war time. But somebody has to tackle these problems sometime, so why not now? I think that the Boer War diggers and the World War I diggers should be accommodated in our repatriation hospitals for all ailments, whether due to war causes or not.

There are also a lot of anomalies in our social services. It was strange to hear the honorable member for Bowman (Dr. Gibbs) talk about the lifting of the means test - after 16 years. Why has not the Government done already something about lifting the means test? I believe it should be lifted completely. People who are earning more than a stipulated figure could be placed in the taxation field. They would not be free of tax. They could come into the tax field and in this way they would not be a burden on the country.

The anomaly that I consider to be worst of all so far as social services are concerned is in respect of the wife of the individual who has turned 65 years of age. Most industries and most companies have a superannuation scheme which obliges employees to retire at 65 years. But some do not receive any superannuation benefit because the scheme came into operation too late for them to be able to participate. They retire on the age pension. Quite a few in my electorate are in that situation. Unfortunately, if the wife of the retired man has not reached 60 years of age she is the one who suffers. If she is 57 years of age she has three years fo wait before she may receive the age pension. Apparently she is expected to go out and work. After a woman has been a housewife for 30 or 40 years, does the Government expect her to humiliate herself by taking in washing or ironing? What else can she do? She is not trained for anything else. If her husband is in receipt of the pension but she is not, they cannot live on the one pension and so, after looking after her husband for 30 or 40 years, she has to go out to work or take in washing and ironing. This is a disgraceful situation which should have been corrected long ago.

Surely a woman who has been married for all those years should not have to suffer the humiliation of having to take in washing and ironing. She cannot do any other work. It is no good saying that if she had been a school teacher 40 years ago she could go back to teaching. As a teacher she would be useless. If she had been a nurse before she married she could not go back into that profession after 40 years absence. All she can do is look for washing and ironing. This is the penalty she has to pay for being less than 60 years of age when her husband retires. This situation should have been cleaned up long ago as it is one of the worst anomalies. There are quite a few others that 1 have not time to deal with. I ask the Minister to look into this question. If a woman has kept house for her husband for all those years - I do not care if a limit of 30 or 40 years is put on it - surely she is entitled to receive the age pension at the same time as her husband becomes entitled to the benefit so that she is not forced to humiliate herself by going out to do washing and ironing.

talk.start.para: .- In dealing with social services I should like to highlight three matters which were introduced by the Government in the recent legislation. The first is the removal of the nationality provisions which until this time required a person to be a naturalised British subject before he could obtain social service benefits. Under the new provisions, even though persons are aliens, if they satisfy the residential period of 10 years and otherwise satisfy the means test they become eligible for the benefit without having to be naturalised.

speech.para: The second matter to which I refer is the increase in the earning capacity of eligible pensioners in respect of dependent children. This reacts favorably particularly for the class A widow. The provision increases her permissible earning capacity for each child from $1 to $3 per week. In the case of the civilian class A widow with two dependent children, one who has two children at school and is able to go out to work, she can now receive $34.50 per week virtually tax free without affecting her pension. She can now receive her base rate pension of $13, for both children she can receive the allowance of $3, the mother's allowance of $4 and child endowment of $1.50, which is $21.50 tax free. Then she is able to earn a permissible income for herself of $7 and now, for the two children, $6 per week which enables her to have a total weekly income of $34.50. She is eligible also for medical and pharmaceutical benefits, as well as concessions from the Postmaster-General's Department and State Government travel concessions. The Federal basic wage, following the recent increase of $2 per week, now stands at $32.80. So it will be seen from the example 1 have stated that a class A widow can now, from all sources, obtain $1.70 in excess of the Federal basic wage. As I have pointed out, most of this is tax free.

The third matter .hat I would like to highlight in respect of so;;al services is the extension of the Aged Persons Homes Act to enable religious _nJ charitable organisations which are registered v/i.h the Department or the hospital a.-.d ciarit.es departments of the various Suites to receive a capital grant- to enable them to erect buildings to be" used as nursing homes for the aged sick. One of the great deserts in our welfare work as a government undoubtedly has been brought about by the aged sick living longer and having to go to private nursing homes for custodial care and their families having to support them. Most of the nursing homes, in my State anyway, charge in the vicinity of $45 to S50 per week, which has put them beyond the means of a person receiving the normal pension, even with the Commonwealth Government subsidy of $14 per week. This extension of the provisions will be of great benefit in future in housing and providing custodial care for our aged sick.

Turning from social services to service pensions, I am rather concerned about the operation of the general rate war pension. This benefit is now paid to ex-servicemen for war caused disabilities and runs in 10 per cents, up to the 100 per cent. rate. The pension is paid to them as a compensation for their disabilities which have been adjudged by the tribunals as war caused. This amount is paid not in a lump sum but as a pension. Nevertheless it is compensation for war caused disabilities. It is not taxable and it is inviolable at law. Nobody who sues a Service pensioner can attach the pension. Yet, when an ex-serviceman's finances are at their lowest ebb so that he has to apply for a service pension, this war pension is included in the means test as income and affects his entitlement for a service pension.

I shall cite the example of two single men, both 65 years of age, one a civilian pensioner and the other an ex-serviceman. For the sake of the example, both have the $4,040 in extra property. The serviceman cannot claim the civilian pension or $13 beceause he is receiving the 100 per cent, general rate of $13 which is compensation for his war caused disabilities. He is in an adverse position when compared with the civilian who has no such compensation but can receive a social service benefit of $13 per week for which the ex-serviceman is not eligible.

I shall cite another example of the man in receipt of a 10 per cent, or 20 per cent, w.ir pension whose war caused disabilities get worse. He goes to his repatriation medical officers, the specialist examines him and they upgrade him from 10 per cent, or 20 per cent, to 50 per cent. This is the man who has been receiving a part service pension, less the amount of his general rate war pension of 10 per cent, or 20 per cent, which is now increased to 50 per cent. He cannot do as much work because his disabilities are worse, yet he receives no more money because the increase is set off against the balance of his service pension. This is a grave injustice to him. I: is inequitable and it is discriminating against those who have put service above self. In New Zealand the general rale war pension is not included as income in the means test applied for social service pensions. Nor do we in Australia take into account general rate war pensions so far as unemployment and sickness benefits are concerned. Permanent military personnel who retire on an invalidity pension are assessed under the Defence Forces Retirment Benefits Act and have only the amount they earn taken into account. Their civil income is taken into account in grading their incapacity. We do not take their general rate war pension into account in this case, but we do take it into account when a returned ex-serviceman is at his lowest financial ebb and wants to apply for a service pension. It has been estimated that the cost of exempting those now receiving part general rate war pensions from the income means test for service pensions would be $3.12 million a year.

talk.start.para: - That is a small cost to do a just action.

- That is so. I feel that there is an argument against it, and I shall deal with it. It is argued that if this is done it will be possible for a man to receive a source of pension of $13 a week, and this, with the $13 100 per cent, war pension, would bring him into conflict with the intermediate pension and the T.P.I, pension. If this is true then, I suggest that a percentage of the war pension should be exempted from the income means test. If, say, 75 per cent, were exempt, then the man on a 40 per cent, war pension would have an exemption of 30 per cent, of the pension, and so on up the scale. 1 have taken 75 per cent, just for the purposes of my argument, but the percentage could be tailored so that there would be no impinging on the T.P.I, and intermediate rates. If the suggestion were adopted, it would mean that returned soldiers from all wars, not merely the Boer War and World War I, who were in need and who applied for and received part service pensions would also get free hospitalisation and free medical benefits not only for was caused disabilities but also for non war caused disabilities. This would not be discriminatory in the way that the recent Opposition amendment to the Repatriation Bill would have been. It would be based on need. There would not be an indiscriminate benefit, to be enjoyed by people who had money, as would have 'been the case had the amendment to the Repatriation Bill been adopted. My suggestion would give needy people eligibility to full hospitalisation and medical treatment once they became entitled to a part service pension.

speech.para: I come now to another group in the community about whom I am concerned. I refer to the fixed income superannuatants. Rising costs with no cost of living adjustments have put many of these people in a worse position than recipients of social service benefits. Something has got to be done to relieve them. Some people advocate taxation concessions, but I think that partial exemption of their superannuation from the means test would be the answer. If the first $10 a week of superannuation were exempted, these people would at least get some compensation for the fact that they were on low fixed incomes, for which they contributed many years ago when money had a different value. Then there is the question of the permissible income. This is now set at $7 a week. It has been set at that amount for 12 years now. I think this should be increased to $10 a week.

The honorable member for Scullin (Mr. Peters) is interjecting. I have not a great deal of time, and I wish to refer now to the abolition, not of the honorable member for Scullin but of the means test. This has been freely advocated in this chamber. The revised estimate of the cost of abolishing the means test is $340 million a year, plus the consequent increase in medical benefit costs. 1 invite the Committee to think of the present members of the community in terms of three groups - those presently over 60 years of age. those presently over 40 years of age and those presently over 20 years of age. Those in the first group - those over 60 years of age - have had difficult times. They have been through two wars and a depression. They have had no superannuation schemes and life assurance has not been attractive or of great benefit to them. They have had low wages and therefore no ability to provide for their retirement. It is this group that we generally think of when we talk of the abolition of the means test.

The second group, those presently over 40, have had better opportunities than the first group. They have had better wage conditions, better superannuation schemes, long service leave, a better chance for life assurance, and the benefit of postwar progress over the last 25 years of their working life. The third group, those presently over 20 years of age, are in an affluent society, enjoy top wage conditions, the extension of superannuation schemes and cost of living adjustments. The majority of these people should be able to provide for their retirement 20 or 30 years hence.

So that when we think of this question of the abolition of the means test we should realise that it is the first group about whom we are thinking. But if we abolish it, we abolish it also for the second and third groups. In fact, we abolish it for all posterity. This is a quite unscientific and unrealistic approach to the problem. I think that we have to introduce a compulsory national superannuation scheme, as advocated by the honorable member for Sturt (Sir Keith Wilson), with contributions based on a percentage of the wages earned and with payments being made at age 70, reducing later perhaps to age 65. The pension would be a percentage of the average wage earned over the last five years of working life. I submit that it is necessary to retain the present form of social service benefits in order to cover the people in group 1 and the needy minority in the second group to which I have referred. There would be but very few in the third group.
Before I conclude I should like to pay a tribute to the honorable member for Sturt who has been chairman of the Government

Members Social Services Committee from 1955 up to the present time. He will be retiring from this Parliament at the end of this session. He is a man who has dedicated himself to social services. He has given not only of his time but also of his money in promoting the establishment of cottage schemes for the aged in his own State. He has suggested many innovations in the field of social services which have been accepted by this Parliament. I pay tribute to him and wish him health and happiness in his retirement.

talk.start.para: . - Shortly after I was elected to this Parliament in May 1955, the late Sir Earle Page, who was then Minister for Health, introduced a rigid means test for pharmaceutical and medical benefits for age and invalid pensioners. Up to its abolition in 1965, not one member of the Government parties ever protested about this iniquitous means test. It was abolished only after continual hammering for 10 years by the members of the Opposition. I advocated its abolition year after year. All that it cost was something less than $3 million. It took the Government 10 years to undertake, at a cost of $3 million. This gives some idea of the sincerity of those members on the Government side who talk about the abolition of the means test.

speech.para: No doubt what they do is take extracts from their speeches as reported in "Hansard", and have them published in the local newspaper. When their constituents read these extracts they think their member is doing a marvellous job in trying to have the means test abolished. But when it comes to voting in the House on these particular matters, what happens?

talk.start.para: - That is the real test.

- That is the real test, as the honorable member for Hindmarsh says. What happens when it comes to the real test? Before relating my remarks to the estimates for the Department of Social Services, I should like to take this opportunity of commending the officers of that Department for their efficiency and the courtesy they extend to me whenever I make representations on behalf of my constituents on matters relating to all aspects of social ser vices. I am sure that all other honorable members will agree with me that they are most efficient.

speech.para: During 1964-65, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Accounts, of which I am honoured to be Vice-Chairman, conducted an inquiry into this Department in conformity with the Audit Act. I might add that I was very impressed by the competency of the officers who appeared before us. From time to time, certain sections of the Press and the general community seem to take pride in knocking the ability and efficiency of our Public Service. I certainly do not agree with them. I believe that the public servants in general are comparable with if not better than many servants of private enterprise.

In referring to social services, I take honorable members back to the general election campaign of December 1949 when the former Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, gave a solemn promise that a Liberal-Country Party Government would maintain the full value of social service benefits and appoint a special committee to inquire into the means test with a view to its abolition. Neither promise was honoured, as I shall now proceed to show. 1 shall deal first with child endowment. Let us compare the purchasing power of this benefit in relation to the average basic wage of $13.20 a week in July 1950- the time when the Menzies Government introduced endowment for the first child - with its purchasing power in relation to the present average basic wage of $32.80 a week. In 1950, the endowment of 50c a week for one child was 3.79 per cent, of the basic wage. The same percentage of the basic wage of today is $1.25. So the loss in purchasing power is 75c. A family with two children received in endowment $1.50 a week, or 11.36 per cent, of the basic wage, in 1950. The same percentage of today's basic wage represents $3.70. The loss is $2.20. In 1950, a family with three children received endowment of $2.50 a week, or 18.94 per cent, of the basic wage. The same percentage of the current basic wage represents $6.20. So the loss is $3.70. A family with four children received endowment totalling $3.50 a week, or 26.51 per cent, of the basic wage, in 1950. The same percentage of the present basic wage represents $8.70. The loss is $5.20. Endowment for five children totalled S4.50 a week, or 34.09 per cent, of the basic wage, in 1950. The same percentage of the current basic wage represents Si 1.10. The loss is $6.60.

talk.start.para: - Are these figures based on official statistics?

- They are. Endowment for a family of six children totalled $5.50 a week, or 41.66 per cent, of the basic wage, in 1950. The same percentage of today's basic wage represents $13.70. So the loss is S8.20. These figures amply and forcibly illustrate the manner in which mothers have been cheated by the failure of this and preceding Liberal-Australian Country Party Governments to implement the promise made in 1949 to maintain full value in social service benefits, lt is interesting to note that recently various authorities have expressed concern at the decrease in the birthrate in Australia over the last two or three years, lt has been said, inter alia, that the pill is largely responsible or that some parents are too busy enjoying themselves to bother about raising families. I do not accept those reasons, Mr. Deputy Chairman. I believe that the major contributing factor is that breadwinners in the lower income brackets, for economic reasons, find it impossible to raise families of average size. Furthermore, many scores of thousands of housewives go to work from sheer necessity because the husband's wage is insufficient to meet normal weekly commitments. Everyone is aware of the enormous cost of special infants' foods and of the high cost of clothes, shoes and school accessories for growing children. The basic solution for this appalling situation rests with this Government. If the Prime Minister (Mr. Harold Holt) refuses to accept the responsibility for remedying the situation, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) certainly will accept it.

speech.para: I shall now deal with the maternity allowance, which is more popularly known as the baby bonus. The monetary value of this benefit has remained unaltered since 1 949, despite the fact that the average basic wage has increased by 148 per cent., from $13.20 to $32.80, as I pointed out earlier. In assessing the real value of the maternity allowance, let us consider this fact: The Liberal-Country Party Government in New South Wales and the Liberal Government in Victoria have recently steeply increased hospital charges, ls it any wonder tha; the birthrate is falling? Scores of thousands of young married couples are eager and willing to raise families of average size but are prevented by poor economic circumstances from doing so. It is true th-t we are expanding our population by the admission each year of many migrants, all of whom are welcome. 1 believe that it is equally important, by putting real value into child endowment and the maternity allowance, to assist and encourage our young couples to raise our birthrate. 1 turn now to the funeral benefit. This was introduced by the Curtin Government in July 1943, the amount then payable being $20. At that time, the basic wage stood at $9.50 a week. So the benefit was then equivalent to 222 per cent, of the average basic wage. The only alteration in the benefit occurred in 1965 when it was extended by allowing a pensioner who is responsible for the burial of a spouse or another pensioner benefit at the rate of $40. This sum represents only 122 per cent, of the present basic wage of $32.80. The ordinary rate of $20 represents only 61 per cent, of the present basic wage, compared to 222 per cent, of the basic wage of 1943.

I wish now to deal with the merged means test, with specific reference to the permissible income of $7 a week for a single pensioner or $14 a week for a pensioner married couple. These limits of permissible income were last adjusted in 1954. It is interesting to note that in that year the base rate of pension was $7 a week for a single pensioner and $14 a week for a pensioner married couple. In 1954, the permissible income equalled the base rate of pension. The base rates are now $13 a week for a single pensioner and $ 1 1 .75 a week for a pensioner married couple. Despite the great increase in the rates of pension since 1954, the permissible income remains the same. This is most unfair to superannuitants. They have paid both ways. During their working days, they paid taxes and they also contributed to superannuation. Yet they are denied justice when they go into retirement. This situation ought to be rectified immediately, lt has been suggested on both sides of the chamber that the means test should be liberalised step by step until it is completely abolished.

I may be like Daniel entering the lions' den, but I want to protest at the discrimination against Australian rules football in the Territory of Papua and New Guinea, I regard this as a very serious
- Hear, hear!

talk.start.para: - Who supplies the free equipment?

It is interesting to know that the Victorian Football League, which might be called the landlord of Australian rules, often invites New Guineans to Melbourne towards the end of the football season, paying their fares and board while they are in Melbourne, so that they may study Australian rules in action. speech.para: I wonder if there are agents of rugby and soccer entrenched in the Department of Territories, committed, James Bond like, to strangling Australian rules in its infancy. talk.start.para: - Is this the only thing wrong with the administration of the Territory?

Could the Minister, with his rugged exterior, be the James Bond of the rugby and soccer fans and promoters? - I am listening attentively but I do not think the Minister is missing much.

- 1 hope the Minister is not missing anything, because I do not want to have to repeat myself. After all, a code which is dominant in Tasmania, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia and which has pockets df support in New South Wales, Canberra and even

speech.para: Queensland, is worthy of treatment from this Government equal to that accorded rugby and soccer.

But if my information is correct, this Government, the Department and the Minister have something to answer for. Behind his easy going and affable exterior he may be a James Bond of the worst type, sabotaging Australian rules in New Guinea. We of the southern States face him squarely tonight. I wish he were here to answer my charge before we pass these estimates in about two hours time. Let us know for sure what is going on in New Guinea. We all admire the physique of the people of the Territory. They are wonderful sportsmen. They are great athletes. I do not think any code - here th honorable member for Indi (Mr. Holten) will support me, I am sure - gives greater scope for brains, ability, stamina, strength, courage, tenacity'-

. - I do not want to follow Oddjob entirely in this debate. There are serious matters under consideration. I hope that this is the last time that the estimates for the Northern Territory will appear in their present form. If honorable members will look at the printed document, they will see that, in round figures, $29 million is provided for the Northern Territory, but the detail covers four and a half pages. We provide $71 million for Papua and New Guinea and most of it is dealt with in one line. Of the $71 million, $70 million is dealt with in one line. What is being done in regard to New Guinea is right; what is being done in regard to the Northern Territory is wrong. It is absolutely wrong for the detailed estimates for the Northern Territory to be set down in a way that deprives the Legislative Council of the Territory, as a partly elective body, of all control or authority over details and in a way that hampers and inhibits the efficiency of the Administration.

speech.para: The Northern Territory, as honorable members know, is subject to a heavy monsoon. Virtually no public works can be undertaken out of doors during December, January, February, March and probably most of April. If the authorities wait for their budget, their construction season is compressed uneconomically; it is distorted. I know that the present Administrator of the Northern Territory, a man for whom everybody in the Parliament has the highest respect, has tried to cure this state of affairs. 1 know that he has extorted some kind of flexibility from the central administration, and good luck to him for having done so. But still it is bad in principle that we in this Parliament should lay down detailed estimates for the Northern Territory, instead of acting sensibly, as we do for Papua and New Guinea, and putting them all in one line. 1 do not suggest that the Legislative Council of the Northern Territory should have full authority for the expenditure of the money, lt is not ready for that full authority yet. 1 should think that any expenditure should be subject to a report to this Parliament in a form that our own Public Accounts Committee might conveniently settle, so that prompt and effective information would be available to this Parliament.
