I believe that all moneys spent should be subject to the authority of the Administrator, who in turn is responsible to the Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes). However, I believe that we should try gradually to transfer authority to the Legislative Council in Darwin by giving it not executive but advisory authority, so that the Administrator can call the members of the Council, particularly elected members, into consultation. I think the formal control of expenditure should remain with this Parliament while we are providing most of the revenue; but without relinquishing the formal control of expenditure, we could gradually transfer real authority to the Legislative Council in Darwin so that it can determine the way in which money is spent in the Northern Territory, lt should act first in an advisory capacity, subject, of course, to the veto of the Minister, just as is done with Papua and New Guinea. lt would gradually take on more and more authority. 1 believe that we should be making a conscious effort, though it it not necessary to go too fast, to build up the authority of the Legislative Council in Darwin.

talk.start.para: - What about acceptance of local government responsibility first?

- The honorable member makes a very practical suggestion. I will not have time to canvass it, but perhaps he will enlarge on it in the course of this debate. I should think that one thing we should be doing is to bring in a one line budget for the Northern Territory, leave to the Administrator full formal authority for the expenditure, and ask the Administrator to rely more and more on the advice of the elected members of the Legislative Council in Darwin, thus gradually building up the authority and prestige of the Legislative Council of the Northern Territory. There would be a good by-product of this, because, by so doing, we would avoid the distortions of expenditure which at present, regrettably, despite the best efforts of the Administrator, are taking place in the Northern Territory as a result of the peculiar position of the monsoon, which shuts down public works in the period of a few months around Christmas. 1 put this to the Minister as something that is overdue and should be done.

speech.para: I would like to deal with a second matter in relation to the Northern Territory. We must consider the position of the Aboriginal people, who form the largest part of the permanent residents in the Northern Territory. We must consider their interests in what is done. I know that this is a very difficult matter. A good deal of painful adjustment is inevitable in the implementation of the Government's policy of full wages for Aboriginals. I think the Government's policy is right. The Government advocated this policy and the court accepted it, perhaps with too great delays, although this is not the kind of thing I want to stress particularly. The Government's objective of full wages for Aboriginals in the Northern Territory is correct. Nevertheless, the transition period will cause great difficulties and we should have a much more constructive scheme to meet them. Let me say also that these difficulties may be accentuated by the inevitable increase of fencing in the

Northern Territory. This will change the method of working from the open range to the fenced paddocks and thus change the requirement for the peculiar skills that the Aboriginal stockmen at present exhibit. Coming at this time, this will accentuate the difficulties of transition. These are practical problems. I will not have time now to deal with any more than the most sketchy of outlines, but I will say that there are grave difficulties ahead. They are difficulties that can be overcome by goodwill and constructive policy and I am confident that the Government will exhibit both these qualities.

Let me say something about the Aboriginal reserves in the Northern Territory, particularly Arnhem Land, which is by far the biggest of the reserves. Arnhem Land is undeveloped as yet. Contrary to the impression that is generally held, it is likely to be very rich in both pastoral and mineral potential. Its mineral potential, except for Gove, is still not established. As honorable members will probably know, the Western Nuclear company is conducting a survey at the present moment. The geological nature of Arnhem Land is such that it is likely that good deposits will be hard to find, but will be big when they are found. I will not take time to elaborate on this, but there are technical reasons for the statement I have made.

There is great pastoral potential there, too, but I am not in favour of relinquishing the Aboriginals' right and title to this land. It may be that in certain parts there will be mining or other special development. If this is so I ask the Government to do a great deal more than it has done up to date to preserve the rights of the Aboriginals. The so called special royalties, and things of that character, are of a quite derisory nature: They do not meet the position at all. Arnhem Land should be thought of as belonging to the Aboriginals, and should be exploited for the interests of the Aboriginals primarily and of nobody else. The Government should rethink a little its policy in this regard. I would consider, for example, that if a company is established to mine in Arnhem Land, or to develop a pastoral property, at least one quarter of the ordinary shares should be reserved for the benefit of Aboriginals. Furthermore, a place on the company's board should be kept for an Aboriginal, even though in this transition period it might be necessary ;o have a church or some other body acting as a trustee in the place on that board. I feel that this is the least we could do. Something like this would be far better than the quite small so called extra royalties that are provided in the foreshadowed contracts.

I know - and the Minister will agree with me I am sure - that there are difficulties regarding the ownership of tribal lands. I do not think these difficulties are insurmountable, although they do exist, but I ask that Arnhem Land and the other reserves should be considered primarily as reserves to be used for the benefit of the Aboriginals of the Northern Territory. Any policy which is not keyed to this primary objective is an inadequate policy. I do not believe that at present there should be open access to these reserves. I say this with a great deal of doubt, but I still feel that this is correct. No Aboriginal, of course, should be kept on a reserve: Every Aboriginal on a reserve should be free to leave it when he wants to and to return to it whenever he wants to .do so, but for the present this area should be kept for the Aboriginals as a refuge in this very difficult state of transition in which they are at present placed.

I recently spent four or five weeks in the bush in Arnhem Land and I have seen something of the missions and the stations surrounding them. I have seen something of the Aboriginals who are living there. I believe that we can approach this in a way that will be to their advantage and which will give them a greater measure of initiative, self reliance and authority, because these people must have restored to them the feeling that they are the owners. This is a psychological problem. They must be given back the pride of ownership, and this I think we have perhaps failed to do.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

. - I should like to speak on the estimates for the Territory of Papua and New Guinea. It seems to me rather disturbing that so few honorable members are here when these estimates are being considered. Much as I can sympathise with my colleague, the honorable member for Wilmot (Mr. Duthie), about whether Australian rules football ought to be played in Papua and New Guinea, I must confess to being somewhat of a heretic in respect of Australian Rules, because I have not seen a game played this year in what is probably the headquarters of that great game. However, with respect to Papua and New Guinea we are considering the problems of more than two million people - more people than in any State of Australia with the exception of Victoria and New South Wales. I believe - and 1 am sure my party does too - that anybody irrespective of the colour of his skin, is as good as anybody else and should be given the same opportunity to improve or to evolve as we have been given.

speech.para: I must say with all respect to the Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes) that 1 was rather disturbed by an answer he gave to a question about wages in Papua and New Guinea. He said that if the Papua and New Guinea Administration wanted to increase the wages and salaries it had to find the increase out of its own Budget. I draw the attention of the Committee to a rather interesting document which has never been debated fully in this place, despite its importance. 1 refer to the report of the World Bank on the economic development of Papua and New Guinea. I have cited these figures before. In the roneoed edition of the report is an estimate for the year 1962-63, which is four years ago, of the gross national product of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea. I point out again that Papua and New Guinea has a population of more than two million people, about one sixth of the population of Australia. The figures in the report are measured in pounds Australian because the conversion to dollars had not then taken place. If we take what is called the monetary sector and the subsistence sector the gross national product of Papua and New Guinea in 1962-63 was A146 million, or in round figures $A300 million. When that is related to our gross national product as it then was - somewhere in the region of 15,000 million - it represents about one fiftieth. This was to support a population about one sixth of Australia's population, lt shows the disparity of income levels between Australia and Papua and New Guinea as roughly of the order of about 10 to 1. When we analyse the figures further as between what we call the monetary sector and the subsistence sector the disparity is greater even than that. Between the poorest persons in Papua and New Guinea and the richest persons in Australia the disparity is probably 20 to 30 times to 1. This surely is the proportion of the problem that faces Australia in relation to Papua and New Guinea.

The problem is not disposed of in terms of the very small sum that we allocate out of our Budget. The Government may claim that it is spending more now than any other government ever spent. So it should. I suggest that in the years ahead it will have to spend a great deal more. I do not think that we in this country realise the obligations that we have to this particular piece of the earth. It is an area twice the size of Victoria and, as 1 have stated previously, it has a population greater than that of any State of Australia except Victoria and New South Wales. In many respects it has been regarded in the past as having some strategic significance as far as Australia is concerned but I doubt whether, in terms of 1966, it has anything like that strategic significance any more. However, we in Australia have at least some moral obligation to this part of the world. 1 often think that if we faced up to our obligations we. could make ourselves a pilot scheme for raising the standards of this particular area. Some few months ago we had in Canberra meeting of the Interparliamentary Union which was attended by representatives from approximately 50 other countries. 1 was a delegate to that conference and had the opportunity to address it. I said then that I thought that nowhere yet has there been an example of what might be called a subsistence economy which has been able, in a measurable period, to lift itself from the subsistence standard to a standard near that of the more advanced parts of the world. It should be recognised in Australia that New Guinea is a subsistence economy, lt is beset by the same kinds of difficulties as beset subsistence economies anywhere else.

From Australia's point of view there are two difficulties, namely that the area and geographical problems of the Territory are much greater than those of any similar place. In many respects New Guinea is what almost may be called geography's joke. Whereas in Australia our problem is a shortage of water, in New Guinea the problem is a super-abundance of water in terms of population and geography. Anyone who knows the area is aware of the difficulty involved in constructing a road from, say, Port Moresby to Lae, a distance of only a couple of hundred miles over which one can fly in an hour or two. To construct such a road would be one of the hardest road building tasks in the world. No-one wants to construct a road because the population which would be served by it is relatively small. However, somehow in the next few years Australia must make a breakthrough in this very important problem.

It disturbs me, I must confess, to see how little interest this House is showing in this problem at the present time. It may well be that because this is election year and in a few weeks we will go to the hustings honorable members are not bothered very much about it. However, the point is that Australia can do better with Papua and New Guinea than anyone else can. Fortunately, I think, for Australia the Papuans and New Guineans think the same thing. It ill behoves us to be complacent about the continuance of such circumstances. Whichever party becomes the government of this country for the next three years - if I may be political at this stage, I hope there will be a change of government - I believe that much greater attention will need to be paid to the problems of Papua and New Guinea than has been the case in the past few years.

I think we are getting on top of the health problem there, and once we get on top of the health problem we bring upon the population what is called death control - we limit the rate at which people die. However, at the other end of the line we still have the problem of birth control. It is estimated that by the year 2000, which is only 34 years from now, Papua and New Guinea probably will have four million people. By that time, in terms of numbers and of world attitudes, the problem will be much greater and much more significant than it is in 1966. I believe that politically we must always think in terms of 20 years ahead rather than in terms of 20 months ahead. I doubt whether the estimates that are now before us are thinking of Papua and New Guinea in terms of 1986 rather than in terms of 1968. That is unfortunate.

We are, for the time being, custodians of that area and, as I have said, I believe that primarily our obligations are economic, social and moral. The people of the Territory still regard us as their friends. Within the next few months, and certainly within the next few years, there probably will be a good deal of argument as to their political evolution. It is pretty difficult to translate what we call democratic processes to what have been fairly primitive areas in the past. Even in this Parliament we argue in 1966 whether the institutions we have had for 60 years are satisfactory, yet in essence we try to perpetrate upon the Territory the same kind of institutions. The Territory is having its growing pains and will continue to have them, but at least it seems to me that there is at present a bank, if you like, of goodwill towards Australia. Just as I believe that Australia can best develop its own area, so do I believe that Australia, in association with the native population of Papua and New Guinea, can best develop the Territory for the benefit of its people.

Sometimes it is suggested that if we do not develop our own northern areas someone else will come in and develop them for us. I am one who believes that with the proper application of capital, technology and skills in the right places we can do better with our own country than anyone else can. Equally, I believe that the goodwill Australia feels towards the Territory must be backed by more than kind thoughts. It must be backed by physical application - primarily money. But money only purchases technology and skills. There must be an application of technology and skills in far greater measure in the immediate few years than there has been in the past if we are to develop the area.

As I have said, the Government that is in power in the next Parliament, of whatever political persuasion, will have to make much greater allocations of money to these areas than are shown in the estimates now before us. I trust that in the next Parliament more time and more consideration will be given to the fundamental problems of something more than two million people, each of whom is entitled to as good a go in the world as any Australian is.

A great deal has been said about the investment of overseas capital in the Northern Territory, but it is generally forgotten that the land is held on leasehold only. An example of what has happened to properties in the Territory is to be found at Brunette Downs, which is held by a company in which Australian and American capital has been subscribed. Brunette Downs has been transformed in the last five years from a property that sent off cattle in forward store to fat condition, only at 4 to 5 years, and mostly walked them, to one that is today turning off fat cattle as three year olds by road. The changes have not all been made simply because of the good management of the company I refer to, but have been due also to some extent to the improvements in communications and

There has been a general realisation of what can be done in the higher rainfall areas of the Northern Territory by means mainly of Townsville lucerne, but also of other legumes and pasture plants. While I am on this point I may say that I hope the Government will see fit to provide people who are trying to improve these areas with superphosphate at the prices prevailing at the northern Queensland ports. This will enable Northern Territory properties to carry a great many more cattle, and to carry them in a way different from that which prevails today. The Northern Territory suffered more than any other area in Australia from war damage and I am sure that nobody would be more alive to the wisdom of defending Australia from somewhere outside Australia than the Territorians.

Now I come to New Guinea. I have said that great changes have taken place in the Northern Territory, but I venture to suggest that nowhere have greater changes taken place than in New Guinea in the last 20 years. We must remember that half the population of Papua and New Guinea, both of which are under the jurisdiction of Australia, had never seen a European until 1930 and had never seen a wheel of any kind until an aeroplane landed near where Goroka now is in 1 935, and had never seen an animal larger than their domestic pigs until 1 938, which is only 28 years ago. These people, who occupy some of the richest agricultural land in New Guinea, have been taken from the stone age and plunged into the atomic age in less than two generations. It is true that although they remain to a great extent unsophisticated politically, they have a tremendous amount of basic wisdom. They are people with very sound philosophies built on a system of living that they have developed for some hundreds of years at least. They are agriculturalists who live in small groups. In the past they have been mutually afraid and suspicious of one another. Modern society is something that cannot be thrust on them in a limited length of time.

This is a rich area where considerable expansion in agriculture has taken place and also some expansion in animal husbandry in the cattle industry. It is against the background that I have outlined. with half ;he population being somewhat backward so far as civilisation is concerned, that it is fair to measure our progress and what we have done for the Territories since the last war. Anybody who saw the country in 1945 will remember the devastated condition that it was in, even though development previously had been very limited. To see it now one would hardly recognise it as the same country. Great things have been done there. A big hydro-electric scheme is being carried out. Roads run from Mount Hagen to Goroka through some of the rich land that I have referred to. Roads are being put through the Markham and Ramu Valleys. There will be a road right from Lae to Madang which will open up excellent areas. The economy which was originally based very largely on gold and copper has now been expanded and diversified to include such things as coffee, tea, timber and cattle.

A great deal has been said about the exploitation of this country by European people, but I would like to mention two notable happenings. The Bulolo Gold Dredging Company was one of the first companies to operate in New Guinea. The company has slightly more than 50 per cent, outside capital and nearly 50 per cent. Australian capital. Having made great profits out of gold in the Bulolo Valley it might well have chosen to leave the Territory. Instead it diversified its activities and commenced to operate in the timber industry. It has started another notable enterprise on the Leron Plains, about 80 miles from Lae. It took over 25,000 acres of land which was unused and virtually unusable except to a very minor degree by the natives. The natives did not want it. I might explain that land in these Territories is used by Europeans only if the natives do not want it. The company bought a lease of the land and fenced 25,000 acres, 16,000 acres of which is put to use. It is fenced into small paddocks. The company has put in several sets of first class cattle yards and water facilities and it has improved the property in such a way that unless one compared it with what might be termed over-improved properties it would compare with any property in Australia so far as improvements are concerned. It now carries 4,000 cattle on country that has considerable pasture improvement, and a gre: deal of experimentation is being carried out at no cost to the Government. This is all being done by the Bulolo Gold Dredging Company for the purpose of supplying its employees at the timber mills, both Europeans and indigenes, with cheaper meat.

Another example of what private enterprise is doing is provided by a retired Victorian businessman and pastoralist who went to New Guinea in 1960. He has studied the tea industry around the world and has taken up 1,000 acres of what was swamp land near Mount Hagen and has so far spent half a million dollars on it. This area is about to come into production. So the European residents are not, as is so often represented, only exploiters of the Territory. Most of them have deep roots in the Territory and have deep affection for the indigenous people. This is reciprocated in most cases. But the Territorians do have a marked awareness of the great dangers facing their security, and therefore Australia's security.

All these facts are rather overshadowed by the Territory's uncertainty about its political future. It is this fact, and not any lack in sense of service, that is today causing many excellent types of young men in the administration to feel that their future, and the future of their families, will be jeopardised if they remain in the area. We are doing something about education for the Territorians but we must do more. Advances have been made in this regard - there is no doubt about that - by the Government and by mission schools, so far as primary and secondary education is concerned. Higher education is being undertaken. But it is very doubtful whether the responsibilities of democratic government could be fully undertaken by the people of the Territory for at least another two generations - very doubtful indeed.

It is rather odd that most of the countries which are pressing for Australia to set a time for self government for the Territory of Papua and New Guinea are those which have certainly not embraced democracy as we know it when they themselves gained self government. Australia simply cannot afford to have an insecure political situation in Papua and New Guinea, as that country is one of the keys to our security. I say unhesitatingly that what Australia has done in Papua and New Guinea is something of which we have great reason to be proud. It is a record of great achievement and great development. The establishment of mutual trust between Europeans and indigenous people that exists in the Territory is seldom equalled, and is unsurpassed, anywhere in the world. This spirit of mutual trust and dependence is particularly marked in the relationship between officers of the Administration and the indigenous people. This state of affairs has been concreted only by diligent and valuable service over a long period by the Administration generally. It has not been assisted in any way by the critics who sometimes go to the Territory and have a casual look and who, very often, base their assumptions on a few years knowledge, of a very limited locality. lt is notable that most of the agitation for self government in the Territory at present comes from within Papua. Papua is only sixth in the list of districts in contributions made to the economy of the country. What Australia has done in the Territory is something of which we can be proud. We have made a great contribution, and we must continue to do so in order to build these people up in good time so that they will be able to take their place among the emerging countries of the world.

talk.start.para: .- I would like to say a few words tonight on the development of the Northern Territory cattle industry. The honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Armstrong) mentioned Brunette Downs. I think one must certainly agree with him that Brunette Downs is one of the properties in the Northern Territory where attempts have been made to achieve a level of carrying capacity and turnoff in line with the natural resources. Brunette Downs was, I think, purchased from the White family, the Gulf Cattle Company, in 1958. At that time it was one of the best improved cattle properties, certainly the most improved on the Barkly Tableland and one of the best in the top end of the Northern Territory. Since the American and Australian interests have taken over they have spent, according to the latest figures I saw, about $800,000, principally for property improvements such as fencing, water conservation and the provision of yards, and in the introduction of better blood in the herds.

speech.para: However, the biggest problem facing Brunette Downs is thai facing all major property owners in the Northern Territory, as well as in North Queensland and the Kimberleys - management. The size of the properties is a matter which has been giving people concerned with the administration of the Northern Territory a headache for a long time. In the early days, the days before beef roads and before cattle prices were high, there was justification for big properties. But even 28 years ago it was recognised in the Payne Fletcher report that the days of the large properties such as Alexandria, Brunette Downs, Wave Hill and Victoria River Downs were over. Even in those days it was recognised that there should be progressive policies or subdivision, with the object of settling more people in the Northern Territory.

If one looks at the area from Camooweal to Wyndham what does one find in the way of towns? The biggest town is Elliott and it would probably have no more than 150 to 200 people. It was recognised in 1938 by an honorable member still present in this House that there was need for the commonsense resumption of land, and action to ensure that there would be the maximum number of people occupying this country; that they should have a decent standard of living and be able to attain maximum production from the land. Those points were regarded as the principal factors to bc considered in deciding resumptions. The honorable member I refer to is the Leader of the Australian Country Party today, Mr. McEwen, who was Minister for the Interior from, I think, 1937 to 1939. He recognised in those days that these properties were too large and that the major ones should be divided into smaller areas. What has been done since then? Certainly the properties have got smaller, although Brunette Downs at present covers about 4,700 square miles. Alexandria has just been broken up into three smaller properties and this action, by the Territory Administration, as the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr. McEwen) knows, has been trenchantly criticised throughout Australia. The action of the Administration of the Northern Territory in regard to the subdivision of Alexandria has been criticised. lt was in the late 1940's that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation made a study of the Barkly Tableland area and came to certain conclusions regarding carrying capacity and turnoff. That area has been classified as containing some of the best natural breeding country in Australia. The conclusion reached was that the area would carry a lot more cattle than it does today. This has certainly been highlighted by the various surveys which were carried out in the area with respect to Alexandria, but what do we see? We see, as I said, a decision which has been trenchantly criticised in a number of newspapers in Australia. There is no question that the decision deserves criticism. Alexandria was split up into three more properties - Mount Drummond, Benmara and Mittiebah - and we saw the extraordinary result of Americans winning the ballot at the expense of Australians who had the experience and who had the capital. We saw the other two leases being won by Australians, but I understand that one of them had interests in both leases.

The remarkable thing about the Benmara lease won by Mr. Snyder - I forget the other American, but I think it was Mr. Wise - is that these gentlemen owned also a property of 2,000 square miles close to the Stuart Highway. I agree with those people who have criticised this decision. If there had been no Australians who were capable of developing this area and if there had been no Australians with the necessary finance there would have been a case for allowing overseas interests to be in the ballot; but surely from what I have quoted from the remarks of the Leader of the Australian Country Party in 1938 when he was Minister for the Interior we see that he recognised the importance of subdividing these areas and settling Australians in these areas in times when it was far more difficult than it is today. Yet we see this phenomenon of Americans coming in and winning the ballot.

talk.start.para: - Who changed his policies on Alexandria?

- The Alexandria policy was changed during the war when bombs were literally falling on the Northern Territory and Queensland. But the principle of subdivision was still the same. I have never heard the Leader of the Country Party say anything different from what he said in 1938 because he still believes in commonsense subdivision. I am quite certain that in an open debate he would admit that it is a scandalous thing for Americans to come in here and win the ballots over Australians who have the experience and have the money. These statements have been made throughout northern Australia where the Leader of the Country Party has been challenged to say anything different from what he said at that time. He will not say anything different because he was right when he said that. I have not had time to check the facts and so I am open to correction by the Minister at the table, but my recollection is that one of the reasons given by the Minister in the adjournment debate in support of Americans was that they introduced or were responsible for the introduction to Australia of Santa Gertrudis cattle. I do not know who told the Minister that, but he will find that the Zebus, although not fixed to a true Santa Gertrudis type, were introduced into Australia many years before the Americans came in.
- They were first introduced in 1906.

- The point is that even in the Northern Territory, at Koolpinyah for example, Zebus were being run for years. Let us admit that in certain parts the Americans are doing a good job. I will admit that in certain areas, such as in the Cape York Peninsula area, the American money will do a good job, but I absolutely disagree in principle with Australians not being given a chance to settle this country first. Why are they not given this opportunity? The obvious reason is that the areas are far too big under present conditions. It was said, for example, that we could not settle the brigalow area in small areas, yet this is being done. The Cape York Peninsula area, which is a high rainfall area, is no more difficult than the Northern Territory or other areas. Of course, what the Americans are bringing in is money. They are not bringing in any technical knowhow so let there be no attempt to put that over. There are plenty of Australians who could show the Americans more about cattle in northern Australia than they will ever know. But the point is that the Australians have not the finance and are not given the chance to have the finance under the present system of leasehold conditions in the Northern Territory, the Kimberleys and in the northern parts of Queensland. 1 suggest in the short time available to me that in order to test this point the Northern Territory Administration - I cannot speak of Queensland or the Kimberleys in this debate - should study the methods and principles used in the classification of brigalow lands, using the scientists who are available in land research, the botanist, the ecologist, the climatologist, the geomorphologist and others to work in with the experienced cattle producers to determine what is the best method of subdivision of these areas. On this point we have seen, for example, the beef roads. It has been rightly claimed that practically all the money expended so far on beef road construction has been for the benefit of absentee owners. This, of course, is rather an exaggeration. Nevertheless, certainly the major part in the Northern Territory has been for their benefit. If we forget the two arms from Yuendumu to Alice Springs and Plenty River, certainly the road from Walhallow and Anthony Lagoon down to the Barkly Highway, the road from Dunmurra to Top Springs and the proposed road to Wave Hill will serve large properties and the main beneficiaries will be large companies. The road from Katherine and Willeroo to Top Springs will serve principally the Victoria River Downs southern areas, Wave Hill and the new blocks and the properties around Top Springs, but the main beneficiaries here again are still the very large companies. The road across from Victoria River to Auvergne and Newry serves almost exclusively the large properties.

speech.para: Obviously, if we are to do what the Leader of the Australian Country Party suggested in 1938, a proposition with which I agree, and get people into the area we must try to take a more progressive view of subdivision in association with the availability of finance. There is no shortage of applicants; there is no shortage of good managers or young managers; there is no shortage of good white stockmen and their families to develop these areas; but certainly we must admit that there is a shortage of finance. This, I assume, is the main reason why the north at the present time is being taken over so quickly by absentee owners and predominantly foreign companies. If the Government is pleased to see the north becoming more and more a colony of overseas countries, certainly we in the Labour Party are not. First and foremost the problem should be tackled progressively and it should be tackled to give the maximum benefit to Australians.

There should not be a repetition of what we have seen in Alexandria in the ballot to which I have referred. I believe there were approximately 60 applicants who originally applied for the three blocks, and yet we have seen even Australians with a lifetime of experience in running cattie being unsuccessful in the ballot. One application was from Mr. Milton who has had a lifetime of experience in running cattle in Queensland in the tick and clear areas and in areas closely associated with the Mitchell and Flinders pastures which are the main grasses of the Barkly Tableland. Yet he has been denied access to the ballot, and he has the finance.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- It is not my intention to speak for long in this debate, but there are one or two points I would like to make. I should like to reply first to what the honorable member for Dawson (Dr. Patterson) has said. I think he really appreciates the Government's attitude towards foreign investment in this leasehold country in the Northern Territory. There is a significant difference between the development of leasehold country and the development of freehold country. The simple fact is that leasehold country developed in this way returns to the Crown after a period of time in a developed condition.
- That is not right.

- It is right. The leasehold country returns to the Crown in a developed condition. This is one way of assisting the overall development of Australia. I find myself in some sympathy with the honorable member's point about the exclusion of Australians from the ballot, but I see the difficulty of the Administration in this matter in that American capital could come in through the backdoor by way of a successful Australian applicant. At least, in this way we know where the capital is coming from.

speech.para: The honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) spoke about a single line budget for the Northern Territory. I find myself in sympathy with this suggestion too, but J suggest to the honorable member that perhaps he is starting at the wrong end. I suggest that it might be more advisable to have an extension of local government so that the people of the Territory would accept the responsibility for charging rates, for paying rates and for carrying out all the other functions of local government, before taking the step of having a single line budget. I repeat that 1 am in sympathy with the idea but it must come in due course and in the proper way. I know that many parts of the Northern Territory are accepting the principle and the responsibilities of local government now, but there must be an extension of this before a single line budget will be practicable.

One matter to which I wish to direct the attention of the Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes) is the need for a subsidy on superphosphate freights to the Northern Territory. It is my belief that phosphate is badly needed for the development of agricultural and pastoral areas in the high rainfall zone. I believe, too, that, given proper encouragement, an area of from 8 million to 10 million acres in that high rainfall zone could be developed if superphosphate were made available at a price at least comparable with that applying in the northern parts of Queensland. I understand that superphosphate now costs something like $54 a ton landed at Darwin, as against about half that price in the high rainfall zone of Victoria. I do not think there is' any way of overcoming this difficulty except by way of a straight out superphosphate freight subsidy, at least until we get to the point where the demand is such that phosphate manufacturers will see that it would be practicable and economic to construct a works in Darwin. Somebody has to give a lead in the use of phosphate, and I think that lead should come from the Government. I ask the Minister to give consideration to that point.

I come now to another point which has bugged me a little in recent years. I refer to the voting rights of the Northern Territory. I believe that the Northern Territory is deserving of full voting rights in this Parliament. I say this for the reason that the Northern Territory is the front line of Australia. It is a strategic area and is of extreme importance to the defence of the whole of Australia. It is a tremendously large area to represent, and I do not think there is any part of Australia where matters related to foreign affairs and defence are more important than they are to the Northern Territory. The people there are placed in different circumstances from the people of the southern States. In my view, therefore, the principle of one vote one value is of no real importance in this context. I know that the electoral population is only 17,000, but I believe the peculiar situation of the people of the Northern Territory justifies their right to have a full vote in the affairs of this nation. They should certainly have full voting rights on all matters relating to defence and foreign affairs that are debated in this Parliament. There are no people more vitally concerned with these problems than are the people represented by the honorable member for the Northern Territory (Mr. Nelson). I ask the Minister to give consideration to the points I have raised.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to draw the attention of the Committee to Australia's growing responsibilities towards her Territories. Australia now has Territories scattered far and wide. I know we are not debating Antarctica, but Australia has Territories in the Antarctic and is responsible for half the area in that region. We have the Territories of Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean. We have the Territory of Norfolk Island and we have the Territory of Papua and New Guinea. As the world progresses apace, Australia's responsibilities to her Territories will increase. So far, I have no complaint with the work carried out in our Territories by this and previous governments.

speech.para: Before dealing with Papua and New Guinea, I wish to emphasise the importance of Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands to Australia. The phosphate deposits on Nauru are showing signs of working out. It is estimated that they will last for only another 30 or 40 years. In the meantime, as honorable members know, the price of phosphate rook from Nauru is increasing. It seems to me to be increasing year by year, and there may come a time when it is just too expensive for us to buy. We are fortunate in having Christmas Island, although the phosphate rock there is of low quality. The agricultural industries of Australia are dependent upon phosphate, and we are very lucky to have such deposits as those on Christmas Island to fall back on. Christmas Island is a straight out Australian Territory. No doubt, as the years go by, Australia - will take greater interest in the area and develop it, because, as I have said, our agricultural industries . cannot be developed without phosphate rock.

Apart from that, there is the important defence angle to be considered. It is interesting to know that Christmas Island is nearer to Indonesia than it is to Australia. It lies 180 miles south of Indonesia while the nearest point in Australia to it - North West Cape - is some 875 miles away. The Cocos (Keeling) Islands are 600 miles from Indonesia and 1,200 miles from Australia. Both Territories, I am sure, are further from Australia than most people realise. Cocos (Keeling) Islands are important, because we learn from the annual report of the Department that last year some 274 nights were made to them. They were made mainly by Qantas. From the defence point of view, these islands are of the utmost importance to Australia. We all know that Britain is withdrawing from that part of the world, and as the British power decreases our possessions in this area will become all the more important.

I should like now to say a little about Papua and New Guinea. If we examine closely what has happened there over a very short period of time we will develop a better understanding of that Territory. Vast development has taken place in Papua and New Guinea since World War II. Before World War II, very few people went to New Guinea. Very few indeed gave a second thought to going there to live or of taking up land there, because most people believed that if they went there they would be stricken by all sorts of tropical diseases and that the future was not very bright. Consequently, in the early stages, except for the devoted people of the Administration, only the missionaries and a few planters went to Papua and New Guinea to try to start up a way of life there. The population of the area followed the example set by these earlier settlers. We have been very fortunate indeed that the people who went there in those early days were people of the right type and went there with the right ideals.

Papua was proclaimed a British protectorate on 6th November 1884 and General Sir Peter Scratchley was appointed the first Special Commissioner. He came to two important conclusions. The first was that the administration of justice according to European ideas was impossible. His second conclusion was that the showing of the flag by naval men-of-war was not suited to the purposes of administering justice and punishing outrages that might occur on the New Guinea coast. Outrages have not occurred there, Mr. Chairman. The indigenous people have followed the example set by the Europeans who have gone there. By the standards of world rule, the people of Papua have been educated in a unique fashion. As I have said, before World War II the country was very primitive. Disease was rife. It is only since scientists have found out how to cure or prevent certain diseases, including malaria, and how to cure and avoid complaints such as tinea, that the development of the country has expanded rapidly. That is understandable. Most of the servicemen who were in New Guinea during the war suffered from tinea. They took a long time to get over it. Most of the health problems have now disappeared. Consequently, there is a new phase of prosperity in the country.

Those of the native people who have worked and become by their own standards very rich find it hard to understand the views of their fellow countrymen. As I see the situation, the indigenous people of New Guinea must take stock of themselves. It is of no use for the dissatisfied inhabitants of the coastal areas merely to say: " This is what must be done ". This will be of no avail, because the people in the Highlands have different views altogether. The Highlands have been settled by Europeans and developed only since the end of World War II. Before the war, European settlement and development of any kind were found only on the coastal fringes. All the diseases that one could pick up in the tropics were common. In a short period, we have seen the country develop rapidly. 1 am rather alarmed when I read in the newspapers accusations by Russia that Australia is building up Papua and New Guinea as an arsenal and statements to the effect that this should not be done. I think it is to the credit of the Government and of the Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes) that last year the Minister made available some 34 reports on what took place when the United Nations mission toured the Territory. If one examines the views that were put to the mission, one will find a few complaints from the local people. Some said they wanted higher wages and others said they wanted schools. But generally they said: " Leave us alone. When the time is right, and we want independence, we shall say so." I think it would be very bad if we in Australia were to say: " You will be independent on such and such a date next year ". If we did that, we would . not be doing the right thing for the people of Papua and New Guinea. It is up to us to help them to establish an independent nation when they say that they want independence. I am sure that we shall only bring trouble on them if we try to make them run before they are able to walk. Some academics whom I know have told me: " The people of Papua and New Guinea must get independence - and they must get it quickly ". I say: Of course, they must have independence. But let them have it when they want it.

I believe that one of the great advances that has taken place in the Territory is the development of administration by means of local government councils. The indigenous people show great interest in these. Some of them now sit in their own House of Assembly. This represents a step in the right direction. But we know that more than half of them do not understand parliamentary government. Even though they have their own Parliament, we must not force them and try to make them understand too readily the meaning of parliamentary government, for they are not yet capable of understanding. I do not say that with any harshness towards the indigenous people. They have not reached the stage of understanding yet, but they will gradually get to it. They will then be in a position to administer their own affairs. However, I believe that at present they should hasten slowly.

I have mentioned complaints made by Russia. One complaint is that Australia is building airstrips in the Territory. The indigenous people themselves say that they want us to do this. Progress Report No. 16 on the United Nations mission to New Guinea states the views expressed by Robin Safetoa, a local government assistant, of Popondetta, who told the mission that he was concerned about the defence of the Territory. He said that the Pacific Islands Regiment was not strong enough and that defences in the Territory should be built up. The report states that he said that radio news of fighting in other countries was constantly heard and that greater preparation, including armament factories, was wanted. I believe that the Russians, through the United Nations, hear of statements such as these. Here we have these primitive people themselves saying that they want armament factories in the Territory and that defences ought to be built up.

I have not Lime to read to the Committee extracts from other reports. They show that the indigenous people have expressed grave fears about Indonesia, which shares a common border with the Territory. They want the Territory defended against any possible threat by Indonesia. All this has to be done with the means and the funds that we are able to give them in assisting them to put their affairs in order. I believe that what we have done in Papua and New Guinea has been well done. Australia has been criticised for spending too much money in the Territory and not enough elsewhere. So long as we promote the steady and gradual development of the people and encourage them to do the things that are within their capacity, we shall do the correct thing for them. When Papua was first taken over by Queensland, its boundaries were somewhat awry. A couple of weeks ago in this chamber, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Whitlam) pointed this out. It goes back to 1884, Mr. Chairman. Funnily enough, Queensland now has a common border with parts of Papua and New Guinea. But that was the attitude of those days. The record shows that Queensland's population was expected to be so great by 1950 that it would have to spill over into Papua and New Guinea. That is why the boundaries were drawn as they were.

I would say that it is in their own interest for the people of Papua and New Guinea to put their faith in Australia. We will stand by them as long as they want us. As soon as they are ready for self determination and apply for it, they will get it. I repeat that in my opinion it would be wrong to give self-determination to Papua and New Guinea before the people are ready for it.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- The Northern Territory, together with the rest of northern Australia, suffers some serious disadvantages compared with other parts of the Commonwealth. I refer particularly to freight charges. The Commonwealth Government has made some worthwhile contributions towards minimising some of these disadvantages. I refer, for example, to the subsidy on petrol, which ensures that people in outlying areas of the Northern Territory pay no more than 4d. a gallon in excess of the capital city price.

speech.para: I think all honorable members will agree that we must develop the north. If we are to do this we must take some practical steps towards assisting and encouraging people to live there. The cost of materials used in the construction of homes and factories is extremely high in the Northern Territory and in the northern part of Western Australia. Much of this high cost is due to freight charges. Many of the materials used in buildings are manufactured in the south and transported to the north. The cost of building a house in Kununurra, for instance, is almost twice as high as the cost of building a house in the south. There may be several reasons for this higher cost. Labour may be dearer in the north, for one thing.

As Australia has developed, most of our factories have been erected in the south. In developing new areas in the north it has been necessary to transport building materials over long distances. This will continue to be done until such time as these materials are manufactured in the north. I feel that the Government could give greater tax concessions to people living in the north to encourage its development. The people of the north are entitled to amenities such as air conditioning. But these things come from the south. The cost of everything that comes from the south contains a freight component, which is extremely high. We know that in Western Australia the Commonwealth Grants Commission has greatly assisted as far as shipping is concerned. But we should be looking for more ways to overcome the cost of freight. The subsidy on superphosphate has been referred to. I fully support the subsidy of $6 a ton on superphosphate used in Australia. This subsidy will help people in outlying areas, including the Northern Territory. But as I mentioned recently, 35 per cent, of the cost of superphosphate is incurred beyond the factory. No doubt superphosphate costs more the further you go from the factory. If we are to develop the north we must do something to level out the costs faced by the people who are prepared to go there and stay there. We know the problems associated with obtaining a home in the south. We know what it costs to build a home. We know that housing costs are rising. But they are much higher in the north than they are in the south. How can we expect people to go into the north and face these high costs when they can obtain homes considerably cheaper in the south? This is an important problem. We must consider also what can be done to encourage the establishment of small factories in the north.

In the new Parliament next year the only member without full voting rights will be the member for the Northern Territory. Having in mind what I have said about the development of the north, I think that the Government could well look into the matter of granting to the member for the Northern Territory full voting rights. The Northern Territory will grow rapidly. The member for the Northern Territory should have full voting rights in this Parliament.

talk.start.para: - What is the position now?

- At the moment two members of the Parliament do not have full voting rights. In the next Parliament only one will have restricted voting rights. The Northern Territory does not have a full voice in this Parliament. Having regard to the problems of the Territory and its proximity to our Asian neighbours, I think the Government should seriously consider granting to the member for the Northern Territory full voting rights.

speech.para: A lot has been said from time to time about development of the north. We all are of the same opinion on this matter. We have our own ships on our coastal runs. We have our Australian National Line. Western Australia has its shipping line. I have already referred to the assistance given to Western Australia in this regard by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. I think the Commonwealth Government has power to assist northern development by doing something about freight costs. If we reduced freight costs in the north we would be giving a tremendous boost to the Northern Territory by assisting in the building of homes and factories and the providing of commodities that go towards development of the north of Australia.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to address myself to the proposed expenditure for the Territory of Papua and New Guinea. We are in a special relationship to Papua and New Guinea. Although the honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hallett) is correct in his statement of the deficiencies of the Northern Territory as regards its representation in this place, at least that Territory has a member here. The people of Papua and New Guinea have no direct voice at all in this Parliament. So to that extent each of us is an honorary member for the Territory of Papua and New Guinea.

speech.para: One of the things that concerns me about the Territory is its relative isolation from Australia. This relates to a number of things, such as travel and administration. Let us examine for a moment the matter of air fares from Australia to the Territory. Let me give some details taken from a Trans-Australia Airlines timetable. These details apply equally to AnsettA.N.A. and other airlines operating to New Guinea. The distance from Cairns to Port Moresby is about 530 miles. The air fare is $58.20. The distance from Cairns to Coolangatta is about 900 miles, but the fare is only $58.40. So the person who lives in the Territory and the Territory people themselves :.re disadvantaged to the extent of the disparity between the air fares. In the Territory we are dealing with a particularly poor section of the Australian domain. These are the people who have the least amount of cash. Travel to them is a much more expensive operation that it is to the rest of us. For an Australian living in Papua and New Guinea for any reason, the distance to bc travelled before reaching the mainland of Australia is tremendous. I believe that the disparity in fares is a serious error in airline administration. I do not think any convincing argument can be advanced that it is any more expensive to operate across the Coral Sea than across the land spaces of Australia. The density or liquidity or whatever property air has is no different. In fact, it is part of international air travel. As far as Australia is concerned administratively, I believe that in such matters we ought to treat Papua and New Guinea as an integral part of the Australian scene.

The disparity exists not only in air fares but in other matters. It extends even to telephones. A telephone call from Port Moresby to Australia costs about 30s. lt is 12 months since 1 was there, but at that time the telephone service closed down at night and a fairly expensive late fee was charged to get it opened. I think in Australia the maximum charge for an internal telephone call is about 12s. 6d. or 15s. For instance, it is possible to make a call from Cairns to Perth for 15s. or thereabouts, but from Cairns to Port Moresby costs about 30s. I think that we are erecting a false barrier between Papua and New Guinea and Australia. Apart from that aspect, there is the simple economic barrier that we are creating between ourselves and the people who have the least amount of cash to spend.

This applies equally to what might be called the positive areas of travel. There is a lack of suitable shipping to Papua and New Guinea. The average citizen is unable to travel there. But at some time in the near future - 1 have no doubt that this will occur after the election - we will turn our attention to the relationships we should have in a number of areas, such as customs and shipping. In the world today, the barriers are coming down. French and Germans are now living in some amity and travel between the two countries is easy. Travel between Singapore and Malaysia, between the countries of Europe and elsewhere in world is relatively easy. But in this part of the world, where we ought to be setting standards, we are busy erecting barriers of our own. I believe that this isolation extends not only to what might be called material areas, but it is also found in the administration of the Territory.

I believe that it would be an advantage if members of the Parliament were able to travel to Papua and New Guinea as readily as if they were travelling internally in Australia. Most of us would go there only for special purposes, but there are those in the Parliament who have demonstrated a particular interest in Papua and New Guinea. It would be better for them to be able to go there once a year or as often as they wish. It would not be likely that we would find honorable members travelling more often than necessary. But the infrequency of travel to Papua and New Guinea makes it difficult to keep in touch with affairs there. This is an area in which progress would not cost the country much but would be of considerable advantage to Papua and New Guinea. I believe also that facilities ought to be provided for members of the House of Assembly to visit Australia with some frequency. The average citizen in Australia has the advantage or disadvantage, depending on the way we look at it, of 25 Commonwealth Ministers, of a. varying number of State Ministers - 8, 13 or 15, depending on the State - and of municipal councillors to look after his interests. But the people in Papua and New Guinea must look in general to only one department. I think the Postmaster-General's Department operates only in the field of broadcasting and does not provide postal services. The Department of Defence operates there and so does the Department of Civil Aviation. But in the specialised fields, such as education, health, agriculture and research, the people in the Territory must rely largely on the internal resources of the Public Service of Papua and New Guinea. I know that difficulties arise in the relationships between the services. But one of the big advantages Australians have in living under the auspices of the Commonwealth is that, no matter where they are, the full services of the Australian administration are available to them and remoteness is of no account.

I believe that the isolation of Papua and New Guinea from the specialist Australian services has been to the disadvantage of the Territory. I should think that this is particularly apparent in the field of education. There are some other problems that are difficult to tackle, but they should be consistently faced. There is the question of racial discrimination. It has been the policy of the Government, and it has been expressed by the Administrator and his officers from time to time quite effectively, that there should be no such thing as racial discrimination. But this discrimination is one of the prevailing characteristics of humanity. To the itinerant observer in Papua and New Guinea, there may seem to be no racial discrimination. In the Services - for instance, in the Army - I understand that now at the various levels, such as in the officers mess, people of different races associate freely and work with a sense of complete amity and unanimity. This would, I should think, be so in the House of Assembly itself. In some specialist areas there is no sense of racial discrimination, but in some areas, including the Public Service, there is still an indication of racial attitudes in the way that white people and black people separate. Apparently there is still a failure to admit black people to some clubs and so on. This is a serious matter, and I realise that it is difficult for the Administration to counter it. But I believe it is to the advantage of the Administration to attempt to do so. We should always discuss racial discrimination and express our concern at its existence so that Australians working and living in Papua and New Guinea will at least know that Australia disagrees with this discrimination.

I believe that development in Papua and New Guinea is lagging in three principal areas. They are education, industry and political development. I will deal briefly with each one of these. Papua and New Guinea has a tremendous educational problem. I will say that, as we look at the rest of the world, we realise that probably in Papua and New Guinea the social experiment in advancing people from a primitive state into the modern age is being carried on more successfully than anywhere else. It is to the great credit of this country that we are able to administer such a difficult area, with such diversity of peoples, ranging over such intimidating mountains, in such an effective way. But I still believe, as I have said here before, that the approach to education has been rather more diffident than it ought to be.

The school population in Papua and New Guinea is somewhere about 600,000. Of these, some 210,000 are in schools. Those are the figures that we received recently. In Papua and New Guinea, we are attempting to create an education system almost of the size of that of Victoria, lt is interesting to consider for a moment the problems that we face in this area. Honorable members may turn to the figures and see how many schools, students and teachers are in Papua and New Guinea. Victoria has 665,000 children of school age. We have about 487,000 in State schools and 178,000 in non-State schools. We have 2,229 government schools and 568 non-government schools, making a total of 2,797. But it is in the field of teachers that the figures are almost astronomical. Victoria has 24,352 full time teachers and 2,572 part time teachers. This was the position a couple of years ago. The statistics are readily available. Education costs about 82 or $164 a pupil. The cost of running the education system in Victoria is about $25 per head of population. If this standard were applied to Papua and New Guinea, it would mean that the Government ought to be spending about $100 million on education alone.

The extension of education in Papua and New Guinea, of course, presents great difficulties, but when I have been there I have been unable to convince the people to whom I have spoken that there are any real dynamics behind the Government's approach to education. I believe that the recommendation by the World Bank that there be a cut back in the development of education was a mistake. This is the most important area of development in Papua and New Guinea. Only an educated society will be able to develop itself in the face of world competition in the sale of its various products; only an educated society will be able to take its place in the community of the world. Before this can be done, and before it will be really effective, there will have to be substantial indus trial development. It is a fallacy to wait for private enterprise to develop enterprise in Papua and New Guinea. With all the evidence of recent history before him it would have to be a particularly benevolent capitalist who would pour great sums of money into Papua and New Guinea. It may well be that there is no fear of expropriation, but the capitalists of the world are realists and I consider it a complete fallacy to wait for them to develop industry in this Territory. Therefore it is a question for this Government to tackle.

There should be substantial government industrialisation of Papua and New Guinea. Public enterprise will have to undertake the industrialisation. It has been the misfortune of Papua and New Guinea that it has been beset by probably the two most conservative Ministers who could have been appointed from this Liberal Party and Country Party Government. Their attitudes have been bound to doctrines rather than to the needs of the people of Papua and New Guinea. Consider the simple question of clothing. Why is there not a substantial clothing manufacturing business in Papua and New Guinea? Why is there not a substantial shoe manufacturing industry there? These are light industries that could be embarked upon without great capital expenditure and in which it would be relatively easy to train people. I believe this is the first element in what we might call the material side of the development and industrialisation of Papua and New Guinea. The other element to which I want to refer is, of course, the parliamentary political development of the Territory. The honorable member for Batman (Mr. Benson) said we must go slowly. I do not think we can go much more slowly than now in the political development of the Territory. There has been a very tentative approach towards democratic government there. The Territory House of Assembly is a vehicle towards the independence of Papua and New Guinea. Independence and self determination are relative questions. The Australian Commonwealth for 50 or 60 years expended much time in trying to get rid of the shackles of Whitehall and is now getting a new lot forged in the White House.

Independence is related to industrial development, to a place in the world and to attitudes on this, that and the other. Every time the House of Assembly passes a new law - whether it is to ban the playing of cards, whether it is to extend the Public Service, whether to raise the school leaving age or to provide whether vehicles should drive on the right or left of the road - and it goes through the various echelons of approval and finally is not rejected by the Minister, that is a step on the road to self determination and independence. 1 recommend honorable members to read the report of the Select Committee on Constitutional Development in Papua and New Guinea. Their Parliament is going to be the instrument of the future of the people there and part of their future relationships with us. It must be expanded; it must be given more membership; it must be given more resources; its members must be given the ability to move around the country, and greater faith must be placed in it. Papua and New Guinea is one of the great social experiments going on in the world today. It is Australia's most important trusteeship. We cm show by the way in which we develop and extend future relationships between us that here is a new element of man's relation to man, despite material resources, despite race and despite background. This is our greatest challenge, and 1 hope that in the near future we will accept it in a much more effective way than we have done so far.

talk.start.para: . - I think that the honorable member for Wills (Mr. Bryant) made a very good point when he said that two of the most conservative Ministers in the Government have, for the last 17 years, controlled the destinies of Papua and New Guinea. This was certainly an understatement. For a long time I thought the present Minister for Territories (Mr. Barnes) was lazy in his job; that this could be the only possible explanation for some of the decisions taken; that he was allowing the departmental heads and the administrators in the Department to make decisions for him, and though they were bad decisions he was too lazy to bother about correcting them. But as I study him more closely I am satisfied it was not the fault of the administrators at all, or of the departmental heads, but that it was the wilful decision of the Minister himself that backward, retrograde points of view should be imposed upon the people who were unfortunate enough to come under his control.

speech.para: I was fortunate enough to have the opportunity to visit Papua and New Guinea some six years ago and I was able to gather quite a lot of useful information while I was there. The first thing I discovered was that the natives of New Guinea are probably among the most exploited people in the Southern Hemisphere.

talk.start.para: - Is this the view of the honorable member?
- Order! I ask the honorable member for Corangamite to cease interjecting.

- I dare say that the honorable member who is interjecting is envious of the cheap labour that is available in New Guinea. He would love to have such labour on his wealthy western district estates so that he could employ people at about 6s. 9d. - I am sorry, the wages have increased by about SO per cent, to 9s. - a week plus feed. It is amazing when one realises it, that an enlightened people such as we claim to be should have the hide, the cheek, to allow these native people to be employed at the miserable pittance of about 9s. a week and keep, lt is about time we had a look at ourselves.
- What would the honorable member suggest?
- I suggest that they be paid the same rate, for the same work, as a white man receives.
- This is good news for the planters.
- It is elementary, surely. It ought to be so. Where a New Guinean driver of a bulldozer drives just as well as a white man he ought to get the same rate of pay as the white man.
- Who is going to pay it?
- The employers, of course. Who does the honorable member think should pay it?
- Who are the employers?

- The employers for the time being would be Burns Philp & Co. Ltd., W. R. Carpenter & Co. Ltd. and some of the other companies that have grown fabulously wealthy from the sweat and toil of underpaid natives. This is who should pay the natives. If they cannot pay them, then the quicker they get out and admit that they are incapable of running an industry in New Guinea the better for everybody concerned. Instead of letting W. R. Carpenter, Burns Philp and the other wealthy millionaire exploiters in New Guinea continue to exploit the natural resources and the cheap manpower of New Guinea, why does not the Minister say to the natives: " Look, we will give you an opportunity of running your own cooperatives. We will help you." Let us not forget that the Government is helping Burns Philp and W. R. Carpenter very handsomely now.
- There are hundreds of co-operatives.

- There are nothing of the kind. I will tell the honorable member something about co-operatives in a moment if he will bear with me. The millions of pounds that we pour into New Guinea each year find their way into the pockets of companies like Burns Philp and W. R. Carpenter. It would be far better for us to be using this money to finance and to sponsor co-operatives run by the natives for the benefit of the natives. When I was there about six years ago I was disgusted to read that the Minister's illustrious predecessor had granted, or had allowed somebody else to grant, a huge tract of wonderful cattle country in the Markham Valley to Bulolo Gold Dredging Ltd.
- In the Markham Valley?
- Yes.
- The honorable member has his geography mixed up.
- Where is it then?
- Bulolo is near Wau.

- I said that a huge tract of cattle country in the Markham Valley had been handed over to Bulolo Gold Dredging Ltd. That is what I said. It was handed over at the princely sum of 6d. an acre a week on a SO year lease. How could that be justified when there are pockets of native population in New Guinea bursting at the seams and crying out for land? Here was land - a huge area upon which this Government had already spent enormous sums in development - that could have been set aside for a native cooperative. But nothing was done. I have said before, and I repeat, that the money we spend in New Guinea, if we are to get the best value for it, has to be spent in developing a cultural corridor running parallel to the Indonesian border and working eastward. This idea of spending all of the money in Port Moresby where the Administrator happens to have his cocktail bar, or within easy radius of Port Moresby, has to end. If we are going to establish true defence for the people that we are caring for in New Guinea, and if we want to get a proper return for the money we are spending there, we ought to remember that the day cannot be far distant when there will be a border dispute between West Irian and East New Guinea. What will we be able to do to stand up to our responsibilities to the natives in the event of such a border dispute? Virtually nothing at all. The reason we will be able to do nothing at all is that we have not attempted to develop a cultural oneness, a oneness of language or some tie which will unite the people we care for in the corridor running parallel to the eastern border.

speech.para: This is where we should be establishing our medical aid posts and our schools and be doing everything we can, as quickly as we can, to teach the English language to all the youngsters for a start. If we cannot teach it to the older members of the population, let us commence by teaching English to the youngsters living in the villages there in the hope we can do the job effectively enough so that in the event of a dispute these people will at least be able to converse with each other. There are something like 500 different languages in New Guinea, so different indeed that it is utterly impossible for any one of the 500 language groups to understand even one word spoken by the other language groups. There will never be a united New Guinea - at any rate, united to the degree of being able to defend itself against Indonesia - until we weld the people together into at least a one language group. This has not been done and no attempt is being made to do it. I believe that none of the missions should receive any more aid from the Government until they agree to teach the one language. We have the fantastic position at present of some missions teaching in German, some in the native tongue of the particular localities, others in Pidgin, others in Motu, others in English and others in any other language which happens to be favoured by the particular missionary. This is not good. We should be insisting that all schools - both government schools and missionary schools which are financed by the Government - should teach only one language, English.

Before concluding I want to get closer to home and to refer to the strange position which has arisen at Alexandria Downs. The Minister knows something about this. I am sure he is not completely ignorant about it. Some time ago a certain part of Alexandria Downs was acquired for redistribution. Three blocks were taken. Applications were called for the blocks and it was decided that a ballot would be held. Some time ago I learned from the Minister, in reply to a question, that for one block there were 24 applications. Three of these were withdrawn or were rejected because they were late. Twenty were arbitrarily excluded from the ballot by the Land Board and there were 18 protests with the result that only three of the applications remained in the ballot. Just think of that: Of the 24 who applied to go in the ballot only three were allowed to enter. The others had been arbitrarily excluded from the ballot by the Board and had no chance of winning. The three who were in the ballot had a 3 to 1 chance of winning. I will have more to soy about that later. For the second block 55 applications were received. Of these five were either withdrawn or were rejected because they were late; and 36 were not even allowed to go into the ballot, in the result, only 20 were allowed in the ballot. For the final block 58 applications were received. Four of these were withdrawn or were rejected because they were late, 39 were excluded and only 21 were allowed in the ballot.

Then a rather odd kind of situation seemed to develop because one of the applicants which was successful in the ballot was an American firm which already had a holding of 2,000 square miles in the Northern Territory.
