That company was allowed to enter the ballot and was successful. The other two blocks were won by different companies but it is interesting to note that one person was a partner in both of them. I happen to know three of the applicants who were excluded from the ballot. One is Mr. P. J. Browne who has had a tremendous amount of experience in the cattle industry. He had 80.000 which he could have made available for the development of the land but he was excluded because he did not have sufficient relevant experience. I tried to squeeze out of the Minister some explanation of the magic term " insufficient relevant experience". I thought the Minister might have interjected at that point.

talk.start.para: - I am waiting to have my say later.
- I do not know what is meant by relevant experience but Mr. Browne had more than 20 years experience.
- Does years mean experience?

- Yes it does, the kind of experience he had. I do not know whether the Minister's clerks in the Land Board told him that this gentleman had more than 20 years experience in the cattle industry. I do not know whether the clerks in the Land Board told the Minister that Mr. C. Milton, another applicant who was excluded on the ground of insufficient experience, had a tremendous amount of experience. He comes from Queensland and probably knows more about the cattle industry than the Minister or any of his clerks who rejected the application will ever know. He also had plenty of money to invest.

speech.para: Another applicant who was rejected, a Mr. Mahommed, also had a fund of experience in the cattle industry. He had been in it nearly all his life - in fact since he had been a little boy in short trousers - but he did not have much money and was told: " You have been rejected because you have not enough money". But that could not have been said about Mr. Browne because he had $80,000 to put into the project as soon as he was granted a lease, so to overcome that difficulty the clerks, in the case of Mr. Browne and Mr. Milton, used the excuse that they did not have sufficient relevant experience. In my question I asked the Minister -

quote.para: Were about 40 applicants to enter the ballot excluded from the ballot?

speech.para: The answer, of course, was " Yes ". Then I asked -

quote.para: Is it a fact that at least two of those excluded (Messrs. P. J. Browne and C. Milton) were excluded on the grounds that they had insufficient relevant experience?

speech.para: Again the answer was " Yes ". Then I asked the Minister -

quote.para: Can he say whether both of these applicants did in fact have considerable experience in the cattle industry?

speech.para: The answer prepared by his clerks was -

quote.para: It was the considered opinion-

speech.para: Listen to this - of the Northern Territory Land Board that these applicants did not have sufficient relevant experience.

I know that was the reason why they were rejected. I mentioned that in my question. What I was trying to learn then and what I am trying to squeeze out of the Minister now is what is meant by this term " insufficient relevant experience ". Will he tell us what it means? Will he tell everyone in Australia what it means? Do not try to pull the wool over my eyes, Mr. Minister, by using this magic phrase.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

. - I am delighted to note the wide range of interest shown in the estimates for the Department of Territories. Unfortunately I was on duty in Cabinet and was unable to hear the first part of the speech by the honorable member for Mackellar (Mr. Wentworth) although I did hear the latter part of it in which he suggested that Aboriginal reserves should be utilised to a greater extent than they are for the benefit of the Aborigines. I agree with his suggestion and I hope to be able to announce soon some policy along these lines because, obviously, if they are to have any future in the pastoral, agricultural or, for that matter, mining industry, something should be done to help them. I may add that on one reserve to the north of Alice Springs the Aborigines are working a copper show. They have quite a lot of copper at grass and I think this could be quite a good operation. It is our great aim to find useful and profitable occupations for these people. Honorable members have probably noticed reports in the Press that quite a number of them are engaged in asparagus picking in the Gundagai district, where they are earning most satisfactory wages.

speech.para: This is a most important development. It stems from a visit I paid to the Riverina early last year, when 1 was impressed by the need for seasonal labour for the picking of vegetables and so on. I formed the opinion that this was an excellent operation for Aborigines. We brought down 60 or 70 of them last year, with very great success. We have had requests to bring many more. They receive full award rates and they have made a very good impression in these areas. The asparagus picking in the Gundagai district is one manifestation of this scheme and I hope it can be extended further.

The honorable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr. Crean) criticised the Government for not spending enough money in Papua and New Guinea. I believe that we are spending to the very limit of our resources in that country. In this connection I would like to quote some figures. This being a kind of progressive operation, I may say that in 1954-55 the total budget for Papua and New Guinea was $20.5 million while in 1966-67 it is $120 million. This shows a very steep rise. Australia's contribution per capita in Papua and New Guinea is far greater than that of any other developed country to any other underdeveloped country in the world. Tn Kenya, for instance, the contribution from outside is about $5 per capita. In Ghana it is also probably $5 per capita. Australia's contribution in Papua and New Guinea amounts to $35 per capita, and I think this is something we can be very proud of. We are making a mighty effort in trying to advance the people of the Territory. There is a lot more to be done, certainly, but we are developing a country ourselves and we are quite short of many resources.

I very much appreciated the contribution of the honorable member for Riverina (Mr. Armstrong), and particularly his remarks about the Northern Territory. He has had a good deal of experience in the pastoral industry and obviously his comments are ot great value. His observations on Papua and New Guinea were also of great interest because he served there with much distinction during the war and he obviously appreciates the great advances that have been made.

The honorable member for Dawson (Dr. Patterson) was probably a little more moderate than the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron), because the honorable member for Dawson has a better understanding of the position and has not as much imbalance as the honorable member for Hindmarsh has. Nevertheless I was rather surprised at the way in which the honorable member for Dawson went off at a tangent with his suggestions about the areas into which this country should be cut up. If we study the history of land settlement in Australia we will find that great tragedies have occurred because districts have been cut up into areas that have been far too small and completely uneconomic. With all the goodwill and hard work in the world, men have suffered a great deal of hardship. I am particularly concerned about what has happened to the wives and families of men who have worked so willingly to help them on these small areas and have suffered great hardships in consequence. Of course this suggestion of cutting districts up into small areas is quite characteristic of Labour land policy in Australia, which has been a failure in whatever area one might study its application.

When honorable members criticise the large station owners in the Northern Territory they should look at the history of land settlement in the Territory. It is only in recent years that pastoral activity in the Territory has been in any way profitable. This has been a most isolated area and in a sense it has been simply a breeding area for cattle that have been fattened in districts to the south. This was the only profitable operation for years in the Northern Territory. Most of the owners of stations in the Northern Territory sent their mobs of store cattle south and fattened them there. There has been recently a rise in prices, but I might remind the Committee that after cattle prices dropped to disastrously low levels in 1920-21 there was a period of about 25 years when property owners in the Northern Territory received no reasonable profit at all. lt is only in recent years that these people have had any decent return on their investment.

I was rather glad that the honorable member for Dawson commented on the excellent management of Brunette Downs before it was taken over by the King Ranch organisation, because two cousins of mine were successive managers of that property. I agree with the honorable member for Dawson because I think these two men knew something about the industry and the district and they set a pretty good example of development there.

One field in which we are at a disadvantage in the Northern Territory is that of land laws. The land ordinances are completely out of date. They have been amended and added to and so on, and they are completely inflexible. Soon after I became Minister and had to make decisions on matters of leases I became aware of this and realised that we must have a completely new set of land ordinances. I have had a study group working on this for the last two years and I hope to bring something forward soon and to present it to the Northern Territory Legislative Council. It will be laid on the table of that Council and there will be discussion about it. We have a great history of land laws in Australia and I believe we will be able to devise something very useful for the Northern Territory.

The honorable member for Gippsland (Mr. Nixon) commented on the necessity of providing reasonably cheap superphosphate in the area, and of course I quite agree with him. But, despite its high cost, superphosphate is being used to an increasing extent. The use of this commodity increased from 171 tons in 1963-64 to an estimated 3,000 tons this year. It is making progress but I agree that before we can achieve very effective use of the land in the higher rainfall areas of the Northern Territory we will have to provide superphosphate at much reduced rates. Again I may say that the use of superphosphate will increase most substantially when it becomes economically possible for one of the superphosphate manufacturers to operate in the Territory. Then there is another factor, of course, which has to do with the use of certain grades of rock phosphate from Christmas Island. We may be able to get some of these grades in. bulk to the Northern Territory, which would make for a cheaper operation.

I was impressed by the comments of the honorable member for Batman (Mr. Benson). He has a great understanding of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea and his comments were most relevant. 1 was particularly interested in his suggestions on the possibilities of developing the Christmas Island phosphate operations. As he said, very great opportunities exist there. Over the last two years we have been able to establish very much larger reserves of rock phosphate on Christmas Island. Only a couple of years ago the estimated reserves were 90 million tons. So far we have been able to establish reserves of 200 million tons, which will ease our dependence on other areas in the world. Of course, it will take a year or two to take full advantage of those reserves. Production will be stepped up from about 750,000 tons a year at present to about one million tons next year and probably to more than 2i million tons by 1972. These deposits offer great prospects for increased production.

The honorable member for Canning (Mr. Hallett) commented on the difficulties of the freight situation in the Northern Territory. This is always a problem in any isolated area. I believe that the situation will gradually right itself, with the tremendous operations of the mining companies in the Territory. There are the present operations on Groote Eylandt; the iron ore operations that will be starting soon south of Darwin, as a result of which exports from the Darwin harbour will increase by about 100 per cent, over the next two years; the operations of the Gove bauxite enterprise when it commences production; and the McArthur River operations. These will mean more ports and considerably more shipping to and from the Northern Territory. There will be a two way cargo operation, compared with the one way operation that has existed up to the present time. Obviously, this will be a big factor in the reduction of freight charges.

talk.start.para: - Under what flag will the ships operate?

- Let us hope that the trade will open to ships of all flags. That is the best way to achieve cheaper opera tion. God help the people of the Northern Territory if they had to depend on cargo shipping under only the Australian flag, because that is a most expensive operation. It is certainly all right for bulk cargo operations, but not for general cargo operations. The high cost of operation has wiped Australian cargo vessels off our coast.

speech.para: The honorable member for Wills (Mr. Bryant) commented on the necessity for education in Papua and New Guinea. I agree that it is very necessary. I believe that we have education going hand in hand with economic development because, after all, if we educate people we have to have jobs for them to go to. He mentioned the commencement of new industries. This is important, too. But where he and I differ is on his view that these new industries should be government industries. We will have no hope in the world if we try to develop a country on government spending. We have to provide an economic incentive for private enterprise. That is what we are doing. We are encouraging the very great advance in industrial development in Papua and New Guinea.

We have introduced a pioneer industry scheme under which, for a period of years, a company receives taxation relief. Eleven new industries have been granted pioneer industry concessions. Applications from another 12 industries are coming up. These are small industries, but I hope they will grow. The important thing is that they will provide job opportunities for local people. That is what we are setting out to do.

talk.start.para: - They will provide opportunities to exploit the natives.

- The honorable member again mentions exploitation. I cannot help feeling that he has a warped mind in most directions. He is difficult to understand. He said that we should pay Australian award wages to plantation workers. That shows that he has a complete misunderstanding of the economics of the Territory. It produces coffee, copra and cocoa in competition with the rest of the equatorial countries which have probably the lowest wage conditions in the world. If the wages were increased these industries would be put out of operation. Many of the local people are engaged in these industries. These are

speech.para: The honorable member for Hindmarsh concluded his remarks with his estimate of the relative competency of the people who put in for the ballot for the Alexandria holdings. Who is going to assess the relative worth of applicants for land areas? It will certainly not be the honorable member for Hindmarsh and it certainly will not be the Minister for Territories. There has to be some body of men with experience and honesty, and thoroughly impartial. What better can be done than to have a land board set up? This is done in the States. The people in the Territory who handle these matters are completely impartial, experienced and honest. I believe this is the only satisfactory way in which it can be done. As I mentioned before, these overseas companies cannot be excluded, because the land laws of the Northern Territory do not provide for this rather irrational attitude to what is called absentee ownership by foreign companies. This thing has to be looked at in its true perspective. The honorable member for Dawson was not quite as irrational as his leader, whom I heard quoted as saying that 60,000 square miles were owned by foreign companies. Half of that area - 30,000 square miles - is British owned. Are those people foreign? Are we going to call our close ancestors, in many cases, foreigners? This is a new attitude to British people. Certainly the rest of this area, 30,000 square miles, is owned by American, British and Chinese interests, the Chinese being of British nationality. That is out of a total of 500,000 square miles in the Northern Territory. I admit that probably only half of this area is capable of useful land development, but this is only a fractional operation. It is leasehold land. It is still Crown land, it is only leased. It will not be owned by these foreign interests. Opposition members should get into their minds that this land is still owned by the Government. That is all I have to say, Mr. Chairman.

talk.start.para: . - The matter I wish to raise is one of considerable importance to a large number of people in Western Australia and particularly in the electorate of Kalgoorlie which covers nine-tenths of the State. I refer to the provision for establishment of television in the districts of Kalgoorlie and Geraldton. Although we have been pursuing this matter for five years and have been pressing the Postmaster-General (Mr. Hulme) and his predecessor to provide such a service, we are no nearer today to receiving a definite answer than we were when we started. Because of our continuing representations over a long period of time, the first point to which I direct attention tonight is an article which appeared in the " Kalgoorlie Miner " on 15th September. This is a report of a meeting of the

speech.para: Chamber of Commerce in Kalgoorlie. It stated -

quote.para: Kalgoorlie-Boulder people had spent about $40,000 on the installation of television receivers and masts in their homes, chamber was told yesterday.
A chamber member, Mr. K. Willison, was commenting on a letter received from the goldfields branch of the Democratic Labour Party.
The letter contained answers by the Postmaster-General, Mr. Hulme, to questions asked in the Senate by the D.L.P. Leader, Senator McManus.

Mr. Hulme said that although T.V. transmissions could be made over the proposed East-West microwave link which will pass through Kalgoorlie, no provision had yet been made for the link to service a station here.

speech.para: Then the report stated -

quote.para: Mr. Willison said the Postmaster General had claimed he had had no indication that goldfields people wanted a television station.

speech.para: Unfortunately I have not been able to locate any reference in the Senate " Hansard " to the question which the newspaper reports was asked by Senator McManus so I have not been able to determine whether the report is correct or not. But if the report is correct and the Postmaster-General said he had no indication that the goldfields people wanted a television station it is a remarkable and, in fact, a dishonest statement. I would hate to arrive at that conclusion because while the Postmaster-General has been very evasive on this matter of television for the district, I would not suggest for a moment that he had been dishonest. Why should he say he has had no indication that the people require a station on the goldfields? Even if the Minister does not accept my representations - and they have been several - as being an approach on behalf of the goldfields, and even if he discounts approaches made by the Chamber of Commerce and the Shires of Kalgoorlie, Geraldton and Esperance, and treats their request as of no consequence, surely he cannot ignore the petition signed by hundreds of goldfields and Geraldton people which was lodged in the Senate a considerable time ago. So I hope the Minister will oblige us with either a substantiated denial of this report in the newspaper or give some explanation of it.

talk.start.para: - I did not say it, if that is of any help to the honorable member.

- If this article is a correct report of what the Minister said, and it must be coupled with the information I have received regarding a meeting between the Minister and the Managers of TVW Ltd. and Swan Television Ltd., then one must have very grave doubts whether the Government ever intends to extend the television service beyond phase 4, or whether it intends to do so after a long time. We must come to that conclusion from what the Minister has said in his replies to questions and statements. I suggest that he is either being deliberately evasive or he is using that method rather than give a definite refusal to our several requests. He has been reported as telling the television managers that it was impossible to expect that all country areas in Australia could be covered by television. He went on to say that television coverage when phase 4 was completed would be 91 per cent, of the Australian population and he considered that this was an exceptionally good figure. If he has been correctly reported in that respect it must surely mean that he considers that when phase 4 is completed Australia will be sufficiently served by television and that at least for some time it would be unwarranted to extend the service any further.

speech.para: Honorable members will be aware that it has been decided to install a microwave telecommunication link between Adelaide and Perth and that it will pass close to Kalgoorlie. As recently as the 15th of last month I asked a question on whether this would make it possible to extend television to Kalgoorlie. I received the usual evasive reply that it may be relevant to the provision of television for Kalgoorlie. The Minister went on to say that he had asked the Control Board to prepare a report with regard to a further extension and that full consideration would be given to the question of providing television in Kalgoorlie.

As I said earlier, it is five years since we really started to push television for Kalgoorlie, yet we find today, after a very full examination of all the pros and cons of the microwave link that must have been made well prior to' the decision to install it, that the Minister is saying he has only just decided to call for a report on whether a television link should be provided in the communication link. It does not just sound right. Let us look at something else that the Minister has told us.

On the 21st of last month I asked the Postmaster-General whether with regard to low power stations in remote areas he would consider extending or relaxing the existing limitation of control of commercial television stations. I think that was the only time that I ever received a deliberate answer. He said he certainly would not. However, he went on to say that the Department had not been able to get any application for a licence for the areas I had referred to. Of course, it would not have been surprising if he had not received any because the fact is that the licence limitation is an obstructing factor.

What I wish to point out is that both TVW Ltd. and Swan Television Ltd. of Western Australia claim that the Postmaster-General's statements about not having received any concrete proposals for the establishment of television stations if the Act were amended with regard to licences were quite misleading. They point out that they have made several approaches. This seems to be borne out by an article which appeared in yesterday's issue of the "West Australian". I should like to know what the Postmaster-General's attitude is in relation to this. The article is headed " TVW Offers Early Service for Fields, Geraldton " and goes on to state -

quote.para: Kalgoorlie and Geraldton could have television in 9 to 12 months under a proposal made to the Australian Broadcasting Control Board by TVW Ltd.
TVW managing director J. W. Cruthers said yesterday that the company had submitted a $250,000 scheme for package stations at the two centres.

speech.para: The article goes on to explain what that would mean and then states -

quote.para: Mr. Cruthers said that the TVW proposal could not be carried out if the board insisted on classing the package stations as separate operating licences

speech.para: A little later it states -

quote.para: When television began in W.A. in 1959, TVW offered to co-operate with the board in extending services to country areas, Mr. Cruthers said.

speech.para: Further down this appeared -

quote.para: TVW had made a number of approaches to the board in an effort to speed the expansion of country television, but nothing had come of them

speech.para: This, I suggest, refutes what the Postmaster-General has said, that is, that there would be no approaches or applications in regard to those stations if the Act were amended.

The General Manager of Swan Television Ltd., Mr. R. J. Mercer, said on the day before yesterday that his company would be interested in establishing a package television station in either Kalgoorlie or Geraldton if existing legislation were altered to allow the operation of such a station without its being regarded as the subject of a second licence. It would seem to me that here is a possibility of obtaining some type of service - certainly not as good as I would like to see - in those areas, but if the Minister is to be adamant in relation to limitation of licences it is idle for these people to pursue this particular offer. I suggest that the time has arrived for the Minister to make a definite decision in relation to national stations in these places. Will they be made available and, if so, when will they be made available? Also, is this offer of TVW Ltd. to be examined to see whether it has any value, or is it just to be scrapped because the Minister is not prepared to relax the provisions of the Broadcasting and Television Act in relation to the control of low powered stations?

talk.start.para: . - What I have to say could have been more properly put during the debate on the estimates for the Prime Minister's Department, but unfortunately the Whips were not able to find time for me on that occasion, and because this matter is not unimportant I feel it reasonable that I should put it now. I want to refer to our diplomatic representation in Great Britain. On the outbreak of World War II, we had precisely one diplomatic post abroad, and that was in London. Today we have 70 such posts. No doubt it v/as reasonable at that time that, not having a separate Department of External Affairs, Australia House should be administered by the Prime Minister's Department. But many years have gone by. No other dominion, no other part of the British Commonwealth, so far as I know, has a High Commissioner or an Ambassador in London whose department is administered from the prime ministers office in the country of origin. We alone retain this situation. It is anomalous and it ought to be changed. Indeed, I shall be pursuing the matter further. Tonight, all that I want to do is to adumbrate the situation.

speech.para: We have indeed in London, at Australia House, a representative of the Department of External Affairs. He is quite a senior officer, who represented us for many years with great distinction in Kuala Lumpur. But he ranks about fifth, I think, in the hierarchy of Australia House, and his task is not to report upon the situation in Britain at all but to report upon British policies abroad - British policies outside United Kingdom. Now, Sir, what needs to be done at any diplomatic post? Of course, if we have an Ambassador or High Commissioner - it does not matter which - in a place like Britain, what we want to know is what is going on in Britain that affects us; what is going on in the political field. For example, if there is a Labour Party conference at Blackpool or wherever the Labour Party chooses to have a conference, or if there is a Conservative Party conference and the Conservative Party is likely to find itself in government, we want to know what are the policies that may affect us in future - policies on defence, policies on trade and so forth. That is what we need. That is the kind of reporting we want from any diplomatic post. We do not have that situation in London. No doubt the High Commissioner himself, who is a former distinguished member of this House, does report along those lines. I have the highest respect for him. Nor am T raising the question whether a former member of Parliament or a former Minister should be a High Commissioner, or whether he should be some man with a diplomatic training. I am not raising this issue at all. Indeed, I believe we are very well represented by Sir Alexander Downer with whom I sat in this House for a number of years and for whom I have the highest regard. Anglophile as he is, I could not imagine anybody who would be more acceptable in Britain to represent us. So I am not raising that issue at all. What I am saying is that his staff is not a diplomatic staff because the High Commission is administered by the Prime Minister's Department and not by the Department of External Affairs.

talk.start.para: - That is right.

- -Well, it is wrong. Everybody here knows that in an embassy you have not only the ambassador himself but also the various officers who get around among the people in the country concerned - in England these would be the people in Whitehall - and who obtain information that is of immense value to us in this country. In London we do not have that kind of staff because it happens that the High Commission is still administered by the Prime Minister's Department. We do not have these skilled people who are able to get around and supplement what the High Commissioner can do. The High Commissioner in London is a particularly busy man. He is busy with many other things. As we all know, vast numbers of Australian visitors go to London and no doubt they occupy some part of his time. Also, a number of other departments, including the Department of Immigration, the Department of the Treasury, and the Department of Defence are represented in London and these all involve for the High Commissioner's staff considerable administrative duties.

speech.para: What I suggest is that the time has long gone by when the post in London should be regarded as other than a diplomatic post from which we should be able, because it is properly staffed, to get the sort of reports we get from other countries. This is a throw back to the past, a historical accident, an anachronism and it is high time it was altered.

I do not want to let the matter simply rest there. I have drawn attention to an anomaly, and something ought to be done about it. The time has come when we should revise many of our old ideas and get up to date. I was going to ask the Minister at the table but he is no longer in the chair, so I ask whoever is in charge of the House - if anybody is - to convey to the Prime Minister what I have said because it is not unimportant. I would like the Prime Minister to confer with the Minister for External Affairs and see whether something can be done to correct this anomalous situation.

If the Government, the Prime Minister and the Minister for External Affairs take the view that what has persisted for so many years is still correct, then I would expect that an explanation will be given to the House. I am raising a serious and important matter and Parliament - this House - and the public are entitled to be told the answer. If what I have said is right, then the position should be remedied. If the Government believes that what has been done for so long is still the best thing that ought to be done, then I think the Parliament is entitled to a defence of the Government's policy. In any event, I have raised a not unimportant matter and I would ask whoever is in charge of the House to see that it is drawn to the attention of the appropriate people and that an answer is given.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 12.40 a.m. (Thursday).
